circonus-datasource-account.body:
data "account" "$1" {
    # id - (Optional) The Circonus ID of a given account.
    id = ""

    # current - (Optional) Automatically use the current Circonus Account attached
    current = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "address1" - The first line of the address associated with the account.
    # "address2" - The second line of the address associated with the account.
    # "cc_email" - An optionally specified email address used in the CC line of invoices.
    # "id" - The Circonus ID of the selected Account.
    # "city" - The city part of the address associated with the account.
    # "contact_groups" - A list of IDs for each contact group in the account.
    # "country" - The country of the user's address.
    # "description" - Description of the account.
    # "invites" - An list of users invited to use the platform.  Each element in the list has both an "email" and "role" attribute.
    # "name" - The name of the account.
    # "owner" - The Circonus ID of the user who owns this account.
    # "state_prov" - The state or province of the address associated with the account.
    # "timezone" - The timezone that events will be displayed in the web interface for this account.
    # "ui_base_url" - The base URL of this account.
    # "usage" - A list of account usage limits.  Each element in the list will have a "limit" attribute, a limit "type", and a "used" attribute.
    # "users" - A list of users who have access to this account.  Each element in the list has both an "id" and a "role".  The "id" is a Circonus ID referencing the user.
}
circonus-datasource-account.description:
`circonus_account` provides
[details](https://login.circonus.com/resources/api/calls/account) about a specific
[Circonus Account](https://login.circonus.com/user/docs/Administration/Account). The `circonus_account` data source can be used for pulling various attributes
about a specific Circonus Account.

circonus-datasource-collector.body:
data "collector" "$1" {
    # id - (Optional) The Circonus ID of a given collector.
    id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The Circonus ID of the selected Collector.
    # "details" - A list of details about the individual Collector instances that make up the group of collectors.  See below for a list of attributes within each collector.
    # "latitude" - The latitude of the selected Collector.
    # "longitude" - The longitude of the selected Collector.
    # "name" - The name of the selected Collector.
    # "tags" - A list of tags assigned to the selected Collector.
    # "type" - The of the selected Collector.  This value is either "circonus" for a Circonus-managed, public Collector, or "enterprise" for a private collector that is private to an account.
}
circonus-datasource-collector.description:
`circonus_collector` provides
[details](https://login.circonus.com/resources/api/calls/broker) about a specific
[Circonus Collector](https://login.circonus.com/user/docs/Administration/Brokers). As well as validating a given Circonus ID, this resource can be used to discover
the additional details about a collector configured within the provider.  The
results of a `circonus_collector` API call can return more than one collector
per Circonus ID.  Details of each individual collector in the group of
collectors can be found via the `details` attribute described below. ~> **NOTE regarding `cirocnus_collector`:** The `circonus_collector` data source
actually queries and operates on Circonus "brokers" at the broker group level.
The `circonus_collector` is simply a renamed Circonus "broker" to make it clear
what the function of the "broker" actually does: act as a fan-in agent that
either pulls or has metrics pushed into it and funneled back through Circonus.

circonus-resource-circonus_check.body:
resource "circonus_check" "$1" {
    # target - (Required) A string containing the location of the thing being checked.  This value changes based on the check type.  For example, for an `http` check type this would be the URL you're checking. For a DNS check it would be the hostname you wanted to look up.
    target = ""

    # metric - (Required) A list of one or more `metric` configurations.  All metrics obtained from this check instance will be available as individual metric streams.  See below for a list of supported `metric` attrbutes.
    metric = ""

    # collector - (Required) A collector ID.  The collector(s) that are responsible for running a `circonus_check`. The `id` can be the Circonus ID for a Circonus collector (a.k.a. "broker") running in the cloud or an enterprise collector running in your datacenter.  One collection of metrics will be automatically created for each `collector` specified.
    collector = ""

    # active - (Optional) Whether or not the check is enabled or not (default `true`).
    active = ""

    # caql - (Optional) A [Circonus Analytics Query Language (CAQL)](https://login.circonus.com/user/docs/CAQL) check.  See below for details on how to configure a `caql` check.
    caql = ""

    # cloudwatch - (Optional) A [CloudWatch check](https://login.circonus.com/user/docs/Data/CheckTypes/CloudWatch) check. See below for details on how to configure a `cloudwatch` check.
    cloudwatch = ""

    # consul - (Optional) A native Consul check.  See below for details on how to configure a `consul` check.
    consul = ""

    # http - (Optional) A poll-based HTTP check.  See below for details on how to configure the `http` check.
    http = ""

    # httptrap - (Optional) An push-based HTTP check.  This check method expects clients to send a specially crafted HTTP JSON payload.  See below for details on how to configure the `httptrap` check.
    httptrap = ""

    # icmp_ping - (Optional) An ICMP ping check.  See below for details on how to configure the `icmp_ping` check.
    icmp_ping = ""

    # json - (Optional) A JSON check.  See below for details on how to configure the `json` check.
    json = ""

    # metric_limit - (Optional) Setting a metric limit will tell the Circonus backend to periodically look at the check to see if there are additional metrics the collector has seen that we should collect. It will not reactivate metrics previously collected and then marked as inactive. Values are `0` to disable, `-1` to enable all metrics or `N+` to collect up to the value `N` (both `-1` and `N+` can not exceed other account restrictions).
    metric_limit = ""

    # mysql - (Optional) A MySQL check.  See below for details on how to configure the `mysql` check.
    mysql = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the check that will be displayed in the web interface.
    name = ""

    # notes - (Optional) Notes about this check.
    notes = ""

    # period - (Optional) The period between each time the check is made in seconds.
    period = ""

    # postgresql - (Optional) A PostgreSQL check.  See below for details on how to configure the `postgresql` check.
    postgresql = ""

    # statsd - (Optional) A statsd check.  See below for details on how to configure the `statsd` check.
    statsd = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of tags assigned to this check.
    tags = ""

    # tcp - (Optional) A TCP check.  See below for details on how to configure the `tcp` check (includes TLS support).
    tcp = ""

    # timeout - (Optional) A floating point number representing the maximum number of seconds this check should wait for a result.  Defaults to `10.0`.
    timeout = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
circonus-resource-circonus_check.description:
The ``circonus_check`` resource creates and manages a
[Circonus Check](https://login.circonus.com/resources/api/calls/check_bundle). ~> **NOTE regarding `cirocnus_check` vs a Circonus Check Bundle:** The
`circonus_check` resource is implemented in terms of a
[Circonus Check Bundle](https://login.circonus.com/resources/api/calls/check_bundle).
The `circonus_check` creates a higher-level abstraction over the implementation
of a Check Bundle.  As such, the naming and structure does not map 1:1 with the
underlying Circonus API.

circonus-resource-circonus_contact_group.body:
resource "circonus_contact_group" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the contact group.
    name = ""

    # aggregation_window - (Optional) The aggregation window for batching up alert notifications.
    aggregation_window = ""

    # alert_option - (Optional) There is one `alert_option` per severity, where severity can be any number between 1 (high) and 5 (low).  If configured, the alerting system will remind or escalate alerts to further contact groups if an alert sent to this contact group is not acknowledged or resolved.  See below for details.
    alert_option = ""

    # email - (Optional) Zero or more `email` attributes may be present to dispatch email to Circonus users by referencing their user ID, or by specifying an email address.  See below for details on supported attributes.
    email = ""

    # http - (Optional) Zero or more `http` attributes may be present to dispatch [Webhook/HTTP requests](https://login.circonus.com/user/docs/Alerting/ContactGroups#WebhookNotifications) by Circonus.  See below for details on supported attributes.
    http = ""

    # irc - (Optional) Zero or more `irc` attributes may be present to dispatch IRC notifications to users.  See below for details on supported attributes.
    irc = ""

    # long_message - (Optional) The bulk of the message used in long form alert messages.
    long_message = ""

    # long_subject - (Optional) The subject used in long form alert messages.
    long_subject = ""

    # long_summary - (Optional) The brief summary used in long form alert messages.
    long_summary = ""

    # pager_duty - (Optional) Zero or more `pager_duty` attributes may be present to dispatch to [Pager Duty teams](https://login.circonus.com/user/docs/Alerting/ContactGroups#PagerDutyOptions). See below for details on supported attributes.
    pager_duty = ""

    # short_message - (Optional) The subject used in short form alert messages.
    short_message = ""

    # short_summary - (Optional) The brief summary used in short form alert messages.
    short_summary = ""

    # slack - (Optional) Zero or more `slack` attributes may be present to dispatch to Slack teams.  See below for details on supported attributes.
    slack = ""

    # sms - (Optional) Zero or more `sms` attributes may be present to dispatch SMS messages to Circonus users by referencing their user ID, or by specifying an SMS Phone Number.  See below for details on supported attributes.
    sms = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of tags attached to the Contact Group.
    tags = ""

    # victorops - (Optional) Zero or more `victorops` attributes may be present to dispatch to [VictorOps teams](https://login.circonus.com/user/docs/Alerting/ContactGroups#VictorOps). See below for details on supported attributes.
    victorops = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
circonus-resource-circonus_contact_group.description:
The ``circonus_contact_group`` resource creates and manages a
[Circonus Contact Group](https://login.circonus.com/user/docs/Alerting/ContactGroups).

circonus-resource-circonus_graph.body:
resource "circonus_graph" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The title of the graph.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) Description of what the graph is for.
    description = ""

    # graph_style - (Optional) How the graph should be rendered.  Valid options are `area` or `line` (default).
    graph_style = ""

    # left - (Optional) A map of graph left axis options.  Valid values in `left` include: `logarithmic` can be set to `0` (default) or `1`; `min` is the `min` Y axis value on the left; and `max` is the Y axis max value on the left.
    left = ""

    # line_style - (Optional) How the line should change between points.  Can be either `stepped` (default) or `interpolated`.
    line_style = ""

    # notes - (Optional) A place for storing notes about this graph.
    notes = ""

    # right - (Optional) A map of graph right axis options.  Valid values in `right` include: `logarithmic` can be set to `0` (default) or `1`; `min` is the `min` Y axis value on the right; and `max` is the Y axis max value on the right.
    right = ""

    # metric - (Optional) A list of metric streams to graph.  See below for options.
    metric = ""

    # metric_cluster - (Optional) A metric cluster to graph.  See below for options.
    metric_cluster = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of tags assigned to this graph.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
circonus-resource-circonus_graph.description:
The ``circonus_graph`` resource creates and manages a
[Circonus Graph](https://login.circonus.com/user/docs/Visualization/Graph/Create). https://login.circonus.com/resources/api/calls/graph).

circonus-resource-circonus_metric.body:
resource "circonus_metric" "$1" {
    # type - (Required) The type of metric.  This value must be present and can be one of the following values: `numeric`, `text`, `histogram`, `composite`, or `caql`.
    type = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the metric.  A `name` must be unique within a `circonus_check` and its meaning is `circonus_check.type` specific.
    name = ""

    # active - (Optional) A boolean indicating if the metric is being filtered out at the `circonus_check`'s collector(s) or not.
    active = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of tags assigned to the metric.
    tags = ""

    # unit - (Optional) The unit of measurement for this `circonus_metric`.
    unit = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
circonus-resource-circonus_metric.description:
The ``circonus_metric`` resource creates and manages a
single [metric resource](https://login.circonus.com/resources/api/calls/metric)
that will be instantiated only once a referencing `circonus_check` has been
created.

circonus-resource-circonus_metric_cluste.body:
resource "circonus_metric_cluster" "$1" {
    # query - (Required) One or more `query` attributes must be present.  Each `query` must contain both a `definition` and a `type`.  See below for details on supported attributes.
    query = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the metric cluster.  This name must be unique across all metric clusters in a given Circonus Account.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A long-form description of the metric cluster.
    description = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of tags attached to the metric cluster.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
circonus-resource-circonus_metric_cluste.description:
The ``circonus_metric_cluster`` resource creates and manages a
[Circonus Metric Cluster](https://login.circonus.com/user/docs/Data/View/MetricClusters).

circonus-resource-circonus_rule_set.body:
resource "circonus_rule_set" "$1" {
    # metric_name - (Required) The name of the metric stream within a given check that this rule set is active on.
    metric_name = ""

    # if - (Required) One or more ordered predicate clauses that describe when Circonus should generate a notification.  See below for details on the structure of an `if` configuration clause.
    if = ""

    # check - (Required) The Circonus ID that this Rule Set will use to search for a metric stream to alert on.
    check = ""

    # link - (Optional) A link to external documentation (or anything else you feel is important) when a notification is sent.  This value will show up in email alerts and the Circonus UI.
    link = ""

    # metric_type - (Optional) The type of metric this rule set will operate on. Valid values are `numeric` (the default) and `text`.
    metric_type = ""

    # notes - (Optional) Notes about this rule set.
    notes = ""

    # parent - (Optional) A Circonus Metric ID that, if specified and active with a severity 1 alert, will silence this rule set until all of the severity 1 alerts on the parent clear.  This value must match the format `${check_id}_${metric_name}`.
    parent = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of tags assigned to this rule set.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
circonus-resource-circonus_rule_set.description:
The ``circonus_rule_set`` resource creates and manages a
[Circonus Rule Set](https://login.circonus.com/resources/api/calls/rule_set).

cloudflare-resource-record.body:
resource "cloudflare_record" "$1" {
    # type - (Required) The type of the record
    type = ""

    # value - (Required) The value of the record
    value = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the record
    name = ""

    # domain - (Required) The domain to add the record to
    domain = ""

    # ttl - (Optional) The TTL of the record
    ttl = ""

    # priority - (Optional) The priority of the record
    priority = ""

    # proxied - (Optional) Whether the record gets Cloudflare's origin protection.
    proxied = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The record ID
    # "name" - The name of the record
    # "value" - The value of the record
    # "type" - The type of the record
    # "ttl" - The TTL of the record
    # "priority" - The priority of the record
    # "hostname" - The FQDN of the record
    # "proxied" - (Optional) Whether the record gets Cloudflare's origin protection.
}

cloudscale-resource-floating-ip.body:
resource "cloudscale_floating_ip" "$1" {
    # server - (Required) (Re-)Assign the Floating IP to this server (UUID).
    server = ""

    # ip_version - (Required) `4` or `6`, for an IPv4 or IPv6 address or network respectively.
    ip_version = ""

    # server - (Required) Assign the Floating IP to this server (UUID).
    server = ""

    # prefix_length - (Optional) If you want to assign an entire network instead of a single IP address to your server, you must specify the prefix length. Currently, there is only support for `ip_version=6` and `prefix_length=56`.
    prefix_length = ""

    # reverse_ptr - (Optional) You can specify the PTR record (reverse DNS pointer) in case of a single Floating IP address.
    reverse_ptr = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "href" - The cloudscale.ch API URL of the current resource.
    # "network" - The CIDR notation of the Floating IP address or network, e.g. "192.0.2.123/32".
    # "next_hop" - The IP address of the server that your Floating IP is currently assigned to.
}
cloudscale-resource-floating-ip.description: Provides a cloudscale.ch Floating IP to represent a publicly-accessible static IP address or IP network that can be assigned to one of your cloudscale.ch servers. Floating IPs can be moved between servers. Possible use cases include: High-availability, non-disruptive maintenance, multiple IPs per server, or re-using the same IP after replacing a server.

cloudscale-resource-server.body:
resource "cloudscale_server" "$1" {
    # ssh_keys - (Required) A list of SSH public keys. Use the full content of your \*.pub file here.
    ssh_keys = ""

    # image_slug - (Required) The slug (name) of the image to use for the new server. Possible values can be found in our [API documentation](https://www.cloudscale.ch/en/api/v1#images).
    image_slug = ""

    # flavor_slug - (Required) The slug (name) of the flavor to use for the new server. Possible values can be found in our [API documentation](https://www.cloudscale.ch/en/api/v1#flavors).
    flavor_slug = ""

    # name - (Required) Name of the new server. The name has to be a valid host name or a fully qualified domain name (FQDN).
    name = ""

    # volume_size_gb - (Optional) The size in GB of the SSD root volume of the new server. If this parameter is not specified, the value will be set to 10. Valid values are either 10 or multiples of 50.
    volume_size_gb = ""

    # bulk_volume_size_gb - (Optional) The size in GB of the bulk storage volume of the new server. If this parameter is not specified, no bulk storage volume will be attached to the server. Valid values are multiples of 100.
    bulk_volume_size_gb = ""

    # use_public_network - (Optional) Attach/detach the public network interface to/from the new server. Can be `true` (default) or `false`.
    use_public_network = ""

    # use_private_network - (Optional) Attach/detach the private network interface to/from the new server. Can be `true` or `false` (default).
    use_private_network = ""

    # anti_affinity_uuid - (Optional) Pass the UUID of another server to either create a new anti-affinity group with that server or add the new server to the same (existing) group as the other server.
    anti_affinity_uuid = ""

    # user_data - (Optional) User data (custom cloud-config settings) to use for the new server. Needs to be valid YAML. A default configuration will be used if this parameter is not specified or set to null. Use only if you are an advanced user with knowledge of cloud-config and cloud-init.
    user_data = ""

    # status - (Optional) The desired state of a server. Can be `running` (default) or `stopped`.
    status = ""

    # status - (Optional) The desired state of a server. Can be `running` (default) or `stopped`.
    status = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The UUID of this server.
    # "href" - The cloudscale.ch API URL of the current resource.
    # "ssh_fingerprints" - A list of SSH host key fingerprints (strings) of this server.
    # "ssh_host_keys" - A list of SSH host keys (strings) of this server.
    # "anti_affinity_with" - A list of server UUIDs that belong to the same anti-affinity group as this server.
    # "volumes" - A list of volume objects attached to this server. Each volume object has three attributes:
    # "device_path" - The path (string) to the volume on your server (e.g. "/dev/vda")
    # "size_gb" - The size (int) of the volume in GB. Typically matches "volume_size_gb" or "bulk_volume_size_gb".
    # "type" - A string. Either "ssd" or "bulk".
    # "interfaces" - A list of interface objects attached to this server. Each interface object has two attributes:
    # "type" - Either "public" or "private". Public interfaces are connected to the Internet, while private interfaces are not.
    # "addresses" - A list of address objects:
    # "address" - An IPv4 or IPv6 address that has been assigned to this server.
    # "gateway" - An IPv4 or IPv6 address that represents the default gateway for this interface.
    # "prefix_length" - The prefix length for this IP address, typically 24 for IPv4 and 128 for IPv6.
    # "reverse_ptr" - The PTR record (reverse DNS pointer) for this IP address. If you use an FQDN as your server name it will automatically be used here.
    # "version" - The IP version, either "4" or "6".
}
cloudscale-resource-server.description: Provides a cloudscale.ch Server resource. This can be used to create, modify, and delete servers.

cloudstack-resource-affinity-group.body:
resource "cloudstack_affinity_group" "$1" {
    # type - (Required) The affinity group type. Changing this   forces a new resource to be created.
    type = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the affinity group. Changing this   forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the affinity group.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to register this   affinity group to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The id of the affinity group.
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to register this   affinity group to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    # "description" - The description of the affinity group.
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to register this   affinity group to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
}

cloudstack-resource-disk.body:
resource "cloudstack_disk" "$1" {
    # zone - (Required) The name or ID of the zone where this disk volume will be available.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    zone = ""

    # disk_offering - (Required) The name or ID of the disk offering to use for   this disk volume.
    disk_offering = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the disk volume. Changing this forces a new   resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # attach - (Optional) Determines whether or not to attach the disk volume to a   virtual machine (defaults false).
    attach = ""

    # device_id - (Optional) The device ID to map the disk volume to within the guest OS.
    device_id = ""

    # size - (Optional) The size of the disk volume in gigabytes.
    size = ""

    # shrink_ok - (Optional) Verifies if the disk volume is allowed to shrink when   resizing (defaults false).
    shrink_ok = ""

    # virtual_machine_id - (Optional) The ID of the virtual machine to which you want   to attach the disk volume.
    virtual_machine_id = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the disk volume.
    # "zone" - (Required) The name or ID of the zone where this disk volume will be available.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    # "device_id" - The device ID the disk volume is mapped to within the guest OS.
    # "zone" - (Required) The name or ID of the zone where this disk volume will be available.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
}
cloudstack-resource-disk.description:
Creates a disk volume from a disk offering. This disk volume will be attached to
a virtual machine if the optional parameters are configured.

cloudstack-resource-egress-firewall.body:
resource "cloudstack_egress_firewall" "$1" {
    # protocol - (Required) The name of the protocol to allow. Valid options are:   `tcp`, `udp` and `icmp`.
    protocol = ""

    # cidr_list - (Required) A CIDR list to allow access to the given ports.
    cidr_list = ""

    # network_id - (Required) The network ID for which to create the egress   firewall rules. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    network_id = ""

    # managed - (Optional) USE WITH CAUTION! If enabled all the egress firewall   rules for this network will be managed by this resource. This means it will   delete all firewall rules that are not in your config! (defaults false)
    managed = ""

    # rule - (Optional) Can be specified multiple times. Each rule block supports   fields documented below. If `managed = false` at least one rule is required!
    rule = ""

    # parallelism - (Optional) Specifies how much rules will be created or deleted   concurrently. (defaults 2)
    parallelism = ""

    # icmp_type - (Optional) The ICMP type to allow. This can only be specified if   the protocol is ICMP.
    icmp_type = ""

    # icmp_code - (Optional) The ICMP code to allow. This can only be specified if   the protocol is ICMP.
    icmp_code = ""

    # ports - (Optional) List of ports and/or port ranges to allow. This can only   be specified if the protocol is TCP or UDP.
    ports = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The network ID for which the egress firewall rules are created.
    # "ports" - (Optional) List of ports and/or port ranges to allow. This can only   be specified if the protocol is TCP or UDP.
}
cloudstack-resource-egress-firewall.description: Creates egress firewall rules for a given network.

cloudstack-resource-firewall.body:
resource "cloudstack_firewall" "$1" {
    # protocol - (Required) The name of the protocol to allow. Valid options are:   `tcp`, `udp` and `icmp`.
    protocol = ""

    # cidr_list - (Required) A CIDR list to allow access to the given ports.
    cidr_list = ""

    # ip_address_id - (Required) The IP address ID for which to create the   firewall rules. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    ip_address_id = ""

    # managed - (Optional) USE WITH CAUTION! If enabled all the firewall rules for   this IP address will be managed by this resource. This means it will delete   all firewall rules that are not in your config! (defaults false)
    managed = ""

    # rule - (Optional) Can be specified multiple times. Each rule block supports   fields documented below. If `managed = false` at least one rule is required!
    rule = ""

    # parallelism - (Optional) Specifies how much rules will be created or deleted   concurrently. (defaults 2)
    parallelism = ""

    # icmp_type - (Optional) The ICMP type to allow. This can only be specified if   the protocol is ICMP.
    icmp_type = ""

    # icmp_code - (Optional) The ICMP code to allow. This can only be specified if   the protocol is ICMP.
    icmp_code = ""

    # ports - (Optional) List of ports and/or port ranges to allow. This can only   be specified if the protocol is TCP or UDP.
    ports = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The IP address ID for which the firewall rules are created.
    # "ports" - (Optional) List of ports and/or port ranges to allow. This can only   be specified if the protocol is TCP or UDP.
}
cloudstack-resource-firewall.description: Creates firewall rules for a given IP address.

cloudstack-resource-instance.body:
resource "cloudstack_instance" "$1" {
    # zone - (Required) The name or ID of the zone where this instance will be   created. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    zone = ""

    # template - (Required) The name or ID of the template used for this   instance. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    template = ""

    # service_offering - (Required) The name or ID of the service offering used   for this instance.
    service_offering = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the instance.
    name = ""

    # display_name - (Optional) The display name of the instance.
    display_name = ""

    # network_id - (Optional) The ID of the network to connect this instance   to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    network_id = ""

    # ip_address - (Optional) The IP address to assign to this instance. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    ip_address = ""

    # root_disk_size - (Optional) The size of the root disk in gigabytes. The   root disk is resized on deploy. Only applies to template-based deployments.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    root_disk_size = ""

    # group - (Optional) The group name of the instance.
    group = ""

    # affinity_group_ids - (Optional) List of affinity group IDs to apply to this   instance.
    affinity_group_ids = ""

    # affinity_group_names - (Optional) List of affinity group names to apply to   this instance.
    affinity_group_names = ""

    # security_group_ids - (Optional) List of security group IDs to apply to this   instance. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    security_group_ids = ""

    # security_group_names - (Optional) List of security group names to apply to   this instance. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    security_group_names = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # user_data - (Optional) The user data to provide when launching the   instance.
    user_data = ""

    # keypair - (Optional) The name of the SSH key pair that will be used to   access this instance.
    keypair = ""

    # expunge - (Optional) This determines if the instance is expunged when it is   destroyed (defaults false)
    expunge = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The instance ID.
    # "expunge" - (Optional) This determines if the instance is expunged when it is   destroyed (defaults false)
    # "display_name" - The display name of the instance.
    # "expunge" - (Optional) This determines if the instance is expunged when it is   destroyed (defaults false)
}
cloudstack-resource-instance.description:
Creates and automatically starts a virtual machine based on a service offering,
disk offering, and template.

cloudstack-resource-ipaddress.body:
resource "cloudstack_ipaddress" "$1" {
    # is_portable - (Optional) This determines if the IP address should be transferable   across zones (defaults false)
    is_portable = ""

    # network_id - (Optional) The ID of the network for which an IP address should   be acquired and associated. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    network_id = ""

    # vpc_id - (Optional) The ID of the VPC for which an IP address should be  acquired and associated. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    vpc_id = ""

    # zone - (Optional) The name or ID of the zone for which an IP address should be  acquired and associated. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    zone = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the acquired and associated IP address.
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    # "ip_address" - The IP address that was acquired and associated.
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
}
cloudstack-resource-ipaddress.description: Acquires and associates a public IP.

cloudstack-resource-loadbalancer-rule.body:
resource "cloudstack_loadbalancer_rule" "$1" {
    # member_ids - (Required) List of instance IDs to assign to the load balancer   rule. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    member_ids = ""

    # public_port - (Required) The public port from where the network traffic   will be load balanced from. Changing this forces a new resource to be   created.
    public_port = ""

    # private_port - (Required) The private port of the private IP address   (virtual machine) where the network traffic will be load balanced to.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    private_port = ""

    # algorithm - (Required) Load balancer rule algorithm (source, roundrobin,   leastconn). Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    algorithm = ""

    # ip_address_id - (Required) Public IP address ID from where the network   traffic will be load balanced from. Changing this forces a new resource   to be created.
    ip_address_id = ""

    # name - (Required) Name of the loadbalancer rule.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the load balancer rule.
    description = ""

    # network_id - (Optional) The network ID this rule will be created for.   Required when public IP address is not associated with any network yet   (VPC case).
    network_id = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The load balancer rule ID.
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    # "description" - The description of the load balancer rule.
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
}

cloudstack-resource-network.body:
resource "cloudstack_network" "$1" {
    # zone - (Required) The name or ID of the zone where this network will be   available. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    zone = ""

    # network_offering - (Required) The name or ID of the network offering to use   for this network.
    network_offering = ""

    # cidr - (Required) The CIDR block for the network. Changing this forces a new   resource to be created.
    cidr = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the network.
    name = ""

    # display_text - (Optional) The display text of the network.
    display_text = ""

    # gateway - (Optional) Gateway that will be provided to the instances in this   network. Defaults to the first usable IP in the range.
    gateway = ""

    # startip - (Optional) Start of the IP block that will be available on the   network. Defaults to the second available IP in the range.
    startip = ""

    # endip - (Optional) End of the IP block that will be available on the   network. Defaults to the last available IP in the range.
    endip = ""

    # network_domain - (Optional) DNS domain for the network.
    network_domain = ""

    # vlan - (Optional) The VLAN number (1-4095) the network will use. This might be   required by the Network Offering if specifyVlan=true is set. Only the ROOT   admin can set this value.
    vlan = ""

    # vpc_id - (Optional) The VPC ID in which to create this network. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    vpc_id = ""

    # acl_id - (Optional) The ACL ID that should be attached to the network or   `none` if you do not want to attach an ACL. You can dynamically attach and   swap ACL's, but if you want to detach an attached ACL and revert to using   `none`, this will force a new resource to be created. (defaults `none`)
    acl_id = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the network.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.
    # "display_text" - The display text of the network.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.
    # "network_domain" - DNS domain for the network.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.
}

cloudstack-resource-network-acl.body:
resource "cloudstack_network_acl" "$1" {
    # vpc_id - (Required) The ID of the VPC to create this ACL for. Changing this  forces a new resource to be created.
    vpc_id = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the ACL. Changing this forces a new resource   to be created.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the ACL. Changing this forces a   new resource to be created.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the Network ACL
    # "vpc_id" - (Required) The ID of the VPC to create this ACL for. Changing this  forces a new resource to be created.
}
cloudstack-resource-network-acl.description: Creates a Network ACL for the given VPC.

cloudstack-resource-network-acl-rule.body:
resource "cloudstack_network_acl_rule" "$1" {
    # protocol - (Required) The name of the protocol to allow. Valid options are:   `tcp`, `udp`, `icmp`, `all` or a valid protocol number.
    protocol = ""

    # cidr_list - (Required) A CIDR list to allow access to the given ports.
    cidr_list = ""

    # acl_id - (Required) The network ACL ID for which to create the rules.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    acl_id = ""

    # managed - (Optional) USE WITH CAUTION! If enabled all the firewall rules for   this network ACL will be managed by this resource. This means it will delete   all firewall rules that are not in your config! (defaults false)
    managed = ""

    # rule - (Optional) Can be specified multiple times. Each rule block supports   fields documented below. If `managed = false` at least one rule is required!
    rule = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # parallelism - (Optional) Specifies how much rules will be created or deleted   concurrently. (defaults 2)
    parallelism = ""

    # action - (Optional) The action for the rule. Valid options are: `allow` and   `deny` (defaults allow).
    action = ""

    # icmp_type - (Optional) The ICMP type to allow, or `-1` to allow `any`. This   can only be specified if the protocol is ICMP. (defaults 0)
    icmp_type = ""

    # icmp_code - (Optional) The ICMP code to allow, or `-1` to allow `any`. This   can only be specified if the protocol is ICMP. (defaults 0)
    icmp_code = ""

    # ports - (Optional) List of ports and/or port ranges to allow. This can only   be specified if the protocol is TCP, UDP, ALL or a valid protocol number.
    ports = ""

    # traffic_type - (Optional) The traffic type for the rule. Valid options are:   `ingress` or `egress` (defaults ingress).
    traffic_type = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ACL ID for which the rules are created.
    # "traffic_type" - (Optional) The traffic type for the rule. Valid options are:   "ingress" or "egress" (defaults ingress).
}
cloudstack-resource-network-acl-rule.description: Creates network ACL rules for a given network ACL.

cloudstack-resource-nic.body:
resource "cloudstack_nic" "$1" {
    # virtual_machine_id - (Required) The ID of the virtual machine to which to   attach the NIC. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    virtual_machine_id = ""

    # network_id - (Required) The ID of the network to plug the NIC into. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    network_id = ""

    # ip_address - (Optional) The IP address to assign to the NIC. Changing this   forces a new resource to be created.
    ip_address = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the NIC.
    # "virtual_machine_id" - (Required) The ID of the virtual machine to which to   attach the NIC. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    # "ip_address" - The assigned IP address.
    # "virtual_machine_id" - (Required) The ID of the virtual machine to which to   attach the NIC. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
}
cloudstack-resource-nic.description: Creates an additional NIC to add a VM to the specified network.

cloudstack-resource-port-forward.body:
resource "cloudstack_port_forward" "$1" {
    # virtual_machine_id - (Required) The ID of the virtual machine to forward to.
    virtual_machine_id = ""

    # public_port - (Required) The public port to forward from.
    public_port = ""

    # private_port - (Required) The private port to forward to.
    private_port = ""

    # protocol - (Required) The name of the protocol to allow. Valid options are:   `tcp` and `udp`.
    protocol = ""

    # forward - (Required) Can be specified multiple times. Each forward block supports   fields documented below.
    forward = ""

    # ip_address_id - (Required) The IP address ID for which to create the port   forwards. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    ip_address_id = ""

    # managed - (Optional) USE WITH CAUTION! If enabled all the port forwards for   this IP address will be managed by this resource. This means it will delete   all port forwards that are not in your config! (defaults false)
    managed = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to create this port forward   in. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # vm_guest_ip - (Optional) The virtual machine IP address for the port   forwarding rule (useful when the virtual machine has secondairy NICs   or IP addresses).
    vm_guest_ip = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the IP address for which the port forwards are created.
    # "vm_guest_ip" - (Optional) The virtual machine IP address for the port   forwarding rule (useful when the virtual machine has secondairy NICs   or IP addresses).
    # "vm_guest_ip" - The IP address of the virtual machine that is used
    # "vm_guest_ip" - (Optional) The virtual machine IP address for the port   forwarding rule (useful when the virtual machine has secondairy NICs   or IP addresses).
}

cloudstack-resource-private-gateway.body:
resource "cloudstack_private_gateway" "$1" {
    # vpc_id - (Required) The VPC ID in which to create this Private gateway. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    vpc_id = ""

    # acl_id - (Required) The ACL ID that should be attached to the network.
    acl_id = ""

    # vlan - (Required) The VLAN number (1-4095) the network will use.
    vlan = ""

    # netmask - (Required) The netmask of the Private gateway. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    netmask = ""

    # ip_address - (Required) the IP address of the Private gateway. Changing this forces   a new resource to be created.
    ip_address = ""

    # gateway - (Required) the gateway of the Private gateway. Changing this   forces a new resource to be created.
    gateway = ""

    # physical_network_id - (Optional) The ID of the physical network this private   gateway belongs to.
    physical_network_id = ""

    # network_offering - (Optional) The name or ID of the network offering to use for   the private gateways network connection.
    network_offering = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the private gateway.
    # "vpc_id" - (Required) The VPC ID in which to create this Private gateway. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
}
cloudstack-resource-private-gateway.description: Creates a private gateway for the given VPC. *NOTE: private gateway can only be created using a ROOT account!*

cloudstack-resource-secondary-ipaddress.body:
resource "cloudstack_secondary_ipaddress" "$1" {
    # virtual_machine_id - (Required) The ID of the virtual machine to which you   want to attach the secondary IP address. Changing this forces a new resource   to be created.
    virtual_machine_id = ""

    # ip_address - (Optional) The IP address to bind the to NIC. If not supplied   an IP address will be selected randomly. Changing this forces a new resource   to be	created.
    ip_address = ""

    # nic_id - (Optional) The NIC ID to which you want to attach the secondary IP   address. Changing this forces a new resource to be created (defaults to the   ID of the primary NIC)
    nic_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The secondary IP address ID.
    # "virtual_machine_id" - (Required) The ID of the virtual machine to which you   want to attach the secondary IP address. Changing this forces a new resource   to be created.
}
cloudstack-resource-secondary-ipaddress.description: Assigns a secondary IP to a NIC.

cloudstack-resource-security-group.body:
resource "cloudstack_security_group" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the security group. Changing this forces a   new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the security group. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to create this security   group in. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the security group.
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to create this security   group in. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
}

cloudstack-resource-security-group-rule.body:
resource "cloudstack_security_group_rule" "$1" {
    # protocol - (Required) The name of the protocol to allow. Valid options are:   `tcp`, `udp`, `icmp`, `all` or a valid protocol number.
    protocol = ""

    # rule - (Required) Can be specified multiple times. Each rule block supports   fields documented below.
    rule = ""

    # security_group_id - (Required) The security group ID for which to create   the rules. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    security_group_id = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project in which the security   group is created. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # parallelism - (Optional) Specifies how much rules will be created or deleted   concurrently. (defaults 2)
    parallelism = ""

    # cidr_list - (Optional) A CIDR list to allow access to the given ports.
    cidr_list = ""

    # icmp_type - (Optional) The ICMP type to allow, or `-1` to allow `any`. This   can only be specified if the protocol is ICMP. (defaults 0)
    icmp_type = ""

    # icmp_code - (Optional) The ICMP code to allow, or `-1` to allow `any`. This   can only be specified if the protocol is ICMP. (defaults 0)
    icmp_code = ""

    # ports - (Optional) List of ports and/or port ranges to allow. This can only   be specified if the protocol is TCP, UDP, ALL or a valid protocol number.
    ports = ""

    # traffic_type - (Optional) The traffic type for the rule. Valid options are:   `ingress` or `egress`. (defaults ingress)
    traffic_type = ""

    # user_security_group_list - (Optional) A list of security groups to apply   the rules to.
    user_security_group_list = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The security group ID for which the rules are created.
    # "user_security_group_list" - (Optional) A list of security groups to apply   the rules to.
}
cloudstack-resource-security-group-rule.description: Authorizes and revokes both ingress and egress rulea for a given security group.

cloudstack-resource-ssh-keypair.body:
resource "cloudstack_ssh_keypair" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the SSH key pair. This is a unique value   within a CloudStack account. Changing this forces a new resource to be   created.
    name = ""

    # public_key - (Optional) The public key to register with CloudStack. If   this is omitted, CloudStack will generate a new key pair. The key can   be loaded from a file on disk using the [`file()` interpolation   function](/docs/configuration/interpolation.html#file_path_). Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    public_key = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to register this   key to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The key pair ID.
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to register this   key to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    # "fingerprint" - The fingerprint of the public key specified or created.
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to register this   key to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    # "private_key" - The private key generated by CloudStack. Only available
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to register this   key to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
}
cloudstack-resource-ssh-keypair.description: Creates or registers an SSH key pair.

cloudstack-resource-static-nat.body:
resource "cloudstack_static_nat" "$1" {
    # virtual_machine_id - (Required) The virtual machine ID to enable the   static NAT feature for. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    virtual_machine_id = ""

    # ip_address_id - (Required) The public IP address ID for which static   NAT will be enabled. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    ip_address_id = ""

    # vm_guest_ip - (Optional) The virtual machine IP address to forward the   static NAT traffic to (useful when the virtual machine has secondary   NICs or IP addresses). Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    vm_guest_ip = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The static nat ID.
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    # "vm_guest_ip" - The IP address of the virtual machine that is used
    # "project" - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
}
cloudstack-resource-static-nat.description: Enables static NAT for a given IP address

cloudstack-resource-static-route.body:
resource "cloudstack_static_route" "$1" {
    # gateway_id - (Required) The ID of the Private gateway. Changing this forces   a new resource to be created.
    gateway_id = ""

    # cidr - (Required) The CIDR for the static route. Changing this forces   a new resource to be created.
    cidr = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the static route.
    # "gateway_id" - (Required) The ID of the Private gateway. Changing this forces   a new resource to be created.
}
cloudstack-resource-static-route.description: Creates a static route for the given private gateway or VPC.

cloudstack-resource-template.body:
resource "cloudstack_template" "$1" {
    # zone - (Required) The name or ID of the zone where this template will be created.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    zone = ""

    # url - (Required) The URL of where the template is hosted. Changing this   forces a new resource to be created.
    url = ""

    # os_type - (Required) The OS Type that best represents the OS of this   template.
    os_type = ""

    # hypervisor - (Required) The target hypervisor for the template. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    hypervisor = ""

    # format - (Required) The format of the template. Valid values are `QCOW2`,   `RAW`, and `VHD`.
    format = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the template.
    name = ""

    # display_text - (Optional) The display name of the template.
    display_text = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to create this template for.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # is_dynamically_scalable - (Optional) Set to indicate if the template contains   tools to support dynamic scaling of VM cpu/memory (defaults false)
    is_dynamically_scalable = ""

    # is_extractable - (Optional) Set to indicate if the template is extractable   (defaults false)
    is_extractable = ""

    # is_featured - (Optional) Set to indicate if the template is featured   (defaults false)
    is_featured = ""

    # is_public - (Optional) Set to indicate if the template is available for   all accounts (defaults true)
    is_public = ""

    # password_enabled - (Optional) Set to indicate if the template should be   password enabled (defaults false)
    password_enabled = ""

    # is_ready_timeout - (Optional) The maximum time in seconds to wait until the   template is ready for use (defaults 300 seconds)
    is_ready_timeout = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The template ID.
    # "is_ready_timeout" - (Optional) The maximum time in seconds to wait until the   template is ready for use (defaults 300 seconds)
    # "display_text" - The display text of the template.
    # "is_ready_timeout" - (Optional) The maximum time in seconds to wait until the   template is ready for use (defaults 300 seconds)
    # "is_dynamically_scalable" - Set to "true" if the template is dynamically scalable.
    # "is_ready_timeout" - (Optional) The maximum time in seconds to wait until the   template is ready for use (defaults 300 seconds)
    # "is_extractable" - Set to "true" if the template is extractable.
    # "is_ready_timeout" - (Optional) The maximum time in seconds to wait until the   template is ready for use (defaults 300 seconds)
    # "is_featured" - Set to "true" if the template is featured.
    # "is_ready_timeout" - (Optional) The maximum time in seconds to wait until the   template is ready for use (defaults 300 seconds)
    # "is_public" - Set to "true" if the template is public.
    # "is_ready_timeout" - (Optional) The maximum time in seconds to wait until the   template is ready for use (defaults 300 seconds)
    # "password_enabled" - Set to "true" if the template is password enabled.
    # "is_ready_timeout" - (Optional) The maximum time in seconds to wait until the   template is ready for use (defaults 300 seconds)
    # "is_ready" - Set to "true" once the template is ready for use.
    # "is_ready_timeout" - (Optional) The maximum time in seconds to wait until the   template is ready for use (defaults 300 seconds)
}
cloudstack-resource-template.description: Registers an existing template into the CloudStack cloud.

cloudstack-resource-vpc.body:
resource "cloudstack_vpc" "$1" {
    # zone - (Required) The name or ID of the zone where this disk volume will be   available. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    zone = ""

    # vpc_offering - (Required) The name or ID of the VPC offering to use for this VPC.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    vpc_offering = ""

    # cidr - (Required) The CIDR block for the VPC. Changing this forces a new   resource to be created.
    cidr = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the VPC.
    name = ""

    # display_text - (Optional) The display text of the VPC.
    display_text = ""

    # network_domain - (Optional) The default DNS domain for networks created in   this VPC. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    network_domain = ""

    # project - (Optional) The name or ID of the project to deploy this   instance to. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the VPC.
    # "zone" - (Required) The name or ID of the zone where this disk volume will be   available. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    # "display_text" - The display text of the VPC.
    # "zone" - (Required) The name or ID of the zone where this disk volume will be   available. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    # "source_nat_ip" - The source NAT IP assigned to the VPC.
    # "zone" - (Required) The name or ID of the zone where this disk volume will be   available. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
}

cloudstack-resource-vpn-connection.body:
resource "cloudstack_vpn_connection" "$1" {
    # vpn_gateway_id - (Required) The VPN Gateway ID to connect. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    vpn_gateway_id = ""

    # customer_gateway_id - (Required) The Customer Gateway ID to connect.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    customer_gateway_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the VPN Connection.
    # "vpn_gateway_id" - (Required) The VPN Gateway ID to connect. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
}
cloudstack-resource-vpn-connection.description: Creates a site to site VPN connection.

cloudstack-resource-vpn-customer-gateway.body:
resource "cloudstack_vpn_customer_gateway" "$1" {
    # ipsec_psk - (Required) The IPSEC pre-shared key used for this gateway.
    ipsec_psk = ""

    # ike_policy - (Required) The IKE policy to use for this VPN Customer Gateway.
    ike_policy = ""

    # gateway - (Required) The public IP address of the related VPN Gateway.
    gateway = ""

    # esp_policy - (Required) The ESP policy to use for this VPN Customer Gateway.
    esp_policy = ""

    # cidr - (Required) The CIDR block that needs to be routed through this gateway.
    cidr = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the VPN Customer Gateway.
    name = ""

    # dpd - (Optional) If DPD is enabled for the related VPN connection (defaults false)
    dpd = ""

    # esp_lifetime - (Optional) The ESP lifetime of phase 2 VPN connection to this   VPN Customer Gateway in seconds (defaults 86400)
    esp_lifetime = ""

    # ike_lifetime - (Optional) The IKE lifetime of phase 2 VPN connection to this   VPN Customer Gateway in seconds (defaults 86400)
    ike_lifetime = ""

}

cobbler-resource-distro.body:
resource "cobbler_distro" "$1" {
    # os_version - (Required) The version of the distro you are creating. This varies with the version of Cobbler you are using. An updated signature list may need to be obtained in order to support a newer version. Example: `trusty`.
    os_version = ""

    # name - (Required) A name for the distro.
    name = ""

    # initrd - (Required) Absolute path to initrd on filesystem. This must already exist prior to creating the distro.
    initrd = ""

    # kernel - (Required) Absolute path to kernel on filesystem. This must already exist prior to creating the distro.
    kernel = ""

    # breed - (Required) The "breed" of distribution. Valid options are: redhat, fedora, centos, scientific linux, suse, debian, and ubuntu. These choices may vary depending on the version of Cobbler in use.
    breed = ""

    # arch - (Required) The architecture of the distro. Valid options are: i386, x86_64, ia64, ppc, ppc64, s390, arm.
    arch = ""

    # boot_files - (Optional) Files copied into tftpboot beyond the kernel/initrd.
    boot_files = ""

    # comment - (Optional) Free form text description.
    comment = ""

    # fetchable_files - (Optional) Templates for tftp or wget.
    fetchable_files = ""

    # kernel_options - (Optional) Kernel options to use with the kernel.
    kernel_options = ""

    # kernel_options_post - (Optional) Post install Kernel options to use with the kernel after installation.
    kernel_options_post = ""

    # mgmt_classes - (Optional) Management classes for external config management.
    mgmt_classes = ""

    # owners - (Optional) Owners list for authz_ownership.
    owners = ""

    # redhat_management_key - (Optional) Red Hat Management key.
    redhat_management_key = ""

    # redhat_management_server - (Optional) Red Hat Management server.
    redhat_management_server = ""

    # template_files - (Optional) File mappings for built-in config management.
    template_files = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}

cobbler-resource-system.body:

    status = ""

    # template_files - (Optional) File mappings for built-in configuration management.
    template_files = ""

    # template_remote_kickstarts - (Optional) template remote kickstarts.
    template_remote_kickstarts = ""

    # virt_auto_boot - (Optional) Auto boot the VM.
    virt_auto_boot = ""

    # virt_cpus - (Optional) Number of virtual CPUs in the VM.
    virt_cpus = ""

    # virt_disk_driver - (Optional) The on-disk format for the virtualization disk.
    virt_disk_driver = ""

    # virt_file_size - (Optional) Virt file size.
    virt_file_size = ""

    # virt_path - (Optional) Path to the VM.
    virt_path = ""

    # virt_pxe_boot - (Optional) Use PXE to build this VM?
    virt_pxe_boot = ""

    # virt_ram - (Optional) The amount of RAM for the VM.
    virt_ram = ""

    # virt_type - (Optional) Virtualization technology to use: xenpv, xenfv, qemu, kvm, vmware, openvz.

    # cnames - (Optional) Canonical name records.

    # dhcp_tag - (Optional) DHCP tag.

    # dns_name - (Optional) DNS name.
    dns_name = ""

    # bonding_opts - (Optional) Options for bonded interfaces.
    bonding_opts = ""

    # bridge_opts - (Optional) Options for bridge interfaces.
    bridge_opts = ""

    # gateway - (Optional) Per-interface gateway.
    gateway = ""

    # interface_type - (Optional) The type of interface: na, master, slave, bond, bond_slave, bridge, bridge_slave, bonded_bridge_slave.
    interface_type = ""

    # interface_master - (Optional) The master interface when slave.
    interface_master = ""

    # ip_address - (Optional) The IP address of the interface.
    ip_address = ""

    # mac_address - (Optional) The MAC address of the interface.
    mac_address = ""

    # management - (Optional) Whether this interface is a management interface.
    management = ""

    # netmask - (Optional) The IPv4 netmask of the interface.
    netmask = ""

    # static - (Optional) Whether the interface should be static or DHCP.
    static = ""

    # static_routes - (Optional) Static routes for the interface.
    static_routes = ""

    # virt_bridge - (Optional) The virtual bridge to attach to.
    virt_bridge = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}

consul-data-source-catalog-nodes.description:
The `consul_catalog_nodes` data source returns a list of Consul nodes that have
been registered with the Consul cluster in a given datacenter.  By specifying a
different datacenter in the `query_options` it is possible to retrieve a list of
nodes from a different WAN-attached Consul datacenter.

consul-data-source-catalog-service.description:
`consul_catalog_service` provides details about a specific Consul service in a
given datacenter.  The results include a list of nodes advertising the specified
service, the node's IP address, port number, node ID, etc.  By specifying a
different datacenter in the `query_options` it is possible to retrieve a list of
services from a different WAN-attached Consul datacenter. This data source is different from the `consul_catalog_services` (plural) data
source, which provides a summary of the current Consul services.

consul-data-source-catalog-services.body:
data "consul_catalog_services" "$1" {
    # datacenter - (Optional) The Consul datacenter to query.  Defaults to the same value found in `query_options` parameter specified below, or if that is empty, the `datacenter` value found in the Consul agent that this provider is configured to talk to.
    datacenter = ""

    # query_options - (Optional) See below.
    query_options = ""

    # allow_stale - (Optional) When `true`, the default, allow responses from Consul servers that are followers.
    allow_stale = ""

    # require_consistent - (Optional) When `true` force the client to perform a read on at least quorum servers and verify the result is the same.  Defaults to `false`.
    require_consistent = ""

    # token - (Optional) Specify the Consul ACL token to use when performing the request.  This defaults to the same API token configured by the `consul` provider but may be overriden if necessary.
    token = ""

    # wait_index - (Optional) Index number used to enable blocking quereis.
    wait_index = ""

    # wait_time - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    wait_time = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the keys are being read from to.
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "names" - A list of the Consul services found.  This will always contain the
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "services.<service>" - For each name given, the corresponding attribute is a
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
    # "tags" - A map of the tags found for each service.  If more than one service
    # "wait_time" - (Optional) Max time the client should wait for a blocking query to return.
}
consul-data-source-catalog-services.description:
The `consul_catalog_services` data source returns a list of Consul services that
have been registered with the Consul cluster in a given datacenter.  By
specifying a different datacenter in the `query_options` it is possible to
retrieve a list of services from a different WAN-attached Consul datacenter. This data source is different from the `consul_catalog_service` (singular) data
source, which provides a detailed response about a specific Consul service.

consul-data-source-keys.body:
data "consul_keys" "$1" {
    # path - (Required) This is the path in Consul that should be read or written to.
    path = ""

    # name - (Required) This is the name of the key. This value of the key is exposed as `var.<name>`. This is not the path of the key in Consul.
    name = ""

    # key - (Required) Specifies a key in Consul to be read or written. Supported values documented below.
    key = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # token - (Optional) The ACL token to use. This overrides the token that the agent provides by default.
    token = ""

    # default - (Optional) This is the default value to set for `var.<name>` if the key does not exist in Consul. Defaults to an empty string.
    default = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the keys are being read from to.
    # "default" - (Optional) This is the default value to set for "var.<name>" if the key does not exist in Consul. Defaults to an empty string.
    # "var.<name>" - For each name given, the corresponding attribute
    # "default" - (Optional) This is the default value to set for "var.<name>" if the key does not exist in Consul. Defaults to an empty string.
}
consul-data-source-keys.description:
The `consul_keys` resource reads values from the Consul key/value store.
This is a powerful way dynamically set values in templates.

consul-resource-agent-service.body:
resource "consul_agent_service" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the service.
    name = ""

    # address - (Optional) The address of the service. Defaults to the address of the agent.
    address = ""

    # port - (Optional) The port of the service.
    port = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "address" - The address of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "id" - The ID of the service, defaults to the value of "name".
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "name" - The name of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "port" - The port of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "tags" - The tags of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
}
consul-resource-agent-service.description:
Provides access to the agent service data in Consul. This can be used to
define a service associated with a particular agent. Currently, defining
health checks for an agent service is not supported.

consul-resource-catalog-entry.body:
resource "consul_catalog_entry" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the service
    name = ""

    # node - (Required) The name of the node being added to, or referenced in the catalog.
    node = ""

    # address - (Required) The address of the node being added to, or referenced in the catalog.
    address = ""

    # service - (Optional) A service to optionally associated with the node. Supported values are documented below.
    service = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # address - (Optional) The address of the service. Defaults to the
    address = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # id - (Optional) The ID of the service. Defaults to the `name`.
    id = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # port - (Optional) The port of the service.
    port = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of values that are opaque to Consul,
    tags = ""

    # token - (Optional) ACL token.
    token = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "address" - The address of the service.
    # "token" - (Optional) ACL token.
    # "node" - The ID of the service, defaults to the value of "name".
    # "token" - (Optional) ACL token.
}
consul-resource-catalog-entry.description:
Registers a node or service with the [Consul Catalog](https://www.consul.io/docs/agent/http/catalog.html#catalog_register).
Currently, defining health checks is not supported.

consul-resource-key-prefix.body:
resource "consul_key_prefix" "$1" {
    # subkeys - (Required) A mapping from subkey name (which will be appended to the given `path_prefix`) to the value that should be stored at that key. Use slashes, as shown in the above example, to create "sub-folders" under the given path prefix.
    subkeys = ""

    # path_prefix - (Required) Specifies the common prefix shared by all keys that will be managed by this resource instance. In most cases this will end with a slash, to manage a "folder" of keys.
    path_prefix = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # token - (Optional) The ACL token to use. This overrides the token that the agent provides by default.
    token = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the keys are being read/written to.
    # "subkeys" - (Required) A mapping from subkey name (which will be appended to the given "path_prefix") to the value that should be stored at that key. Use slashes, as shown in the above example, to create "sub-folders" under the given path prefix.
}
consul-resource-key-prefix.description:
Allows Terraform to manage a "namespace" of Consul keys that share a common
name prefix. Like `consul_keys`, this resource can write values into the Consul key/value
store, but *unlike* `consul_keys` this resource can detect and remove extra
keys that have been added some other way, thus ensuring that rogue data
added outside of Terraform will be removed on the next run. This resource is thus useful in the case where Terraform is exclusively
managing a set of related keys. To avoid accidentally clobbering matching data that existed in Consul before
a `consul_key_prefix` resource was created, creation of a key prefix instance
will fail if any matching keys are already present in the key/value store.
If any conflicting data is present, you must first delete it manually. ~> **Warning** After this resource is instantiated, Terraform takes control
over *all* keys with the given path prefix, and will remove any matching keys
that are not present in the configuration. It will also delete *all* keys under
the given prefix when a `consul_key_prefix` resource is destroyed, even if
those keys were created outside of Terraform.

consul-resource-keys.body:
resource "consul_keys" "$1" {
    # value - (Required) The value to write to the given path.
    value = ""

    # path - (Required) This is the path in Consul that should be written to.
    path = ""

    # key - (Required) Specifies a key in Consul to be written. Supported values documented below.
    key = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # token - (Optional) The ACL token to use. This overrides the token that the agent provides by default.
    token = ""

    # delete - (Optional) If true, then the key will be deleted when either its configuration block is removed from the configuration or the entire resource is destroyed. Otherwise, it will be left in Consul. Defaults to false.
    delete = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "datacenter" - The datacenter the keys are being written to.
    # "delete" - (Optional) If true, then the key will be deleted when either its configuration block is removed from the configuration or the entire resource is destroyed. Otherwise, it will be left in Consul. Defaults to false.
}
consul-resource-keys.description:
The `consul_keys` resource writes sets of individual values into Consul.
This is a powerful way to expose infrastructure details to clients. This resource manages individual keys, and thus it can create, update
and delete the keys explicitly given. However, it is not able to detect
and remove additional keys that have been added by non-Terraform means.
To manage *all* keys sharing a common prefix, and thus have Terraform
remove errant keys not present in the configuration, consider using the
`consul_key_prefix` resource instead.

    # Exported Attributes
