    # "name" - (Required) The name of the node being added to, or referenced in the catalog.
    # "name" - The name of the service.
    # "name" - (Required) The name of the node being added to, or referenced in the catalog.
}
consul-resource-node.description:
Provides access to Node data in Consul. This can be used to define a
node. Currently, defining health checks is not supported.

consul-resource-prepared-query.body:
resource "consul_prepared_query" "$1" {
    # regexp - (Required) The regular expression to match with. When using `name_prefix_match`, this regex is applied against the query name.
    regexp = ""

    # regexp - (Required) The regular expression to match with. When using `name_prefix_match`, this regex is applied against the query name.
    regexp = ""

    # type - (Required) The type of template matching to perform. Currently only `name_prefix_match` is supported.
    type = ""

    # service - (Required) The name of the service to query.
    service = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the prepared query. Used to identify the prepared query during requests. Can be specified as an empty string to configure the query as a catch-all.
    name = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The datacenter to use. This overrides the datacenter in the provider setup and the agent's default datacenter.
    datacenter = ""

    # token - (Optional) The ACL token to use when saving the prepared query. This overrides the token that the agent provides by default.
    token = ""

    # stored_token - (Optional) The ACL token to store with the prepared query. This token will be used by default whenever the query is executed.
    stored_token = ""

    # session - (Optional) The name of the Consul session to tie this query's lifetime to.  This is an advanced parameter that should not be used without a complete understanding of Consul sessions and the implications of their use (it is recommended to leave this blank in nearly all cases).  If this parameter is omitted the query will not expire.
    session = ""

    # tags - (Optional) The list of required and/or disallowed tags.  If a tag is in this list it must be present.  If the tag is preceded with a "!" then it is disallowed.
    tags = ""

    # only_passing - (Optional) When `true`, the prepared query will only return nodes with passing health checks in the result.
    only_passing = ""

    # near - (Optional) Allows specifying the name of a node to sort results near using Consul's distance sorting and network coordinates. The magic `_agent` value can be used to always sort nearest the node servicing the request.
    near = ""

    # nearest_n - (Optional) Return results from this many datacenters, sorted in ascending order of estimated RTT.
    nearest_n = ""

    # datacenters - (Optional) Remote datacenters to return results from.
    datacenters = ""

    # datacenters - (Optional) Remote datacenters to return results from.
    datacenters = ""

    # dns - (Optional) Settings for controlling the DNS response details. `ttl` - (Optional) The TTL to send when returning DNS results.
    dns = ""

    # dns - (Optional) Settings for controlling the DNS response details. `ttl` - (Optional) The TTL to send when returning DNS results.
    dns = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the prepared query, generated by Consul.
    # "regexp" - (Required) The regular expression to match with. When using "name_prefix_match", this regex is applied against the query name.
}
consul-resource-prepared-query.description:
Allows Terraform to manage a Consul prepared query. Managing prepared queries is done using Consul's REST API. This resource is
useful to provide a consistent and declarative way of managing prepared
queries in your Consul cluster using Terraform.

consul-resource-service.body:
resource "consul_service" "$1" {
    # service_id - (Optional) (Optional, string) The ID of the service, defaults to the value of `name` if not supplied.
    service_id = ""

    # address - (Optional) (Optional, string) The address of the service. Defaults to the address of the agent.
    address = ""

    # name - (Optional) (Required, string) The name of the service.
    name = ""

    # port - (Optional) (Optional, int) The port of the service.
    port = ""

    # tags - (Optional) (Optional, set of strings) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "service_id" - The id of the service, defaults to the value of "name".
    # "tags" - (Optional, set of strings) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "address" - The address of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional, set of strings) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "name" - The name of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional, set of strings) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "port" - The port of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional, set of strings) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
    # "tags" - The tags of the service.
    # "tags" - (Optional, set of strings) A list of values that are opaque to Consul, but can be used to distinguish between services or nodes.
}
consul-resource-service.description:
A high-level resource for creating a Service in Consul. Currently,
defining health checks for a service is not supported. **Most users should not use this resource**. When using Consul with
compute instances, it's better to install
[the Consul Agent](https://www.consul.io/docs/agent/basics.html)
on these machines and register services via the agent. This ensures
that services get assigned to the appropriate Consul "nodes" and
allows service health to integrate with general node health as
reported by the agent. To register a non-compute resource, such as a hosted database,
as a service, as described in
[Consul's _External Services_ guide](https://www.consul.io/docs/guides/external.html),
use [`consul_catalog_entry`](catalog_entry.html) instead, which
can create an arbitrary service record in the Consul catalog.

do-resource-loadbalancer.body:
resource "digitalocean_loadbalancer" "$1" {
    # protocol - (Required) The protocol used for health checks sent to the backend Droplets. The possible values are `http` or `tcp`.
    protocol = ""

    # type - (Required) An attribute indicating how and if requests from a client will be persistently served by the same backend Droplet. The possible values are `cookies` or `none`. If not specified, the default value is `none`.
    type = ""

    # target_port - (Required) An integer representing the port on the backend Droplets to which the Load Balancer will send traffic.
    target_port = ""

    # target_protocol - (Required) The protocol used for traffic from the Load Balancer to the backend Droplets. The possible values are: `http`, `https`, or `tcp`.
    target_protocol = ""

    # entry_port - (Required) An integer representing the port on which the Load Balancer instance will listen.
    entry_port = ""

    # entry_protocol - (Required) The protocol used for traffic to the Load Balancer. The possible values are: `http`, `https`, or `tcp`.
    entry_protocol = ""

    # forwarding_rule - (Required) A list of `forwarding_rule` to be assigned to the
    forwarding_rule = ""

    # region - (Required) The region to start in
    region = ""

    # name - (Required) The Load Balancer name
    name = ""

    # algorithm - (Optional) The load balancing algorithm used to determine
    algorithm = ""

    # healthcheck - (Optional) A `healthcheck` block to be assigned to the
    healthcheck = ""

    # sticky_sessions - (Optional) A `sticky_sessions` block to be assigned to the
    sticky_sessions = ""

    # redirect_http_to_https - (Optional) A boolean value indicating whether
    redirect_http_to_https = ""

    # droplet_ids - (Optional) - A list of the IDs of each droplet to be attached to the Load Balancer.
    droplet_ids = ""

    # droplet_tag - (Optional) - The name of a Droplet tag corresponding to Droplets to be assigned to the Load Balancer.
    droplet_tag = ""

    # forwarding_rule - (Optional) `forwarding_rule` supports the following:
    forwarding_rule = ""

    # certificate_id - (Optional) The ID of the TLS certificate to be used for SSL termination.
    certificate_id = ""

    # tls_passthrough - (Optional) A boolean value indicating whether SSL encrypted traffic will be passed through to the backend Droplets. The default value is `false`.
    tls_passthrough = ""

    # sticky_sessions - (Optional) `sticky_sessions` supports the following:
    sticky_sessions = ""

    # cookie_name - (Optional) The name to be used for the cookie sent to the client. This attribute is required when using `cookies` for the sticky sessions type.
    cookie_name = ""

    # cookie_ttl_seconds - (Optional) The number of seconds until the cookie set by the Load Balancer expires. This attribute is required when using `cookies` for the sticky sessions type.
    cookie_ttl_seconds = ""

    # healthcheck - (Optional) `healthcheck` supports the following:
    healthcheck = ""

    # port - (Optional) An integer representing the port on the backend Droplets on which the health check will attempt a connection.
    port = ""

    # path - (Optional) The path on the backend Droplets to which the Load Balancer instance will send a request.
    path = ""

    # check_interval_seconds - (Optional) The number of seconds between between two consecutive health checks. If not specified, the default value is `10`.
    check_interval_seconds = ""

    # response_timeout_seconds - (Optional) The number of seconds the Load Balancer instance will wait for a response until marking a health check as failed. If not specified, the default value is `5`.
    response_timeout_seconds = ""

    # unhealthy_threshold - (Optional) The number of times a health check must fail for a backend Droplet to be marked "unhealthy" and be removed from the pool. If not specified, the default value is `3`.
    unhealthy_threshold = ""

    # healthy_threshold - (Optional) The number of times a health check must pass for a backend Droplet to be marked "healthy" and be re-added to the pool. If not specified, the default value is `5`.
    healthy_threshold = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the Load Balancer
    # "ip"- The ip of the Load Balancer
}
do-resource-loadbalancer.description:
Provides a DigitalOcean Load Balancer resource. This can be used to create,
modify, and delete Load Balancers.

do-resource-record.body:
resource "digitalocean_record" "$1" {
    # domain - (Required) The domain to add the record to
    domain = ""

    # type - (Required) The type of record
    type = ""

    # value - (Optional) The value of the record
    value = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the record
    name = ""

    # weight - (Optional) The weight of the record, for SRV records.
    weight = ""

    # port - (Optional) The port of the record, for SRV records.
    port = ""

    # priority - (Optional) The priority of the record, for MX and SRV
    priority = ""

    # ttl - (Optional) The time to live for the record, in seconds.
    ttl = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The record ID
    # "fqdn" - The FQDN of the record
}
do-resource-record.description: Provides a DigitalOcean DNS record resource.

do-resource-ssh-key.body:
resource "digitalocean_ssh_key" "$1" {
    # public_key - (Required) The public key. If this is a file, it
    public_key = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the SSH key for identification
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The unique ID of the key
    # "name" - The name of the SSH key
    # "public_key" - The text of the public key
    # "fingerprint" - The fingerprint of the SSH key
}
do-resource-ssh-key.description:
Provides a DigitalOcean SSH key resource to allow you manage SSH
keys for Droplet access. Keys created with this resource
can be referenced in your droplet configuration via their ID or
fingerprint.

do-resource-tag.body:
resource "digitalocean_tag" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the tag
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The id of the tag
    # "name" - The name of the tag
}
do-resource-tag.description:
Provides a DigitalOcean Tag resource. A Tag is a label that can be applied to a
droplet resource in order to better organize or facilitate the lookups and
actions on it. Tags created with this resource can be referenced in your droplet
configuration via their ID or name.

do-resource-volume.body:
resource "digitalocean_volume" "$1" {
    # size - (Required) The size of the block storage volume in GiB.
    size = ""

    # name - (Required) A name for the block storage volume. Must be lowercase and be composed only of numbers, letters and "-", up to a limit of 64 characters.
    name = ""

    # region - (Required) The region that the block storage volume will be created in.
    region = ""

    # description - (Optional) A free-form text field up to a limit of 1024 bytes to describe a block storage volume.
    description = ""

    # droplet_ids - (Optional) (Computed) A list of associated droplet ids
    droplet_ids = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The unique identifier for the block storage volume.
}
do-resource-volume.description: Provides a DigitalOcean Block Storage volume which can be attached to a Droplet in order to provide expanded storage.

docker-datasource-registry-image.description:
-> **Note:** The initial (current) version of this data source can reliably read only **public** images **from the official Docker Hub Registry**. Reads the image metadata from a Docker Registry. Used in conjunction with the
[docker\_image](/docs/providers/docker/r/image.html) resource to keep an image up
to date on the latest available version of the tag.

docker-resource-container.description: Manages the lifecycle of a Docker container.

docker-resource-image.body:
resource "docker_image" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (Required, string) The name of the Docker image, including any tags.
    name = ""

    # keep_locally - (Optional) (Optional, boolean) If true, then the Docker image won't be
    keep_locally = ""

    # pull_triggers - (Optional) (Optional, list of strings) List of values which cause an
    pull_triggers = ""

    # pull_trigger - (Optional) **Deprecated**, use `pull_triggers` instead.
    pull_trigger = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "latest" (string) - The ID of the image.
}
docker-resource-image.description:
-> **Note:** The initial (current) version of this resource can only pull **public** images **from the official Docker Hub Registry**. Pulls a Docker image to a given Docker host from a Docker Registry. This resource will *not* pull new layers of the image automatically unless used in
conjunction with [`docker_registry_image`](/docs/providers/docker/d/registry_image.html)
data source to update the `pull_triggers` field.

docker-resource-network.body:
resource "docker_network" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (Required, string) The name of the Docker network.
    name = ""

    # check_duplicate - (Optional) (Optional, boolean) Requests daemon to check for networks
    check_duplicate = ""

    # driver - (Optional) (Optional, string) Name of the network driver to use. Defaults to
    driver = ""

    # bridge - (Optional) `bridge` driver.
    bridge = ""

    # options - (Optional) (Optional, map of strings) Network specific options to be used by
    options = ""

    # internal - (Optional) (Optional, boolean) Restrict external access to the network.
    internal = ""

    # ipam_driver - (Optional) (Optional, string) Driver used by the custom IP scheme of the
    ipam_driver = ""

    # ipam_config - (Optional) (Optional, block) See [IPAM config](#ipam_config) below for
    ipam_config = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" (string)
    # "scope" (string)
}
docker-resource-network.description:
Manages a Docker Network. This can be used alongside
[docker\_container](/docs/providers/docker/r/container.html)
to create virtual networks within the docker environment.

docker-resource-volume.body:
resource "docker_volume" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (Optional, string) The name of the Docker volume (generated if not
    name = ""

    # driver - (Optional) (Optional, string) Driver type for the volume (defaults to local).
    driver = ""

    # driver_opts - (Optional) (Optional, map of strings) Options specific to the driver.
    driver_opts = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "mountpoint" (string) - The mountpoint of the volume.
}
docker-resource-volume.description:
Creates and destroys a volume in Docker. This can be used alongside
[docker\_container](/docs/providers/docker/r/container.html)
to prepare volumes that can be shared across containers.

dyn-resource-record.body:
resource "dyn_record" "$1" {
    # zone - (Required) The DNS zone to add the record to.
    zone = ""

    # value - (Required) The value of the record.
    value = ""

    # type - (Required) The type of the record.
    type = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the record.
    name = ""

    # ttl - (Optional) The TTL of the record. Default uses the zone default.
    ttl = ""

    # Exported Attributes

}
dyn-resource-record.description: Provides a Dyn DNS record resource.

fastly-datasource-ip_ranges.description: Use this data source to get the [IP ranges][1] of Fastly edge nodes.

    # ssl_sni_hostname - (Optional) Overrides ssl_hostname, but only for SNI in the handshake. Does not affect cert validation at all.
    ssl_sni_hostname = ""

    # shield - (Optional) The POP of the shield designated to reduce inbound load.
    shield = ""

    # weight - (Optional) The [portion of traffic](https://docs.fastly.com/guides/performance-tuning/load-balancing-configuration.html#how-weight-affects-load-balancing) to send to this Backend. Each Backend receives `weight / total` of the traffic. Default `100`.
    weight = ""

    # healthcheck - (Optional) Name of a defined `healthcheck` to assign to this backend.
    healthcheck = ""

    # cache_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` used to test whether this settings object should be used. This `condition` must be of type `CACHE`.
    cache_condition = ""

    # stale_ttl - (Optional) Max "Time To Live" for stale (unreachable) objects.
    stale_ttl = ""

    # ttl - (Optional) The Time-To-Live (TTL) for the object.
    ttl = ""

    # content_types - (Optional) The content-type for each type of content you wish to
    content_types = ""

    # extensions - (Optional) File extensions for each file type to dynamically
    extensions = ""

    # cache_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` controlling when this gzip configuration applies. This `condition` must be of type `CACHE`. For detailed information about Conditionals,
    cache_condition = ""

    # set - (Optional) `set`, `append`, `delete`, `regex`, or `regex_repeat`.
    set = ""

    # ignore_if_set - (Optional) Do not add the header if it is already present. (Only applies to the `set` action.). Default `false`.
    ignore_if_set = ""

    # source - (Optional) Variable to be used as a source for the header
    source = ""

    # regex - (Optional) Regular expression to use (Only applies to the `regex` and `regex_repeat` actions.)
    regex = ""

    # substitution - (Optional) Value to substitute in place of regular expression. (Only applies to the `regex` and `regex_repeat` actions.)
    substitution = ""

    # priority - (Optional) Lower priorities execute first. Default: `100`.
    priority = ""

    # request_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` to apply. This `condition` must be of type `REQUEST`.
    request_condition = ""

    # cache_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` to apply. This `condition` must be of type `CACHE`.
    cache_condition = ""

    # response_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` to apply. This `condition` must be of type `RESPONSE`. For detailed information about Conditionals,
    response_condition = ""

    # check_interval - (Optional) How often to run the Healthcheck in milliseconds. Default `5000`.
    check_interval = ""

    # expected_response - (Optional) The status code expected from the host. Default `200`.
    expected_response = ""

    # http_version - (Optional) Whether to use version 1.0 or 1.1 HTTP. Default `1.1`.
    http_version = ""

    # initial - (Optional) When loading a config, the initial number of probes to be seen as OK. Default `2`.
    initial = ""

    # method - (Optional) Which HTTP method to use. Default `HEAD`.
    method = ""

    # threshold - (Optional) How many Healthchecks must succeed to be considered healthy. Default `3`.
    threshold = ""

    # timeout - (Optional) Timeout in milliseconds. Default `500`.
    timeout = ""

    # window - (Optional) The number of most recent Healthcheck queries to keep for this Healthcheck. Default `5`.
    window = ""

    # request_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` to
    request_condition = ""

    # max_stale_age - (Optional) How old an object is allowed to be to serve
    max_stale_age = ""

    # force_miss - (Optional) Force a cache miss for the request. If specified,
    force_miss = ""

    # force_ssl - (Optional) Forces the request to use SSL (Redirects a non-SSL request to SSL).
    force_ssl = ""

    # action - (Optional) Allows you to terminate request handling and immediately
    action = ""

    # bypass_busy_wait - (Optional) Disable collapsed forwarding, so you don't wait
    bypass_busy_wait = ""

    # hash_keys - (Optional) Comma separated list of varnish request object fields
    hash_keys = ""

    # xff - (Optional) X-Forwarded-For, should be `clear`, `leave`, `append`,
    xff = ""

    # append_all - (Optional) `append_all`, or `overwrite`. Default `append`.
    append_all = ""

    # timer_support - (Optional) Injects the X-Timer info into the request for
    timer_support = ""

    # geo_headers - (Optional) Injects Fastly-Geo-Country, Fastly-Geo-City, and
    geo_headers = ""

    # default_host - (Optional) Sets the host header.
    default_host = ""

    # bucket_name - (Optional) An optional comment about the Domain.
    bucket_name = ""

    # path - (Optional) Path to store the files. Must end with a trailing slash.
    path = ""

    # domain - (Optional) If you created the S3 bucket outside of `us-east-1`,
    domain = ""

    # period - (Optional) How frequently the logs should be transferred, in
    period = ""

    # gzip_level - (Optional) Level of GZIP compression, from `0-9`. `0` is no
    gzip_level = ""

    # format - (Optional) Apache-style string or VCL variables to use for log formatting. Defaults to Apache Common Log format (`%h %l %u %t %r %>s`)
    format = ""

    # message_type - (Optional) How the message should be formatted; one of: `classic`, `loggly`, `logplex` or `blank`.  Default `classic`.
    message_type = ""

    # timestamp_format - (Optional) `strftime` specified timestamp formatting (default `%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S.000`).
    timestamp_format = ""

    # response_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` to apply. This `condition` must be of type `RESPONSE`. For detailed information about Conditionals,
    response_condition = ""

    # format - (Optional) Apache-style string or VCL variables to use for log formatting. Defaults to Apache Common Log format (`%h %l %u %t %r %>s`)
    format = ""

    # response_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` to apply. This `condition` must be of type `RESPONSE`. For detailed information about Conditionals,
    response_condition = ""

    # format - (Optional) Apache-style string or VCL variables to use for log formatting. Defaults to Apache Common Log format (`%h %l %u %t %r %>s`)
    format = ""

    # format_version - (Optional) The version of the custom logging format used for the configured endpoint. Can be either 1 (the default, version 1 log format) or 2 (the version 2 log format).
    format_version = ""

    # response_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` to apply. This `condition` must be of type `RESPONSE`. For detailed information about Conditionals, see [Fastly's Documentation on Conditionals][fastly-conditionals].
    response_condition = ""

    # message_type - (Optional) How the message should be formatted. One of: classic, loggly, logplex, blank. See [Fastly's Documentation on Sumologic][fastly-sumologic]
    message_type = ""

    # path - (Optional) Path to store the files. Must end with a trailing slash.
    path = ""

    # period - (Optional) How frequently the logs should be transferred, in
    period = ""

    # gzip_level - (Optional) Level of GZIP compression, from `0-9`. `0` is no
    gzip_level = ""

    # format - (Optional) Apache-style string or VCL variables to use for log formatting. Defaults to Apache Common Log format (`%h %l %u %t %r %>s`)
    format = ""

    # response_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` to apply. This `condition` must be of type `RESPONSE`. For detailed information about Conditionals, see [Fastly's Documentation on Conditionals][fastly-conditionals].
    response_condition = ""

    # status - (Optional) The HTTP Status Code. Default `200`.
    status = ""

    # response - (Optional) The HTTP Response. Default `Ok`.
    response = ""

    # content - (Optional) The content to deliver for the response object.
    content = ""

    # content_type - (Optional) The MIME type of the content.
    content_type = ""

    # request_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` to be checked during the request phase. If the condition passes then this object will be delivered. This `condition` must be of type `REQUEST`.
    request_condition = ""

    # cache_condition - (Optional) Name of already defined `condition` to check after we have retrieved an object. If the condition passes then deliver this Request Object instead. This `condition` must be of type `CACHE`. For detailed information about Conditionals,
    cache_condition = ""

    # main - (Optional) If `true`, use this block as the main configuration. If
    main = ""

    # false - (Optional) `false`, use this block as an includable library. Only a single VCL block can be
    false = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the Service.
    # "name" – Name of this service.
    # "active_version" - The currently active version of your Fastly
    # "domain" – Set of Domains. See above for details.
    # "backend" – Set of Backends. See above for details.
    # "header" – Set of Headers. See above for details.
    # "s3logging" – Set of S3 Logging configurations. See above for details.
    # "papertrail" – Set of Papertrail configurations. See above for details.
    # "response_object" - Set of Response Object configurations. See above for details.
    # "vcl" – Set of custom VCL configurations. See above for details.
    # "default_host" – Default host specified.
    # "default_ttl" - Default TTL.
    # "force_destroy" - Force the destruction of the Service on delete.
}
fastly-resource-service-v1.description:
Provides a Fastly Service, representing the configuration for a website, app,
API, or anything else to be served through Fastly. A Service encompasses Domains
and Backends. The Service resource requires a domain name that is correctly set up to direct
traffic to the Fastly service. See Fastly's guide on [Adding CNAME Records][fastly-cname]
on their documentation site for guidance.

github-datasource-team.body:
data "github_team" "$1" {
    # slug - (Required) The team slug.
    slug = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - the ID of the team.
    # "name" - the team's full name.
    # "description" - the team's description.
    # "privacy" - the team's privacy type.
    # "permission" - the team's permission level.
    # "members" - List of team members
}
github-datasource-team.description: Use this data source to retrieve information about a Github team.

github-datasource-user.body:
data "github_user" "$1" {
    # username - (Required) The username.
    username = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "login" - the user's login.
    # "avatar_url" - the user's avatar URL.
    # "gravatar_id" - the user's gravatar ID.
    # "site_admin" - whether the user is a Github admin.
    # "name" - the user's full name.
    # "company" - the user's company name.
    # "blog" - the user's blog location.
    # "location" - the user's location.
    # "email" - the user's email.
    # "gpg_keys" - list of user's GPG keys
    # "ssh_keys" - list of user's SSH keys
    # "bio" - the user's bio.
    # "public_repos" - the number of public repositories.
    # "public_gists" - the number of public gists.
    # "followers" - the number of followers.
    # "following" - the number of following users.
    # "created_at" - the creation date.
    # "updated_at" - the update date.
}
github-datasource-user.description: Use this data source to retrieve information about a Github user.

github-resource-branch-protection.body:
resource "github_branch_protection" "$1" {
    # branch - (Required) The Git branch to protect.
    branch = ""

    # repository - (Required) The GitHub repository name.
    repository = ""

    # enforce_admins - (Optional) Boolean, setting this to `true` enforces status checks for repository administrators.
    enforce_admins = ""

    # required_status_checks - (Optional) Enforce restrictions for required status checks. See [Required Status Checks](#required-status-checks) below for details.
    required_status_checks = ""

    # required_pull_request_reviews - (Optional) Enforce restrictions for pull request reviews. See [Required Pull Request Reviews](#required-pull-request-reviews) below for details.
    required_pull_request_reviews = ""

    # restrictions - (Optional) Enforce restrictions for the users and teams that may push to the branch. See [Restrictions](#restrictions) below for details.
    restrictions = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
github-resource-branch-protection.description: Protects a GitHub branch. This resource allows you to configure branch protection for repositories in your organization. When applied, the branch will be protected from forced pushes and deletion. Additional constraints, such as required status checks or restrictions on users and teams, can also be configured.

github-resource-issue-label.body:
resource "github_issue_label" "$1" {
    # color - (Required) A 6 character hex code, **without the leading #**, identifying the color of the label.
    color = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the label.
    name = ""

    # repository - (Required) The GitHub repository
    repository = ""

    # url - (Optional) (Computed) The URL to the issue label
    url = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
github-resource-issue-label.description:
Provides a GitHub issue label resource. This resource allows you to create and manage issue labels within your
Github organization. Issue labels are keyed off of their "name", so pre-existing issue labels result
in a 422 HTTP error if they exist outside of Terraform. Normally this would not
be an issue, except new repositories are created with a "default" set of labels,
and those labels easily conflict with custom ones. This resource will first check if the label exists, and then issue an update,
otherwise it will create.

github-resource-membership.body:
resource "github_membership" "$1" {
    # username - (Required) The user to add to the organization.
    username = ""

    # role - (Optional) The role of the user within the organization.
    role = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
github-resource-membership.description:
Provides a GitHub membership resource. This resource allows you to add/remove users from your organization. When applied,
an invitation will be sent to the user to become part of the organization. When
destroyed, either the invitation will be cancelled or the user will be removed.

github-resource-organization-webhook.body:
resource "github_organization_webhook" "$1" {
    # configuration - (Required) key/value pair of configuration for this webhook. Available keys are `url`, `content_type`, `secret` and `insecure_ssl`.
    configuration = ""

    # events - (Required) A list of events which should trigger the webhook. Defaults to `["push"]`. See a list of [available events](https://developer.github.com/v3/activity/events/types/)
    events = ""

    # name - (Required) The type of the webhook. See a list of [available hooks](https://api.github.com/hooks).
    name = ""

    # active - (Optional) Indicate of the webhook should receive events. Defaults to `true`.
    active = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "url" - URL of the webhook
    # "active" - (Optional) Indicate of the webhook should receive events. Defaults to "true".
}
github-resource-organization-webhook.description: This resource allows you to create and manage webhooks for Github organization.

github-resource-repository.body:
resource "github_repository" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the repository.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the repository.
    description = ""

    # homepage_url - (Optional) URL of a page describing the project.
    homepage_url = ""

    # private - (Optional) Set to `true` to create a private repository. Repositories are created as public (e.g. open source) by default.
    private = ""

    # has_issues - (Optional) Set to `true` to enable the Github Issues features on the repository.
    has_issues = ""

    # has_wiki - (Optional) Set to `true` to enable the Github Wiki features on the repository.
    has_wiki = ""

    # allow_merge_commit - (Optional) Set to `false` to disable merge commits on the repository.
    allow_merge_commit = ""

    # allow_squash_merge - (Optional) Set to `false` to disable squash merges on the repository.
    allow_squash_merge = ""

    # allow_rebase_merge - (Optional) Set to `false` to disable rebase merges on the repository.
    allow_rebase_merge = ""

    # has_downloads - (Optional) Set to `true` to enable the (deprecated) downloads features on the repository.
    has_downloads = ""

    # auto_init - (Optional) Meaningful only during create; set to `true` to produce an initial commit in the repository.
    auto_init = ""

    # gitignore_template - (Optional) Meaningful only during create, will be ignored after repository creation. Use the [name of the template](https://github.com/github/gitignore) without the extension. For example, "Haskell".
    gitignore_template = ""

    # license_template - (Optional) Meaningful only during create, will be ignored after repository creation. Use the [name of the template](https://github.com/github/choosealicense.com/tree/gh-pages/_licenses) without the extension. For example, "mit" or "mozilla".
    license_template = ""

    # default_branch - (Optional) The name of the default branch of the repository. **NOTE:** This can only be set after a repository has already been created, and after a correct reference has been created for the target branch inside the repository. This means a user will have to omit this parameter from the initial repository creation and create the target branch inside of the repository prior to setting this attribute.
    default_branch = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "full_name" - A string of the form "orgname/reponame".
    # "ssh_clone_url" - URL that can be provided to "git clone" to clone the repository via SSH.
    # "http_clone_url" - URL that can be provided to "git clone" to clone the repository via HTTPS.
    # "git_clone_url" - URL that can be provided to "git clone" to clone the repository anonymously via the git protocol.
    # "svn_url" - URL that can be provided to "svn checkout" to check out the repository via Github's Subversion protocol emulation.
}
github-resource-repository.description:
This resource allows you to create and manage repositories within your
Github organization. This resource cannot currently be used to manage *personal* repositories,
outside of organizations.

github-resource-repository-collaborator.body:
resource "github_repository_collaborator" "$1" {
    # username - (Required) The user to add to the repository as a collaborator.
    username = ""

    # repository - (Required) The GitHub repository
    repository = ""

    # permission - (Optional) The permission of the outside collaborator for the repository.
    permission = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
github-resource-repository-collaborator.description:
Provides a GitHub repository collaborator resource. This resource allows you to add/remove collaborators from repositories in your
organization. Collaborators can have explicit (and differing levels of) read,
write, or administrator access to specific repositories in your organization,
without giving the user full organization membership. When applied, an invitation will be sent to the user to become a collaborator
on a repository. When destroyed, either the invitation will be cancelled or the
collaborator will be removed from the repository. Further documentation on GitHub collaborators: [Adding outside collaborators to repositories in your organization](https://help.github.com/articles/adding-outside-collaborators-to-repositories-in-your-organization/)  [Converting an organization member to an outside collaborator](https://help.github.com/articles/converting-an-organization-member-to-an-outside-collaborator/)

github-resource-repository-deploy-key.body:
resource "github_repository_deploy_key" "$1" {
    # title - (Required) A title.
    title = ""

    # repository - (Required) Name of the Github repository.
    repository = ""

    # read_only - (Required) A boolean qualifying the key to be either read only or read/write.
    read_only = ""

    # key - (Required) A ssh key.
    key = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
github-resource-repository-deploy-key.description:
Provides a GitHub repository deploy key resource. A deploy key is an SSH key that is stored on your server and grants
access to a single GitHub repository. This key is attached directly to the repository instead of to a personal user
account. This resource allows you to add/remove repository deploy keys. Further documentation on GitHub repository deploy keys: [About deploy keys](https://developer.github.com/guides/managing-deploy-keys/#deploy-keys)

github-resource-repository-webhook.body:
resource "github_repository_webhook" "$1" {
    # configuration - (Required) key/value pair of configuration for this webhook. Available keys are `url`, `content_type`, `secret` and `insecure_ssl`.
    configuration = ""

    # events - (Required) A list of events which should trigger the webhook. Defaults to `["push"]`. See a list of [available events](https://developer.github.com/v3/activity/events/types/)
    events = ""

    # repository - (Required) The repository of the webhook.
    repository = ""

    # name - (Required) The type of the webhook. See a list of [available hooks](https://api.github.com/hooks).
    name = ""

    # active - (Optional) Indicate of the webhook should receive events. Defaults to `true`.
    active = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "url" - URL of the webhook
    # "active" - (Optional) Indicate of the webhook should receive events. Defaults to "true".
}
github-resource-repository-webhook.description:
This resource allows you to create and manage webhooks for repositories within your
Github organization. This resource cannot currently be used to manage webhooks for *personal* repositories,
outside of organizations.

github-resource-team.body:
resource "github_team" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the team.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the team.
    description = ""

    # privacy - (Optional) The level of privacy for the team. Must be one of `secret` or `closed`.
    privacy = ""

    # ldan_dn - (Optional) The LDAP Distinguished Name of the group where membership will be synchronized. Only available in GitHub Enterprise.
    ldan_dn = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the created team.
}
github-resource-team.description:
Provides a GitHub team resource. This resource allows you to add/remove teams from your organization. When applied,
a new team will be created. When destroyed, that team will be removed.

github-resource-team-membership.body:
resource "github_team_membership" "$1" {
    # username - (Required) The user to add to the team.
    username = ""

    # team_id - (Required) The GitHub team id
    team_id = ""

    # role - (Optional) The role of the user within the team.
    role = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
github-resource-team-membership.description:
Provides a GitHub team membership resource. This resource allows you to add/remove users from teams in your organization. When applied,
the user will be added to the team. If the user hasn't accepted their invitation to the
organization, they won't be part of the team until they do. When
destroyed, the user will be removed from the team.

github-resource-team-repository.body:
resource "github_team_repository" "$1" {
    # repository - (Required) The repository to add to the team.
    repository = ""

    # team_id - (Required) The GitHub team id
    team_id = ""

    # permission - (Optional) The permissions of team members regarding the repository.
    permission = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
github-resource-team-repository.description:
This resource manages relationships between teams and repositories
in your Github organization. Creating this resource grants a particular team permissions on a
particular repository. The repository and the team must both belong to the same organization
on Github. This resource does not actually *create* any repositories;
to do that, see [`github_repository`](repository.html).

gitlab-resource-deploy_key.body:
resource "gitlab_deploy_key" "$1" {
    # project - (Optional) (Required, string) The name or id of the project to add the deploy key to.
    project = ""

    # title - (Optional) (Required, string) A title to describe the deploy key with.
    title = ""

    # key - (Optional) (Required, string) The public ssh key body.
    key = ""

    # can_push - (Optional) (Optional, boolean) Allow this deploy key to be used to push changes to the project.  Defaults to `false`. **NOTE::** this cannot currently be managed.
    can_push = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
gitlab-resource-deploy_key.description: This resource allows you to create and manage deploy keys for your GitLab projects.

gitlab-resource-group.body:
resource "gitlab_group" "$1" {
    # path - (Required) The url of the hook to invoke.
    path = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of this group.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the group.
    description = ""

    # lfs_enabled - (Optional) Boolean, defaults to true.  Whether to enable LFS support for projects in this group.
    lfs_enabled = ""

    # request_access_enabled - (Optional) Boolean, defaults to false.  Whether to enable users to request access to the group.
    request_access_enabled = ""

    # visibility_level - (Optional) Set to `public` to create a public group. Valid values are `private`, `internal`, `public`. Groups are created as private by default.
    visibility_level = ""

    # parent_id - (Optional) Integer, id of the parent group (creates a nested group).
    parent_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The unique id assigned to the group by the GitLab server.  Serves as a
    # "parent_id" - (Optional) Integer, id of the parent group (creates a nested group).
}
gitlab-resource-group.description:
This resource allows you to create and manage GitLab groups.
Note your provider will need to be configured with admin-level access for this resource to work.

gitlab-resource-label.body:
resource "gitlab_label" "$1" {
    # color - (Required) The color of the label given in 6-digit hex notation with leading '#' sign (e.g. #FFAABB) or one of the [CSS color names](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/color_value#Color_keywords).
    color = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the label.
    name = ""

    # project - (Required) The name or id of the project to add the label to.
    project = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the label.
    description = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The unique id assigned to the label by the GitLab server (the name of the label).
    # "description" - (Optional) The description of the label.
}
gitlab-resource-label.description:
This resource allows you to create and manage labels for your GitLab projects.
For further information on labels, consult the [gitlab
documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/labels.htm).

gitlab-resource-project-hook.body:
resource "gitlab_project_hook" "$1" {
    # url - (Required) The url of the hook to invoke.
    url = ""

    # project - (Required) The name or id of the project to add the hook to.
    project = ""

    # token - (Optional) A token to present when invoking the hook.
    token = ""

    # enable_ssl_verification - (Optional) Enable ssl verification when invoking the hook.
    enable_ssl_verification = ""

    # push_events - (Optional) Invoke the hook for push events.
    push_events = ""

    # issues_events - (Optional) Invoke the hook for issues events.
    issues_events = ""

    # merge_requests_events - (Optional) Invoke the hook for merge requests.
    merge_requests_events = ""

    # tag_push_events - (Optional) Invoke the hook for tag push events.
    tag_push_events = ""

    # note_events - (Optional) Invoke the hook for notes events.
    note_events = ""

    # job_events - (Optional) Invoke the hook for job events.
    job_events = ""

    # pipeline_events - (Optional) Invoke the hook for pipeline events.
    pipeline_events = ""

    # wiki_page_events - (Optional) Invoke the hook for wiki page events.
    wiki_page_events = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The unique id assigned to the hook by the GitLab server.
    # "wiki_page_events" - (Optional) Invoke the hook for wiki page events.
}
gitlab-resource-project-hook.description:
This resource allows you to create and manage hooks for your GitLab projects.
For further information on hooks, consult the [gitlab
documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ce/user/project/integrations/webhooks.html).

gitlab-resource-project-x.body:
resource "gitlab_project" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the project.
    name = ""

    # path - (Optional) The path of the repository.
    path = ""

    # namespace_id - (Optional) The namespace (group or user) of the project. Defaults to your user. See [`gitlab_group`](group.html) for an example.
    namespace_id = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the project.
    description = ""

    # default_branch - (Optional) The default branch for the project.
    default_branch = ""

    # issues_enabled - (Optional) Enable issue tracking for the project.
    issues_enabled = ""

    # merge_requests_enabled - (Optional) Enable merge requests for the project.
    merge_requests_enabled = ""

    # wiki_enabled - (Optional) Enable wiki for the project.
    wiki_enabled = ""

    # snippets_enabled - (Optional) Enable snippets for the project.
    snippets_enabled = ""

    # visibility_level - (Optional) Set to `public` to create a public project. Valid values are `private`, `internal`, `public`. Repositories are created as private by default.
    visibility_level = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - Integer that uniquely identifies the project within the gitlab install.
    # "ssh_url_to_repo" - URL that can be provided to "git clone" to clone the repository via SSH.
    # "http_url_to_repo" - URL that can be provided to "git clone" to clone the repository via HTTP.
    # "web_url" - URL that can be used to find the project in a browser.
}
gitlab-resource-project-x.description:
This resource allows you to create and manage projects within your
GitLab group or within your user.

gitlab-resource-user.body:
resource "gitlab_user" "$1" {
    # email - (Required) The e-mail address of the user.
    email = ""

    # password - (Required) The password of the user.
    password = ""

    # username - (Required) The username of the user.
    username = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the user.
    name = ""

    # is_admin - (Optional) Boolean, defaults to false.  Whether to enable administrative priviledges for the user.
    is_admin = ""

    # projects_limit - (Optional) Integer, defaults to 0.  Number of projects user can create.
    projects_limit = ""

    # can_create_group - (Optional) Boolean, defaults to false. Whether to allow the user to create groups.
    can_create_group = ""

    # skip_confirmation - (Optional) Boolean, defaults to true. Whether to skip confirmation.
    skip_confirmation = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The unique id assigned to the user by the GitLab server.
    # "skip_confirmation" - (Optional) Boolean, defaults to true. Whether to skip confirmation.
}
gitlab-resource-user.description:
This resource allows you to create and manage GitLab users.
Note your provider will need to be configured with admin-level access for this resource to work.

google-bigquery-dataset.body:
resource "google_bigquery_dataset" "$1" {
    # dataset_id - (Required) A unique ID for the resource.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    dataset_id = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # friendly_name - (Optional) A descriptive name for the dataset.
    friendly_name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A user-friendly description of the dataset.
    description = ""

    # location - (Optional) The geographic location where the dataset should reside.   Possible values include `EU` and `US`. The default value is `US`.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    location = ""

    # default_table_expiration_ms - (Optional) The default lifetime of all   tables in the dataset, in milliseconds. The minimum value is 3600000   milliseconds (one hour).   Once this property is set, all newly-created   tables in the dataset will have an expirationTime property set to the   creation time plus the value in this property, and changing the value   will only affect new tables, not existing ones. When the   expirationTime for a given table is reached, that table will be   deleted automatically. If a table's expirationTime is modified or   removed before the table expires, or if you provide an explicit   expirationTime when creating a table, that value takes precedence   over the default expiration time indicated by this property.
    default_table_expiration_ms = ""

    # labels - (Optional) A mapping of labels to assign to the resource.
    labels = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "etag" - A hash of the resource.
    # "creation_time" - The time when this dataset was created, in milliseconds since the epoch.
    # "last_modified_time" -  The date when this dataset or any of its tables was last modified, in milliseconds since the epoch.
}
google-bigquery-dataset.description:
Creates a dataset resource for Google BigQuery. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/reference/rest/v2/datasets).

google-bigquery-table.body:
resource "google_bigquery_table" "$1" {
    # type - (Required) The only type supported is DAY, which will generate   one partition per day based on data loading time.
    type = ""

    # table_id - (Required) A unique ID for the resource.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    table_id = ""

    # dataset_id - (Required) The dataset ID to create the table in.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    dataset_id = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # description - (Optional) The field description.
    description = ""

    # expiration_time - (Optional) The time when this table expires, in   milliseconds since the epoch. If not present, the table will persist   indefinitely. Expired tables will be deleted and their storage   reclaimed.
    expiration_time = ""

    # friendly_name - (Optional) A descriptive name for the table.
    friendly_name = ""

    # labels - (Optional) A mapping of labels to assign to the resource.
    labels = ""

    # schema - (Optional) A JSON schema for the table.
    schema = ""

    # time_partitioning - (Optional) If specified, configures time-based   partitioning for this table. Structure is documented below.
    time_partitioning = ""

    # expiration_ms - (Optional) Number of milliseconds for which to keep the   storage for a partition.
    expiration_ms = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "creation_time" - The time when this table was created, in milliseconds since the epoch.
    # "etag" - A hash of the resource.
    # "last_modified_time" - The time when this table was last modified, in milliseconds since the epoch.
    # "location" - The geographic location where the table resides. This value is inherited from the dataset.
    # "num_bytes" - The size of this table in bytes, excluding any data in the streaming buffer.
    # "num_long_term_bytes" - The number of bytes in the table that are considered "long-term storage".
    # "num_rows" - The number of rows of data in this table, excluding any data in the streaming buffer.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "type" - Describes the table type.
}
google-bigquery-table.description:
Creates a table resource in a dataset for Google BigQuery. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/reference/rest/v2/tables).

google-bigtable-instance.body:
resource "google_bigtable_instance" "$1" {
    # zone - (Required) The zone to create the Bigtable instance in. Zones that support Bigtable instances are noted on the [Cloud Locations page](https://cloud.google.com/about/locations/).
    zone = ""

    # cluster_id - (Required) The name of the Bigtable instance's cluster.
    cluster_id = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the Bigtable instance.
    name = ""

    # num_nodes - (Optional) The number of nodes in your Bigtable instance. Minimum of `3` for a `PRODUCTION` instance. Cannot be set for a `DEVELOPMENT` instance.
    num_nodes = ""

    # instance_type - (Optional) The instance type to create. One of `"DEVELOPMENT"` or `"PRODUCTION"`. Defaults to `PRODUCTION`.
    instance_type = ""

    # storage_type - (Optional) The storage type to use. One of `"SSD"` or `"HDD"`. Defaults to `SSD`.
    storage_type = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # display_name - (Optional) The human-readable display name of the Bigtable instance. Defaults to the instance `name`.
    display_name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
google-bigtable-instance.description:
Creates a Google Bigtable instance. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/bigtable/) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/bigtable/docs/go/reference).

google-bigtable-table.body:
resource "google_bigtable_table" "$1" {
    # instance_name - (Required) The name of the Bigtable instance.
    instance_name = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the table.
    name = ""

    # split_keys - (Optional) A list of predefined keys to split the table on.
    split_keys = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
google-bigtable-table.description:
Creates a Google Bigtable table inside an instance. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/bigtable/) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/bigtable/docs/go/reference).

google-compute-address.body:
resource "google_compute_address" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.
    name = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # region - (Optional) The Region in which the created address should reside.   If it is not provided, the provider region is used.
    region = ""

    # address_type - (Optional) The Address Type that should be configured.   Specify INTERNAL to reserve an internal static IP address EXTERNAL to   specify an external static IP address. Defaults to EXTERNAL if omitted.
    address_type = ""

    # subnetwork - (Optional) The self link URI of the subnetwork in which to   create the address. A subnetwork may only be specified for INTERNAL   address types.
    subnetwork = ""

    # address - (Optional) The IP address to reserve. An address may only be   specified for INTERNAL address types. The IP address must be inside the   specified subnetwork, if any.
    address = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "address" - (Optional) The IP address to reserve. An address may only be   specified for INTERNAL address types. The IP address must be inside the   specified subnetwork, if any.
    # "address" - The IP of the created resource.
    # "address" - (Optional) The IP address to reserve. An address may only be   specified for INTERNAL address types. The IP address must be inside the   specified subnetwork, if any.
}
google-compute-address.description:
Creates a static IP address resource for Google Compute Engine. For more information see
the official documentation for
[external](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances-and-network) and
[internal](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/ip-addresses/reserve-static-internal-ip-address)
static IP reservations, as well as the
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/beta/addresses/insert).

google-compute-autoscaler.body:
resource "google_compute_autoscaler" "$1" {
    # min_replicas - (Required) The group will never be smaller than this.
    min_replicas = ""

    # max_replicas - (Required) The group will never be larger than this.
    max_replicas = ""

    # autoscaling_policy - (Required) The parameters of the autoscaling algorithm. Structure is documented below.
    autoscaling_policy = ""

    # zone - (Required) The zone of the target.
    zone = ""

    # target - (Required) The full URL to the instance group manager whose size we control.
    target = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the autoscaler.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional textual description of the instance   group manager.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # cooldown_period - (Optional) Period to wait between changes. This should be at least double the time your instances take to start up.
    cooldown_period = ""

    # cpu_utilization - (Optional) A policy that scales when the cluster's average CPU is above or below a given threshold. Structure is documented below.
    cpu_utilization = ""

    # metric - (Optional) A policy that scales according to Google Cloud Monitoring metrics  Structure is documented below.
    metric = ""

    # load_balancing_utilization - (Optional) A policy that scales when the load reaches a proportion of a limit defined in the HTTP load balancer. Structure is documented below.
    load_balancing_utilization = ""

    # target - (Optional) The floating point threshold where CPU utilization should be. E.g.
    target = ""

    # load_balancing_utilization - (Optional) A policy that scales when the load reaches a proportion of a limit defined in the HTTP load balancer. Structure is documented below.
    load_balancing_utilization = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the Google Cloud Monitoring metric to follow, e.g. `compute.googleapis.com/instance/network/received_bytes_count`
    name = ""

    # type - (Optional) Either "cumulative", "delta", or "gauge".
    type = ""

    # target - (Optional) The desired metric value per instance. Must be a positive value.
    target = ""

    # target - (Optional) The floating point threshold where load balancing utilization
    target = ""

    # target - (Optional) The desired metric value per instance. Must be a positive value.
    target = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URL of the created resource.
    # "target" - The desired metric value per instance. Must be a positive value.
}
google-compute-autoscaler.description:
A Compute Engine Autoscaler automatically adds or removes virtual machines from
a managed instance group based on increases or decreases in load. This allows
your applications to gracefully handle increases in traffic and reduces cost
when the need for resources is lower. You just define the autoscaling policy and
the autoscaler performs automatic scaling based on the measured load. For more
information, see [the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/autoscaler/) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/autoscalers)

google-compute-backend-bucket.body:
resource "google_compute_backend_bucket" "$1" {
    # bucket_name - (Required) The name of the Google Cloud Storage bucket to be used as a backend   bucket.
    bucket_name = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the backend bucket.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The textual description for the backend bucket.
    description = ""

    # enable_cdn - (Optional) Whether or not to enable the Cloud CDN on the backend bucket.
    enable_cdn = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it is not provided, the   provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "project" - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it is not provided, the   provider project is used.
}
google-compute-backend-bucket.description:
A Backend Bucket defines a Google Cloud Storage bucket that will serve traffic through Google Cloud
Load Balancer. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/http/backend-bucket)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/backendBuckets).

google-compute-backend-service.body:
resource "google_compute_backend_service" "$1" {
    # group - (Required) The name or URI of a Compute Engine instance group   (`google_compute_instance_group_manager.xyz.instance_group`) that can   receive traffic.
    group = ""

    # health_checks - (Required) Specifies a list of HTTP/HTTPS health checks   for checking the health of the backend service. Currently at most one health   check can be specified, and a health check is required.
    health_checks = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the backend service.
    name = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region this backend service has been created in. If   unspecified, this defaults to the region configured in the provider.
    region = ""

    # backend - (Optional) The list of backends that serve this BackendService. Structure is documented below.
    backend = ""

    # description - (Optional) The textual description for the backend service.
    description = ""

    # enable_cdn - (Optional) Whether or not to enable the Cloud CDN on the backend service.
    enable_cdn = ""

    # port_name - (Optional) The name of a service that has been added to an   instance group in this backend. See [related docs](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instance-groups/#specifying_service_endpoints) for details. Defaults to http.
    port_name = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # protocol - (Optional) The protocol for incoming requests. Defaults to   `HTTP`.
    protocol = ""

    # session_affinity - (Optional) How to distribute load. Options are `NONE` (no   affinity), `CLIENT_IP` (hash of the source/dest addresses / ports), and   `GENERATED_COOKIE` (distribute load using a generated session cookie).
    session_affinity = ""

    # timeout_sec - (Optional) The number of secs to wait for a backend to respond   to a request before considering the request failed. Defaults to `30`.
    timeout_sec = ""

    # connection_draining_timeout_sec - (Optional) Time for which instance will be drained (not accept new connections, but still work to finish started ones). Defaults to `300`.
    connection_draining_timeout_sec = ""

    # balancing_mode - (Optional) Defines the strategy for balancing load.   Defaults to `UTILIZATION`
    balancing_mode = ""

    # capacity_scaler - (Optional) A float in the range [0, 1.0] that scales the   maximum parameters for the group (e.g., max rate). A value of 0.0 will cause   no requests to be sent to the group (i.e., it adds the group in a drained   state). The default is 1.0.
    capacity_scaler = ""

    # description - (Optional) Textual description for the backend.
    description = ""

    # max_rate - (Optional) Maximum requests per second (RPS) that the group can   handle.
    max_rate = ""

    # max_rate_per_instance - (Optional) The maximum per-instance requests per   second (RPS).
    max_rate_per_instance = ""

    # max_utilization - (Optional) The target CPU utilization for the group as a   float in the range [0.0, 1.0]. This flag can only be provided when the   balancing mode is `UTILIZATION`. Defaults to `0.8`.
    max_utilization = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "fingerprint" - The fingerprint of the backend service.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-backend-service.description:
A Backend Service defines a group of virtual machines that will serve traffic for load balancing. For more information
see [the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/http/backend-service)
and the [API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/backendServices). For internal load balancing, use a [google_compute_region_backend_service](/docs/providers/google/r/compute_region_backend_service.html).

google-compute-disk.body:
resource "google_compute_disk" "$1" {
    # zone - (Required) The zone where this disk will be available.
    zone = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # disk_encryption_key_raw - (Optional) A 256-bit [customer-supplied encryption key]   (https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/customer-supplied-encryption),   encoded in [RFC 4648 base64](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648#section-4)   to encrypt this disk.
    disk_encryption_key_raw = ""

    # image - (Optional) The image from which to initialize this disk. This can be   one of: the image's `self_link`, of a full name and version, e.g.   `debian-8-jessie-v20170523`
    image = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # size - (Optional) The size of the image in gigabytes. If not specified, it   will inherit the size of its base image.
    size = ""

    # snapshot - (Optional) Name of snapshot from which to initialize this disk.
    snapshot = ""

    # type - (Optional) The GCE disk type.
    type = ""

    # labels - (Optional) A set of key/value label pairs to assign to the image.
    labels = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "disk_encryption_key_sha256" - The [RFC 4648 base64]   (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648#section-4) encoded SHA-256 hash of the   [customer-supplied encryption key](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/customer-supplied-encryption)   that protects this resource.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "users" - The Users of the created resource.
    # "label_fingerprint" - The fingerprint of the assigned labels.
}
google-compute-disk.description:
Creates a new persistent disk within GCE, based on another disk. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/add-persistent-disk)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/disks). ~> **Note:** All arguments including the disk encryption key will be stored in the raw state as plain-text.
[Read more about sensitive data in state](/docs/state/sensitive-data.html).

google-compute-firewall.body:
resource "google_compute_firewall" "$1" {
    # protocol - (Required) The name of the protocol to allow.
    protocol = ""

    # protocol - (Required) The name of the protocol to allow.
    protocol = ""

    # allow - (Required) Can be specified multiple times for each allow   rule. Each allow block supports fields documented below.
    allow = ""

    # network - (Required) The name or self_link of the network to attach this firewall to.
    network = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) Textual description field.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # priority - (Optional) The priority for this firewall. Ranges from 0-65535, inclusive. Defaults to 1000. Firewall   resources with lower priority values have higher precedence (e.g. a firewall resource with a priority value of 0   takes effect over all other firewall rules with a non-zero priority).
    priority = ""

    # source_ranges - (Optional) A list of source CIDR ranges that this  firewall applies to. Can't be used for `EGRESS`.
    source_ranges = ""

    # source_tags - (Optional) A list of source tags for this firewall. Can't be used for `EGRESS`.
    source_tags = ""

    # target_tags - (Optional) A list of target tags for this firewall.
    target_tags = ""

    # deny - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) Can be specified multiple times for each deny   rule. Each deny block supports fields documented below. Can be specified   instead of allow.
    deny = ""

    # direction - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) Direction of traffic to which this firewall applies;   One of `INGRESS` or `EGRESS`. Defaults to `INGRESS`.
    direction = ""

    # destination_ranges - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) A list of destination CIDR ranges that this  firewall applies to. Can't be used for `INGRESS`.
    destination_ranges = ""

    # source_service_accounts - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) A list of service accounts such that   the firewall will apply only to traffic originating from an instance with a service account in this list. Source service accounts   cannot be used to control traffic to an instance's external IP address because service accounts are associated with an instance, not   an IP address. `source_ranges` can be set at the same time as `source_service_accounts`. If both are set, the firewall will apply to   traffic that has source IP address within `source_ranges` OR the source IP belongs to an instance with service account listed in   `source_service_accounts`. The connection does not need to match both properties for the firewall to apply. `source_service_accounts`   cannot be used at the same time as `source_tags` or `target_tags`.
    source_service_accounts = ""

    # target_service_accounts - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) A list of service accounts indicating   sets of instances located in the network that may make network connections as specified in `allow`. `target_service_accounts` cannot   be used at the same time as `source_tags` or `target_tags`. If neither `target_service_accounts` nor `target_tags` are specified, the   firewall rule applies to all instances on the specified network.
    target_service_accounts = ""

    # ports - (Optional) List of ports and/or port ranges to allow. This can   only be specified if the protocol is TCP or UDP.
    ports = ""

    # ports - (Optional) List of ports and/or port ranges to allow. This can   only be specified if the protocol is TCP or UDP.
    ports = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "ports" - (Optional) List of ports and/or port ranges to allow. This can   only be specified if the protocol is TCP or UDP.
}
google-compute-firewall.description:
Manages a firewall resource within GCE. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/vpc/firewalls)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/firewalls).

google-compute-forwarding-rule.body:
resource "google_compute_forwarding_rule" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing
    name = ""

    # backend_service - (Optional) BackendService resource to receive the   matched traffic. Only used for internal load balancing.
    backend_service = ""

    # description - (Optional) Textual description field.
    description = ""

    # ip_address - (Optional) The static IP. (if not set, an ephemeral IP is   used).
    ip_address = ""

    # ip_protocol - (Optional) The IP protocol to route, one of "TCP" "UDP" "AH"   "ESP" or "SCTP" for external load balancing, "TCP" or "UDP" for internal   (default "TCP").
    ip_protocol = ""

    # load_balancing_scheme - (Optional) Type of load balancing to use. Can be   set to "INTERNAL" or "EXTERNAL" (default "EXTERNAL").
    load_balancing_scheme = ""

    # network - (Optional) Network name or self_link that the load balanced IP   should belong to. Only used for internal load balancing. If it is not   provided, the default network is used.
    network = ""

    # port_range - (Optional) A range e.g. "1024-2048" or a single port "1024"   (defaults to all ports!). Only used for external load balancing.
    port_range = ""

    # ports - (Optional) A list of ports (maximum of 5) to use for internal load   balancing. Packets addressed to these ports will be forwarded to the backends   configured with this forwarding rule. Required for internal load balancing.
    ports = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # region - (Optional) The Region in which the created address should reside.   If it is not provided, the provider region is used.
    region = ""

    # subnetwork - (Optional) Subnetwork that the load balanced IP should belong   to. Only used for internal load balancing. Must be specified if the network   is in custom subnet mode.
    subnetwork = ""

    # target - (Optional) URL of target pool. Required for external load   balancing.
    target = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "target" - (Optional) URL of target pool. Required for external load   balancing.
}
google-compute-forwarding-rule.description:
Manages a Forwarding Rule within GCE. This binds an ip and port range to a target pool. For more
information see [the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/network/forwarding-rules) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/forwardingRules).

google-compute-global-address.body:
resource "google_compute_global_address" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.
    name = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    ip_version = ""

    # Exported Attributes
