google-compute-global-address.description:
Creates a static IP address resource global to a Google Compute Engine project. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances-and-network) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/globalAddresses).

google-compute-global-forwarding-rule.body:
resource "google_compute_global_forwarding_rule" "$1" {
    # target - (Required) URL of target HTTP or HTTPS proxy.
    target = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) Textual description field.
    description = ""

    # ip_address - (Optional) The static IP. (if not set, an ephemeral IP is   used). This should be the literal IP address to be used, not the `self_link`   to a `google_compute_global_address` resource. (If using a `google_compute_global_address`   resource, use the `address` property instead of the `self_link` property.)
    ip_address = ""

    # ip_protocol - (Optional) The IP protocol to route, one of "TCP" "UDP" "AH"   "ESP" or "SCTP". (default "TCP").
    ip_protocol = ""

    # port_range - (Optional) A range e.g. "1024-2048" or a single port "1024"   (defaults to all ports!).
    port_range = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # ip_version - (Optional) The IP Version that will be used by this resource's address. One of `"IPV4"` or `"IPV6"`.
    ip_version = ""

    # labels - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features))
    labels = ""

    # ip_version - (Optional) The IP Version that will be used by this resource's address. One of `"IPV4"` or `"IPV6"`.
    ip_version = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "label_fingerprint" - ([Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) The current label fingerprint.
}
google-compute-global-forwarding-rule.description:
Manages a Global Forwarding Rule within GCE. This binds an ip and port to a target HTTP(s) proxy. For more
information see [the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/http/global-forwarding-rules) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/globalForwardingRules).

google-compute-health-check.body:
resource "google_compute_health_check" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.
    name = ""

    # check_interval_sec - (Optional) The number of seconds between each poll of   the instance instance (default 5).
    check_interval_sec = ""

    # description - (Optional) Textual description field.
    description = ""

    # healthy_threshold - (Optional) Consecutive successes required (default 2).
    healthy_threshold = ""

    # http_health_check - (Optional) An HTTP Health Check. Only one kind of Health Check can be added.   Structure is documented below.
    http_health_check = ""

    # https_health_check - (Optional) An HTTPS Health Check. Only one kind of Health Check can be added.   Structure is documented below.
    https_health_check = ""

    # ssl_health_check - (Optional) An SSL Health Check. Only one kind of Health Check can be added.   Structure is documented below.
    ssl_health_check = ""

    # tcp_health_check - (Optional) A TCP Health Check. Only one kind of Health Check can be added.   Structure is documented below.
    tcp_health_check = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # timeout_sec - (Optional) The number of seconds to wait before declaring   failure (default 5).
    timeout_sec = ""

    # unhealthy_threshold - (Optional) Consecutive failures required (default 2).
    unhealthy_threshold = ""

    # host - (Optional) HTTP host header field (default instance's public ip).
    host = ""

    # port - (Optional) TCP port to connect to (default 80).
    port = ""

    # proxy_header - (Optional) Type of proxy header to append before sending   data to the backend, either NONE or PROXY_V1 (default NONE).
    proxy_header = ""

    # request_path - (Optional) URL path to query (default /).
    request_path = ""

    # host - (Optional) HTTPS host header field (default instance's public ip).
    host = ""

    # port - (Optional) TCP port to connect to (default 443).
    port = ""

    # proxy_header - (Optional) Type of proxy header to append before sending   data to the backend, either NONE or PROXY_V1 (default NONE).
    proxy_header = ""

    # request_path - (Optional) URL path to query (default /).
    request_path = ""

    # port - (Optional) TCP port to connect to (default 443).
    port = ""

    # proxy_header - (Optional) Type of proxy header to append before sending   data to the backend, either NONE or PROXY_V1 (default NONE).
    proxy_header = ""

    # request - (Optional) Application data to send once the SSL connection has   been established (default "").
    request = ""

    # response - (Optional) The response that indicates health (default "")
    response = ""

    # port - (Optional) TCP port to connect to (default 80).
    port = ""

    # proxy_header - (Optional) Type of proxy header to append before sending   data to the backend, either NONE or PROXY_V1 (default NONE).
    proxy_header = ""

    # request - (Optional) Application data to send once the TCP connection has   been established (default "").
    request = ""

    # response - (Optional) The response that indicates health (default "")
    response = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "response" - (Optional) The response that indicates health (default "")
}
google-compute-health-check.description:
Manages a health check within GCE. This is used to monitor instances
behind load balancers. Timeouts or HTTP errors cause the instance to be
removed from the pool. For more information, see [the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/health-checks)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/healthChecks).

google-compute-http-health-check.body:
resource "google_compute_http_health_check" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.
    name = ""

    # check_interval_sec - (Optional) The number of seconds between each poll of   the instance instance (default 5).
    check_interval_sec = ""

    # description - (Optional) Textual description field.
    description = ""

    # healthy_threshold - (Optional) Consecutive successes required (default 2).
    healthy_threshold = ""

    # host - (Optional) HTTP host header field (default instance's public ip).
    host = ""

    # port - (Optional) TCP port to connect to (default 80).
    port = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # request_path - (Optional) URL path to query (default /).
    request_path = ""

    # timeout_sec - (Optional) The number of seconds to wait before declaring   failure (default 5).
    timeout_sec = ""

    # unhealthy_threshold - (Optional) Consecutive failures required (default 2).
    unhealthy_threshold = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "unhealthy_threshold" - (Optional) Consecutive failures required (default 2).
}
google-compute-http-health-check.description:
Manages an HTTP health check within GCE. This is used to monitor instances
behind load balancers. Timeouts or HTTP errors cause the instance to be
removed from the pool. For more information, see [the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/health-checks#legacy_health_checks)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/httpHealthChecks). ~> **Note:** HttpHealthChecks/HTTPSHealthChecks are legacy health checks. The newer [google_compute_health_check](/docs/providers/google/r/compute_health_check.html) should be preferred for all uses except except [Network Load Balancers](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/network/) which still require the legacy HttpHealthChecks.

google-compute-https-health-check.body:
resource "google_compute_https_health_check" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing
    name = ""

    # check_interval_sec - (Optional) How often to poll each instance (default 5).
    check_interval_sec = ""

    # description - (Optional) Textual description field.
    description = ""

    # healthy_threshold - (Optional) Consecutive successes required (default 2).
    healthy_threshold = ""

    # host - (Optional) HTTPS host header field (default instance's public ip).
    host = ""

    # port - (Optional) TCP port to connect to (default 443).
    port = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # request_path - (Optional) URL path to query (default /).
    request_path = ""

    # timeout_sec - (Optional) How long before declaring failure (default 5).
    timeout_sec = ""

    # unhealthy_threshold - (Optional) Consecutive failures required (default 2).
    unhealthy_threshold = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URL of the created resource.
    # "unhealthy_threshold" - (Optional) Consecutive failures required (default 2).
}
google-compute-https-health-check.description:
Manages an HTTPS health check within GCE. This is used to monitor instances
behind load balancers. Timeouts or HTTPS errors cause the instance to be
removed from the pool. For more information, see [the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/health-checks#legacy_health_checks)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/httpsHealthChecks). ~> **Note:** HTTPSHealthChecks/HttpHealthChecks are legacy health checks. The newer [google_compute_health_check](/docs/providers/google/r/compute_health_check.html) should be preferred for all uses except except [Network Load Balancers](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/network/) which still require the legacy HttpHealthChecks.

google-compute-image.body:
resource "google_compute_image" "$1" {
    # source - (Required) The full Google Cloud Storage URL where the disk   image is stored.
    source = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # source_disk - (Optional) The URL of a disk that will be used as the source of the   image. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    source_disk = ""

    # raw_disk - (Optional) The raw disk that will be used as the source of the image.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created. Structure is documented   below.
    raw_disk = ""

    # create_timeout - (Optional) Configurable timeout in minutes for creating images. Default is 4 minutes.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    create_timeout = ""

    # container_type - (Optional) The format used to encode and transmit the   block device. TAR is the only supported type and is the default.
    container_type = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the image to be created
    description = ""

    # family - (Optional) The name of the image family to which this image belongs.
    family = ""

    # labels - (Optional) A set of key/value label pairs to assign to the image.
    labels = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "label_fingerprint" - The fingerprint of the assigned labels.
}
google-compute-image.description:
Creates a bootable VM image resource for Google Compute Engine from an existing
tarball. For more information see [the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/images) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/images).

google-compute-instance-group-manager.body:
resource "google_compute_instance_group_manager" "$1" {
    # initial_delay_sec - (Required) The number of seconds that the managed instance group waits before it applies autohealing policies to new instances or recently recreated instances. Between 0 and 3600.
    initial_delay_sec = ""

    # health_check - (Required) The health check resource that signals autohealing.
    health_check = ""

    # port - (Required) The port number.
    port = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the port.
    name = ""

    # zone - (Required) The zone that instances in this group should be created   in.
    zone = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the instance group manager. Must be 1-63   characters long and comply with   [RFC1035](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1035.txt). Supported characters   include lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens.
    name = ""

    # instance_template - (Required) The full URL to an instance template from   which all new instances will be created.
    instance_template = ""

    # base_instance_name - (Required) The base instance name to use for   instances in this group. The value must be a valid   [RFC1035](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1035.txt) name. Supported characters   are lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens (-). Instances are named by   appending a hyphen and a random four-character string to the base instance   name.
    base_instance_name = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional textual description of the instance   group manager.
    description = ""

    # named_port - (Optional) The named port configuration. See the section below   for details on configuration.
    named_port = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # update_strategy - (Optional) (Optional, Default `"RESTART"`) If the `instance_template`   resource is modified, a value of `"NONE"` will prevent any of the managed   instances from being restarted by Terraform. A value of `"RESTART"` will   restart all of the instances at once. In the future, as the GCE API matures   we will support `"ROLLING_UPDATE"` as well.
    update_strategy = ""

    # target_size - (Optional) The target number of running instances for this managed   instance group. This value should always be explicitly set unless this resource is attached to    an autoscaler, in which case it should never be set. Defaults to `0`.
    target_size = ""

    # target_pools - (Optional) The full URL of all target pools to which new   instances in the group are added. Updating the target pools attribute does   not affect existing instances.
    target_pools = ""

    # auto_healing_policies - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) The autohealing policies for this managed instance
    auto_healing_policies = ""

    # target_pools - (Optional) The full URL of all target pools to which new   instances in the group are added. Updating the target pools attribute does   not affect existing instances.
    target_pools = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "fingerprint" - The fingerprint of the instance group manager.
    # "instance_group" - The full URL of the instance group created by the manager.
    # "self_link" - The URL of the created resource.
}
google-compute-instance-group-manager.description:
The Google Compute Engine Instance Group Manager API creates and manages pools
of homogeneous Compute Engine virtual machine instances from a common instance
template. For more information, see [the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instance-groups/manager)
and [API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/instanceGroupManagers) ~> **Note:** Use [google_compute_region_instance_group_manager](/docs/providers/google/r/compute_region_instance_group_manager.html) to create a regional (multi-zone) instance group manager.

google-compute-instance-group-x.body:
resource "google_compute_instance_group" "$1" {
    # port - (Required) The port number to map the name to.
    port = ""

    # name - (Required) The name which the port will be mapped to.
    name = ""

    # zone - (Required) The zone that this instance group should be created in.
    zone = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the instance group. Must be 1-63   characters long and comply with   [RFC1035](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1035.txt). Supported characters   include lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional textual description of the instance   group.
    description = ""

    # instances - (Optional) List of instances in the group. They should be given   as self_link URLs. When adding instances they must all be in the same   network and zone as the instance group.
    instances = ""

    # named_port - (Optional) The named port configuration. See the section below   for details on configuration.
    named_port = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # network - (Optional) The URL of the network the instance group is in. If   this is different from the network where the instances are in, the creation   fails. Defaults to the network where the instances are in (if neither   `network` nor `instances` is specified, this field will be blank).
    network = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "size" - The number of instances in the group.
}
google-compute-instance-group-x.description:
The Google Compute Engine Instance Group API creates and manages pools
of homogeneous Compute Engine virtual machine instances from a common instance
template. For more information, see [the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instance-groups/#unmanaged_instance_groups)
and [API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/instanceGroups)

google-compute-instance-template.body:
resource "google_compute_instance_template" "$1" {
    # scopes - (Required) A list of service scopes. Both OAuth2 URLs and gcloud   short names are supported.
    scopes = ""

    # network_interface - (Required) Networks to attach to instances created from   this template. This can be specified multiple times for multiple networks.   Structure is documented below.
    network_interface = ""

    # machine_type - (Required) The machine type to create.
    machine_type = ""

    # disk - (Required) Disks to attach to instances created from this template.   This can be specified multiple times for multiple disks. Structure is   documented below.
    disk = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the instance template. If you leave this blank, Terraform will auto-generate a unique name.
    name = ""

    # name_prefix - (Optional) Creates a unique name beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with `name`.
    name_prefix = ""

    # can_ip_forward - (Optional) Whether to allow sending and receiving of   packets with non-matching source or destination IPs. This defaults to false.
    can_ip_forward = ""

    # description - (Optional) A brief description of this resource.
    description = ""

    # instance_description - (Optional) A brief description to use for instances   created from this template.
    instance_description = ""

    # labels - (Optional) A set of key/value label pairs to assign to instances   created from this template,
    labels = ""

    # metadata - (Optional) Metadata key/value pairs to make available from   within instances created from this template.
    metadata = ""

    # metadata_startup_script - (Optional) An alternative to using the   startup-script metadata key, mostly to match the compute_instance resource.   This replaces the startup-script metadata key on the created instance and   thus the two mechanisms are not allowed to be used simultaneously.
    metadata_startup_script = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # region - (Optional) An instance template is a global resource that is not   bound to a zone or a region. However, you can still specify some regional   resources in an instance template, which restricts the template to the   region where that resource resides. For example, a custom `subnetwork`   resource is tied to a specific region. Defaults to the region of the   Provider if no value is given.
    region = ""

    # scheduling - (Optional) The scheduling strategy to use. More details about   this configuration option are detailed below.
    scheduling = ""

    # service_account - (Optional) Service account to attach to the instance. Structure is documented below.
    service_account = ""

    # tags - (Optional) Tags to attach to the instance.
    tags = ""

    # auto_delete - (Optional) Whether or not the disk should be auto-deleted.   This defaults to true.
    auto_delete = ""

    # boot - (Optional) Indicates that this is a boot disk.
    boot = ""

    # device_name - (Optional) A unique device name that is reflected into the   /dev/  tree of a Linux operating system running within the instance. If not   specified, the server chooses a default device name to apply to this disk.
    device_name = ""

    # disk_name - (Optional) Name of the disk. When not provided, this defaults   to the name of the instance.
    disk_name = ""

    # source_image - (Optional) (Required if source not set) The image from which to   initialize this disk. This can be one of: the image's `self_link`,   `projects/{project}/global/images/{image}`,   `projects/{project}/global/images/family/{family}`, `global/images/{image}`,   `global/images/family/{family}`, `family/{family}`, `{project}/{family}`,   `{project}/{image}`, `{family}`, or `{image}`.
    source_image = ""

    # interface - (Optional) Specifies the disk interface to use for attaching   this disk.
    interface = ""

    # mode - (Optional) The mode in which to attach this disk, either READ_WRITE   or READ_ONLY. If you are attaching or creating a boot disk, this must   read-write mode.
    mode = ""

    # source - (Optional) (Required if source_image not set) The name of the disk (such as   those managed by `google_compute_disk`) to attach.
    source = ""

    # disk_type - (Optional) The GCE disk type. Can be either `"pd-ssd"`,   `"local-ssd"`, or `"pd-standard"`.
    disk_type = ""

    # disk_size_gb - (Optional) The size of the image in gigabytes. If not   specified, it will inherit the size of its base image.
    disk_size_gb = ""

    # type - (Optional) The type of GCE disk, can be either `"SCRATCH"` or   `"PERSISTENT"`.
    type = ""

    # network - (Optional) The name or self_link of the network to attach this interface to.   Use `network` attribute for Legacy or Auto subnetted networks and   `subnetwork` for custom subnetted networks.
    network = ""

    # subnetwork - (Optional) the name of the subnetwork to attach this interface   to. The subnetwork must exist in the same `region` this instance will be   created in. Either `network` or `subnetwork` must be provided.
    subnetwork = ""

    # subnetwork_project - (Optional) The project in which the subnetwork belongs.   If it is not provided, the provider project is used.
    subnetwork_project = ""

    # access_config - (Optional) Access configurations, i.e. IPs via which this   instance can be accessed via the Internet. Omit to ensure that the instance   is not accessible from the Internet (this means that ssh provisioners will   not work unless you are running Terraform can send traffic to the instance's   network (e.g. via tunnel or because it is running on another cloud instance   on that network). This block can be repeated multiple times. Structure documented below.
    access_config = ""

    # nat_ip - (Optional) The IP address that will be 1:1 mapped to the instance's
    nat_ip = ""

    # access_config - (Optional) Access configurations, i.e. IPs via which this   instance can be accessed via the Internet. Omit to ensure that the instance   is not accessible from the Internet (this means that ssh provisioners will   not work unless you are running Terraform can send traffic to the instance's   network (e.g. via tunnel or because it is running on another cloud instance   on that network). This block can be repeated multiple times. Structure documented below.
    access_config = ""

    # email - (Optional) The service account e-mail address. If not given, the   default Google Compute Engine service account is used.
    email = ""

    # automatic_restart - (Optional) Specifies whether the instance should be   automatically restarted if it is terminated by Compute Engine (not   terminated by a user). This defaults to true.
    automatic_restart = ""

    # on_host_maintenance - (Optional) Defines the maintenance behavior for this   instance.
    on_host_maintenance = ""

    # preemptible - (Optional) Allows instance to be preempted. This defaults to   false. Read more on this   [here](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances/preemptible).
    preemptible = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "metadata_fingerprint" - The unique fingerprint of the metadata.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "tags_fingerprint" - The unique fingerprint of the tags.
}
google-compute-instance-template.description:
Manages a VM instance template resource within GCE. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instance-templates)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/instanceTemplates).

google-compute-instance-x.body:
resource "google_compute_instance" "$1" {
    # count - (Required) - The number of the guest accelerator cards exposed to this instance.
    count = ""

    # type - (Required) - The accelerator type resource to expose to this instance. E.g. `nvidia-tesla-k80`.
    type = ""

    # scopes - (Required) A list of service scopes. Both OAuth2 URLs and gcloud   short names are supported.
    scopes = ""

    # source - (Required) The name or self_link of the disk to attach to this instance.
    source = ""

    # network_interface - (Required) Networks to attach to the instance. This can   be specified multiple times. Structure is documented below.
    network_interface = ""

    # zone - (Required) The zone that the machine should be created in.
    zone = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # machine_type - (Required) The machine type to create. To create a custom   machine type, value should be set as specified   [here](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/instances#machineType)
    machine_type = ""

    # boot_disk - (Required) The boot disk for the instance.   Structure is documented below.
    boot_disk = ""

    # attached_disk - (Optional) List of disks to attach to the instance. Structure is documented below.
    attached_disk = ""

    # can_ip_forward - (Optional) Whether to allow sending and receiving of   packets with non-matching source or destination IPs.   This defaults to false.
    can_ip_forward = ""

    # create_timeout - (Optional) Configurable timeout in minutes for creating instances. Default is 4 minutes.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    create_timeout = ""

    # description - (Optional) A brief description of this resource.
    description = ""

    # labels - (Optional) A set of key/value label pairs to assign to the instance.
    labels = ""

    # metadata - (Optional) Metadata key/value pairs to make available from   within the instance.
    metadata = ""

    # metadata_startup_script - (Optional) An alternative to using the   startup-script metadata key, except this one forces the instance to be   recreated (thus re-running the script) if it is changed. This replaces the   startup-script metadata key on the created instance and thus the two   mechanisms are not allowed to be used simultaneously.
    metadata_startup_script = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # scheduling - (Optional) The scheduling strategy to use. More details about   this configuration option are detailed below.
    scheduling = ""

    # scratch_disk - (Optional) Scratch disks to attach to the instance. This can be   specified multiple times for multiple scratch disks. Structure is documented below.
    scratch_disk = ""

    # service_account - (Optional) Service account to attach to the instance.   Structure is documented below.
    service_account = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of tags to attach to the instance.
    tags = ""

    # auto_delete - (Optional) Whether the disk will be auto-deleted when the instance   is deleted. Defaults to true.
    auto_delete = ""

    # device_name - (Optional) Name with which attached disk will be accessible   under `/dev/disk/by-id/`
    device_name = ""

    # disk_encryption_key_raw - (Optional) A 256-bit [customer-supplied encryption key]   (https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/customer-supplied-encryption),   encoded in [RFC 4648 base64](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648#section-4)   to encrypt this disk.
    disk_encryption_key_raw = ""

    # initialize_params - (Optional) Parameters for a new disk that will be created   alongside the new instance. Either `initialize_params` or `source` must be set.   Structure is documented below.
    initialize_params = ""

    # source - (Optional) The name or self_link of the existing disk (such as those managed by   `google_compute_disk`) to attach.
    source = ""

    # size - (Optional) The size of the image in gigabytes. If not specified, it   will inherit the size of its base image.
    size = ""

    # type - (Optional) The GCE disk type. May be set to pd-standard or pd-ssd.
    type = ""

    # image - (Optional) The image from which to initialize this disk. This can be   one of: the image's `self_link`, `projects/{project}/global/images/{image}`,   `projects/{project}/global/images/family/{family}`, `global/images/{image}`,   `global/images/family/{family}`, `family/{family}`, `{project}/{family}`,   `{project}/{image}`, `{family}`, or `{image}`.
    image = ""

    # interface - (Optional) The disk interface to use for attaching this disk; either SCSI or NVME.
    interface = ""

    # image - (Optional) The image from which to initialize this disk. This can be   one of: the image's `self_link`, `projects/{project}/global/images/{image}`,   `projects/{project}/global/images/family/{family}`, `global/images/{image}`,   `global/images/family/{family}`, `family/{family}`, `{project}/{family}`,   `{project}/{image}`, `{family}`, or `{image}`.
    image = ""

    # device_name - (Optional) Name with which the attached disk will be accessible   under `/dev/disk/by-id/`
    device_name = ""

    # disk_encryption_key_raw - (Optional) A 256-bit [customer-supplied encryption key]   (https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/customer-supplied-encryption),   encoded in [RFC 4648 base64](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648#section-4)   to encrypt this disk.
    disk_encryption_key_raw = ""

    # network - (Optional) The name or self_link of the network to attach this interface to.   Either `network` or `subnetwork` must be provided.
    network = ""

    # subnetwork - (Optional) The name or self_link of the subnetwork to attach this  interface to. The subnetwork must exist in the same region this instance will be  created in. Either `network` or `subnetwork` must be provided.
    subnetwork = ""

    # subnetwork_project - (Optional) The project in which the subnetwork belongs. If the `subnetwork` is a self_link, this field is ignored in favor of the project defined in the subnetwork self_link. If the `subnetwork` is a name and this field is not provided, the provider project is used.
    subnetwork_project = ""

    # address - (Optional) The private IP address to assign to the instance. If   empty, the address will be automatically assigned.
    address = ""

    # access_config - (Optional) Access configurations, i.e. IPs via which this   instance can be accessed via the Internet. Omit to ensure that the instance   is not accessible from the Internet (this means that ssh provisioners will   not work unless you are running Terraform can send traffic to the instance's   network (e.g. via tunnel or because it is running on another cloud instance   on that network). This block can be repeated multiple times. Structure   documented below.
    access_config = ""

    # alias_ip_range - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) An   array of alias IP ranges for this network interface. Can only be specified for network   interfaces on subnet-mode networks. Structure documented below.
    alias_ip_range = ""

    # nat_ip - (Optional) The IP address that will be 1:1 mapped to the instance's
    nat_ip = ""

    # alias_ip_range - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) An   array of alias IP ranges for this network interface. Can only be specified for network   interfaces on subnet-mode networks. Structure documented below.
    alias_ip_range = ""

    # ip_cidr_range - (Optional) The IP CIDR range represented by this alias IP range. This IP CIDR range   must belong to the specified subnetwork and cannot contain IP addresses reserved by   system or used by other network interfaces. This range may be a single IP address   (e.g. 10.2.3.4), a netmask (e.g. /24) or a CIDR format string (e.g. 10.1.2.0/24).
    ip_cidr_range = ""

    # subnetwork_range_name - (Optional) The subnetwork secondary range name specifying   the secondary range from which to allocate the IP CIDR range for this alias IP   range. If left unspecified, the primary range of the subnetwork will be used.
    subnetwork_range_name = ""

    # email - (Optional) The service account e-mail address. If not given, the   default Google Compute Engine service account is used.
    email = ""

    # preemptible - (Optional) Is the instance preemptible.
    preemptible = ""

    # on_host_maintenance - (Optional) Describes maintenance behavior for the   instance. Can be MIGRATE or TERMINATE, for more info, read   [here](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances/setting-instance-scheduling-options)
    on_host_maintenance = ""

    # automatic_restart - (Optional) Specifies if the instance should be   restarted if it was terminated by Compute Engine (not a user).
    automatic_restart = ""

    # guest_accelerator - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) List of the type and count of accelerator cards attached to the instance. Structure documented below.
    guest_accelerator = ""

    # min_cpu_platform - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) Specifies a minimum CPU platform for the VM instance. Applicable values are the friendly names of CPU platforms, such as `Intel Haswell` or `Intel Skylake`. See the complete list [here](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances/specify-min-cpu-platform).
    min_cpu_platform = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "instance_id" - The server-assigned unique identifier of this instance.
    # "metadata_fingerprint" - The unique fingerprint of the metadata.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "tags_fingerprint" - The unique fingerprint of the tags.
    # "label_fingerprint" - The unique fingerprint of the labels.
    # "cpu_platform" - The CPU platform used by this instance.
    # "network_interface.0.address" - The internal ip address of the instance, either manually or dynamically assigned.
    # "network_interface.0.access_config.0.assigned_nat_ip" - If the instance has an access config, either the given external ip (in the "nat_ip" field) or the ephemeral (generated) ip (if you didn't provide one).
    # "attached_disk.0.disk_encryption_key_sha256" - The [RFC 4648 base64](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648#section-4)   encoded SHA-256 hash of the [customer-supplied encryption key]   (https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/customer-supplied-encryption) that protects this resource.
    # "boot_disk.disk_encryption_key_sha256" - The [RFC 4648 base64](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648#section-4)   encoded SHA-256 hash of the [customer-supplied encryption key]   (https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/customer-supplied-encryption) that protects this resource.
    # "disk.0.disk_encryption_key_sha256" - The [RFC 4648 base64](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648#section-4)   encoded SHA-256 hash of the [customer-supplied encryption key]   (https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/customer-supplied-encryption) that protects this resource.
}
google-compute-instance-x.description:
Manages a VM instance resource within GCE. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/instances).

google-compute-network-peering.body:
resource "google_compute_network_peering" "$1" {
    # peer_network - (Required) Resource link of the peer network.
    peer_network = ""

    # network - (Required) Resource link of the network to add a peering to.
    network = ""

    # name - (Required) Name of the peering.
    name = ""

    # auto_create_routes - (Optional) If set to `true`, the routes between the two networks will be created and managed automatically. Defaults to `true`.
    auto_create_routes = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "state" - State for the peering.
    # "state_details" - Details about the current state of the peering.
}
google-compute-network-peering.description:
Manages a network peering within GCE. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/vpc/vpc-peering)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/networks). ~> **Note:** Both network must create a peering with each other for the peering to be functional. ~> **Note:** Subnets IP ranges across peered VPC networks cannot overlap.

google-compute-network-x.body:

    auto_create_subnetworks = ""

    # description - (Optional) A brief description of this resource.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "gateway_ipv4" - The IPv4 address of the gateway.
    # "name" - The unique name of the network.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-network-x.description:
Manages a network within GCE. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/vpc)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/networks).

google-compute-project-metadata.description:
Manages metadata common to all instances for a project in GCE. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/storing-retrieving-metadata)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/projects/setCommonInstanceMetadata). ~> **Note:**  If you want to manage only single key/value pairs within the project metadata 
rather than the entire set, then use 
[google_compute_project_metadata_item](compute_project_metadata_item.html).

google-compute-project-metadata-item.description:
Manages a single key/value pair on metadata common to all instances for
a project in GCE. Using `google_compute_project_metadata_item` lets you
manage a single key/value setting in Terraform rather than the entire
project metadata map.

google-compute-region-autoscaler.body:
resource "google_compute_region_autoscaler" "$1" {
    # min_replicas - (Required) The group will never be smaller than this.
    min_replicas = ""

    # max_replicas - (Required) The group will never be larger than this.
    max_replicas = ""

    # autoscaling_policy - (Required) The parameters of the autoscaling algorithm. Structure is documented below.
    autoscaling_policy = ""

    # region - (Required) The region of the target.
    region = ""

    # target - (Required) The full URL to the instance group manager whose size we control.
    target = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the autoscaler.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional textual description of the instance   group manager.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # cooldown_period - (Optional) Period to wait between changes. This should be at least double the time your instances take to start up.
    cooldown_period = ""

    # cpu_utilization - (Optional) A policy that scales when the cluster's average CPU is above or below a given threshold. Structure is documented below.
    cpu_utilization = ""

    # metric - (Optional) A policy that scales according to Google Cloud Monitoring metrics  Structure is documented below.
    metric = ""

    # load_balancing_utilization - (Optional) A policy that scales when the load reaches a proportion of a limit defined in the HTTP load balancer. Structure is documented below.
    load_balancing_utilization = ""

    # target - (Optional) The floating point threshold where CPU utilization should be. E.g.
    target = ""

    # load_balancing_utilization - (Optional) A policy that scales when the load reaches a proportion of a limit defined in the HTTP load balancer. Structure is documented below.
    load_balancing_utilization = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the Google Cloud Monitoring metric to follow, e.g. `compute.googleapis.com/instance/network/received_bytes_count`
    name = ""

    # type - (Optional) Either "cumulative", "delta", or "gauge".
    type = ""

    # target - (Optional) The desired metric value per instance. Must be a positive value.
    target = ""

    # target - (Optional) The floating point threshold where load balancing utilization
    target = ""

    # target - (Optional) The desired metric value per instance. Must be a positive value.
    target = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URL of the created resource.
    # "target" - The desired metric value per instance. Must be a positive value.
}
google-compute-region-autoscaler.description:
A Compute Engine Regional Autoscaler automatically adds or removes virtual machines from
a managed instance group based on increases or decreases in load. This allows
your applications to gracefully handle increases in traffic and reduces cost
when the need for resources is lower. You just define the autoscaling policy and
the autoscaler performs automatic scaling based on the measured load. For more
information, see [the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/autoscaler/) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/regionAutoscalers)

google-compute-region-backend-service.body:
resource "google_compute_region_backend_service" "$1" {
    # group - (Required) The name or URI of a Compute Engine instance group   (`google_compute_region_instance_group_manager.xyz.instance_group`) that can   receive traffic. Instance groups must contain at least one instance.
    group = ""

    # health_checks - (Required) Specifies a list of health checks   for checking the health of the backend service. Currently at most   one health check can be specified, and a health check is required.
    health_checks = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the backend service.
    name = ""

    # backend - (Optional) The list of backends that serve this BackendService.   Structure is documented below.
    backend = ""

    # description - (Optional) The textual description for the backend service.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # protocol - (Optional) The protocol for incoming requests. Defaults to   `HTTP`.
    protocol = ""

    # session_affinity - (Optional) How to distribute load. Options are `NONE` (no   affinity), `CLIENT_IP`, `CLIENT_IP_PROTO`, or `CLIENT_IP_PORT_PROTO`.   Defaults to `NONE`.
    session_affinity = ""

    # region - (Optional) The Region in which the created address should reside.   If it is not provided, the provider region is used.
    region = ""

    # timeout_sec - (Optional) The number of secs to wait for a backend to respond   to a request before considering the request failed. Defaults to `30`.
    timeout_sec = ""

    # connection_draining_timeout_sec - (Optional) Time for which instance will be drained (not accept new connections, but still work to finish started ones). Defaults to `0`.
    connection_draining_timeout_sec = ""

    # description - (Optional) Textual description for the backend.
    description = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "fingerprint" - The fingerprint of the backend service.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-region-backend-service.description:
A Region Backend Service defines a regionally-scoped group of virtual machines that will serve traffic for load balancing.
For more information see [the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/internal/) 
and [API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/backendServices).

google-compute-region_instance-group-man.body:
resource "google_compute_region_instance_group_manager" "$1" {
    # initial_delay_sec - (Required) The number of seconds that the managed instance group waits before it applies autohealing policies to new instances or recently recreated instances. Between 0 and 3600.
    initial_delay_sec = ""

    # health_check - (Required) The health check resource that signals autohealing.
    health_check = ""

    # port - (Required) The port number.
    port = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the port.
    name = ""

    # region - (Required) The region where the managed instance group resides.
    region = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the instance group manager. Must be 1-63   characters long and comply with   [RFC1035](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1035.txt). Supported characters   include lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens.
    name = ""

    # instance_template - (Required) The full URL to an instance template from   which all new instances will be created.
    instance_template = ""

    # base_instance_name - (Required) The base instance name to use for   instances in this group. The value must be a valid   [RFC1035](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1035.txt) name. Supported characters   are lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens (-). Instances are named by   appending a hyphen and a random four-character string to the base instance   name.
    base_instance_name = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional textual description of the instance   group manager.
    description = ""

    # named_port - (Optional) The named port configuration. See the section below   for details on configuration.
    named_port = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # target_size - (Optional) The target number of running instances for this managed   instance group. This value should always be explicitly set unless this resource is attached to    an autoscaler, in which case it should never be set. Defaults to `0`.
    target_size = ""

    # target_pools - (Optional) The full URL of all target pools to which new   instances in the group are added. Updating the target pools attribute does   not affect existing instances.
    target_pools = ""

    # auto_healing_policies - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) The autohealing policies for this managed instance
    auto_healing_policies = ""

    # target_pools - (Optional) The full URL of all target pools to which new   instances in the group are added. Updating the target pools attribute does   not affect existing instances.
    target_pools = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "fingerprint" - The fingerprint of the instance group manager.
    # "instance_group" - The full URL of the instance group created by the manager.
    # "self_link" - The URL of the created resource.
}
google-compute-region_instance-group-man.description:
The Google Compute Engine Regional Instance Group Manager API creates and manages pools
of homogeneous Compute Engine virtual machine instances from a common instance
template. For more information, see [the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instance-groups/distributing-instances-with-regional-instance-groups)
and [API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/regionInstanceGroupManagers) ~> **Note:** Use [google_compute_instance_group_manager](/docs/providers/google/r/compute_instance_group_manager.html) to create a single-zone instance group manager.

google-compute-route-x.body:
resource "google_compute_route" "$1" {
    # priority - (Required) The priority of this route, used to break ties.
    priority = ""

    # network - (Required) The name or self_link of the network to attach this route to.
    network = ""

    # dest_range - (Required) The destination IPv4 address range that this   route applies to.
    dest_range = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # next_hop_gateway - (Optional) The URL of the internet gateway to route   to if this route is matched. The alias "default-internet-gateway" can also   be used.
    next_hop_gateway = ""

    # next_hop_instance - (Optional) The name of the VM instance to route to   if this route is matched.
    next_hop_instance = ""

    # next_hop_instance_zone - (Optional) (Required when `next_hop_instance` is specified)   The zone of the instance specified in `next_hop_instance`.
    next_hop_instance_zone = ""

    # next_hop_ip - (Optional) The IP address of the next hop if this route   is matched.
    next_hop_ip = ""

    # next_hop_vpn_tunnel - (Optional) The name of the VPN to route to if this   route is matched.
    next_hop_vpn_tunnel = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # tags - (Optional) The tags that this route applies to.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "next_hop_network" - The name of the next hop network, if available.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}

google-compute-router-x.description:
Manages a Cloud Router resource. For more information see

and

google-compute-shared-vpc-host-project.body:
resource "google_compute_shared_vpc_host_project" "$1" {

google-compute-shared-vpc-host-project.description:
Allows enabling and disabling Shared VPC for the host Google Cloud Platform project. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/shared-vpc)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/projects).

google-compute-shared-vpc-service-projec.description:
Allows enabling and disabling Shared VPC for a service Google Cloud Platform project. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/shared-vpc)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/projects).

google-compute-snapshot.body:
resource "google_compute_snapshot" "$1" {
    # source_disk - (Required) The disk which will be used as the source of the snapshot.
    source_disk = ""

    # zone - (Required) The zone where the source disk is located.
    zone = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # source_disk_encryption_key_raw - (Optional) A 256-bit [customer-supplied encryption key]   (https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/customer-supplied-encryption),   encoded in [RFC 4648 base64](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648#section-4)   to decrypt the source disk.
    source_disk_encryption_key_raw = ""

    # snapshot_encryption_key_raw - (Optional) A 256-bit [customer-supplied encryption key]   (https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/customer-supplied-encryption),   encoded in [RFC 4648 base64](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648#section-4)   to encrypt this snapshot.
    snapshot_encryption_key_raw = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # labels - (Optional) A set of key/value label pairs to assign to the snapshot. ## Attributes Reference
    labels = ""

    # source_disk_link - (Optional) The URI of the source disk.
    source_disk_link = ""

    # self_link - (Optional) The URI of the created resource.
    self_link = ""

    # label_fingerprint - (Optional) The unique fingerprint of the labels.
    label_fingerprint = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
google-compute-snapshot.description:
Creates a new snapshot of a disk within GCE. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/create-snapshots)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/snapshots).

google-compute-ssl-certificate.body:
resource "google_compute_ssl_certificate" "$1" {
    # private_key - (Required) Write only private key in PEM format.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    private_key = ""

    # certificate - (Required) A local certificate file in PEM format. The chain   may be at most 5 certs long, and must include at least one intermediate   cert. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    certificate = ""

    # name - (Optional) A unique name for the SSL certificate. If you leave this blank, Terraform will auto-generate a unique name.
    name = ""

    # name_prefix - (Optional) Creates a unique name beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with `name`.
    name_prefix = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional description of this resource.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "certificate_id" - A unique ID for the certificate, assigned by GCE.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-ssl-certificate.description:
Creates an SSL certificate resource necessary for HTTPS load balancing in GCE.
For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/http/ssl-certificates) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/sslCertificates).

google-compute-subnetwork.body:
resource "google_compute_subnetwork" "$1" {
    # ip_cidr_range - (Required) The range of IP addresses belonging to this subnetwork secondary range. Ranges must be unique and non-overlapping with all primary and secondary IP ranges within a network. 
    ip_cidr_range = ""

    # range_name - (Required) The name associated with this subnetwork secondary range, used when adding an alias IP range to a VM instance.
    range_name = ""

    # network - (Required) The network name or resource link to the parent   network of this subnetwork. The parent network must have been created   in custom subnet mode.
    network = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # ip_cidr_range - (Required) The IP address range that machines in this   network are assigned to, represented as a CIDR block.
    ip_cidr_range = ""

    # description - (Optional) Description of this subnetwork.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region this subnetwork will be created in. If   unspecified, this defaults to the region configured in the provider.
    region = ""

    # private_ip_google_access - (Optional) Whether the VMs in this subnet   can access Google services without assigned external IP   addresses.
    private_ip_google_access = ""

    # secondary_ip_range - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) An array of configurations for secondary IP ranges for VM instances contained in this subnetwork. Structure is documented below.
    secondary_ip_range = ""

    # private_ip_google_access - (Optional) Whether the VMs in this subnet   can access Google services without assigned external IP   addresses.
    private_ip_google_access = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "gateway_address" - The IP address of the gateway.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-subnetwork.description:
Manages a subnetwork within GCE. For more information see 
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/vpc/#vpc_networks_and_subnets)
and 
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/subnetworks).

google-compute-target-http-proxy.body:
resource "google_compute_target_http_proxy" "$1" {
    # url_map - (Required) The URL of a URL Map resource that defines the mapping   from the URL to the BackendService.
    url_map = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of this resource. Changing this
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "proxy_id" - A unique ID assigned by GCE.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-target-http-proxy.description:
Creates a target HTTP proxy resource in GCE. For more information see
[the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/http/target-proxies) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/targetHttpProxies).

google-compute-target-https-proxy.body:
resource "google_compute_target_https_proxy" "$1" {
    # url_map - (Required) The URL of a URL Map resource that defines the mapping   from the URL to the BackendService.
    url_map = ""

    # ssl_certificates - (Required) The URLs of the SSL Certificate resources that   authenticate connections between users and load balancing.
    ssl_certificates = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of this resource. Changing this   forces a new resource to be created.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "proxy_id" - A unique ID assigned by GCE.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-target-https-proxy.description:
Creates a target HTTPS proxy resource in GCE. For more information see
[the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/http/target-proxies) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/targetHttpsProxies).

google-compute-target-pool.body:
resource "google_compute_target_pool" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing
    name = ""

    # backup_pool - (Optional) URL to the backup target pool. Must also set   failover\_ratio.
    backup_pool = ""

    # description - (Optional) Textual description field.
    description = ""

    # failover_ratio - (Optional) Ratio (0 to 1) of failed nodes before using the   backup pool (which must also be set).
    failover_ratio = ""

    # health_checks - (Optional) List of zero or one health check name or self_link. Only   legacy `google_compute_http_health_check` is supported.
    health_checks = ""

    # instances - (Optional) List of instances in the pool. They can be given as   URLs, or in the form of "zone/name". Note that the instances need not exist   at the time of target pool creation, so there is no need to use the   Terraform interpolators to create a dependency on the instances from the   target pool.
    instances = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # region - (Optional) Where the target pool resides. Defaults to project   region.
    region = ""

    # session_affinity - (Optional) How to distribute load. Options are "NONE" (no   affinity). "CLIENT\_IP" (hash of the source/dest addresses / ports), and   "CLIENT\_IP\_PROTO" also includes the protocol (default "NONE").
    session_affinity = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "session_affinity" - (Optional) How to distribute load. Options are "NONE" (no   affinity). "CLIENT\_IP" (hash of the source/dest addresses / ports), and   "CLIENT\_IP\_PROTO" also includes the protocol (default "NONE").
}
google-compute-target-pool.description:
Manages a Target Pool within GCE. This is a collection of instances used as
target of a network load balancer (Forwarding Rule). For more information see
[the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/network/target-pools)
and [API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/targetPools).

google-compute-target-ssl-proxy.body:
resource "google_compute_target_ssl_proxy" "$1" {
    # ssl_certificates - (Required) The URLs of the SSL Certificate resources that   authenticate connections between users and load balancing.
    ssl_certificates = ""

    # backend_service - (Required) The URL of a Backend Service resource to receive the matched traffic.
    backend_service = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # proxy_header - (Optional) Type of proxy header to append before sending   data to the backend, either NONE or PROXY_V1 (default NONE).
    proxy_header = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of this resource. Changing this   forces a new resource to be created.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "proxy_id" - A unique ID assigned by GCE.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-target-ssl-proxy.description:
Creates a target SSL proxy resource in GCE. For more information see
[the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/ssl-ssl/) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/targetSslProxies).

google-compute-target-tcp-proxy.description:
