}
heroku-resource-space.description: Provides a Heroku Space resource for running apps in isolated, highly available, secure app execution environments.

ignition-datasource-config.body:
data "ignition_config" "$1" {
    # source - (Required) The URL of the config. Supported schemes are http. Note: When using http, it is advisable to use the verification option to ensure the contents haven’t been modified.
    source = ""

    # disks - (Optional) The list of disks to be configured and their options.
    disks = ""

    # arrays - (Optional) The list of RAID arrays to be configured.
    arrays = ""

    # filesystems - (Optional) The list of filesystems to be configured and/or used in the _ignition_file_ resource.
    filesystems = ""

    # files - (Optional) The list of files, rooted in this particular filesystem, to be written.
    files = ""

    # systemd - (Optional) The list of systemd units. Describes the desired state of the systemd units.
    systemd = ""

    # networkd - (Optional) The list of networkd units. Describes the desired state of the networkd files.
    networkd = ""

    # users - (Optional) The list of accounts to be added.
    users = ""

    # groups - (Optional) The list of groups to be added.
    groups = ""

    # append - (Optional) Any number of blocks with the configs to be appended to the current config.
    append = ""

    # replace - (Optional) A block with config that will replace the current.
    replace = ""

    # verification - (Optional) The hash of the config, in the form _\<type\>-\<value\>_ where type is sha512.
    verification = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "rendered" - The final rendered template.
    # "verification" - (Optional) The hash of the config, in the form _\<type\>-\<value\>_ where type is sha512.
}
ignition-datasource-config.description: Renders an ignition configuration as JSON. It  contains all the disks, partitions, arrays, filesystems, files, users, groups and units.

ignition-datasource-directory.body:
data "ignition_directory" "$1" {
    # path - (Required) The absolute path to the directory.
    path = ""

    # filesystem - (Required) The internal identifier of the filesystem. This matches the last filesystem with the given identifier. This should be a valid name from a _ignition\_filesystem_ resource.
    filesystem = ""

    # mode - (Optional) The list of partitions and their configuration for this particular disk..
    mode = ""

    # uid - (Optional) The user ID of the owner.
    uid = ""

    # gid - (Optional) The group ID of the owner.
    gid = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID used to reference this resource in _ignition_config_.
    # "gid" - (Optional) The group ID of the owner.
}
ignition-datasource-directory.description: Describes a directory to be created in a particular filesystem.

ignition-datasource-disk.body:
data "ignition_disk" "$1" {
    # device - (Required) The absolute path to the device. Devices are typically referenced by the _/dev/disk/by-*_ symlinks.
    device = ""

    # wipe_table - (Optional) Whether or not the partition tables shall be wiped. When true, the partition tables are erased before any further manipulation. Otherwise, the existing entries are left intact.
    wipe_table = ""

    # partition - (Optional) The list of partitions and their configuration for this particular disk..
    partition = ""

    # label - (Optional) The PARTLABEL for the partition.
    label = ""

    # number - (Optional) The partition number, which dictates it’s position in the partition table (one-indexed). If zero, use the next available partition slot.
    number = ""

    # size - (Optional) The size of the partition (in sectors). If zero, the partition will fill the remainder of the disk.
    size = ""

    # start - (Optional) The start of the partition (in sectors). If zero, the partition will be positioned at the earliest available part of the disk.
    start = ""

    # size - (Optional) The size of the partition (in sectors). If zero, the partition will fill the remainder of the disk.
    size = ""

    # type_guid - (Optional) The GPT [partition type GUID](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GUID_Partition_Table#Partition_type_GUIDs). If omitted, the default will be _0FC63DAF-8483-4772-8E79-3D69D8477DE4_ (Linux filesystem data).
    type_guid = ""

    # size - (Optional) The size of the partition (in sectors). If zero, the partition will fill the remainder of the disk.
    size = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID used to reference this resource in _ignition_config_.
    # "size" - (Optional) The size of the partition (in sectors). If zero, the partition will fill the remainder of the disk.
}
ignition-datasource-disk.description: Describes the desired state of a system’s disk.

ignition-datasource-file.body:
data "ignition_file" "$1" {
    # source - (Required) The URL of the file contents. Supported schemes are http, https, tftp, s3, and [data][rfc2397]. When using http, it is advisable to use the verification option to ensure the contents haven't been modified.
    source = ""

    # content - (Required) Content of the file.
    content = ""

    # mime - (Required) MIME format of the content (default _text/plain_).
    mime = ""

    # filesystem - (Optional) The internal identifier of the filesystem. This matches the last filesystem with the given identifier. This should be a valid name from a _ignition\_filesystem_ resource.
    filesystem = ""

    # path - (Optional) The absolute path to the file.
    path = ""

    # content - (Optional) Block to provide the file content inline.
    content = ""

    # source - (Optional) Block to retrieve the file content from a remote location.
    source = ""

    # mode - (Optional) The list of partitions and their configuration for this particular disk..
    mode = ""

    # uid - (Optional) The user ID of the owner.
    uid = ""

    # gid - (Optional) The group ID of the owner.
    gid = ""

    # compression - (Optional) The type of compression used on the contents (null or gzip). Compression cannot be used with S3.
    compression = ""

    # verification - (Optional) The hash of the config, in the form _\<type\>-\<value\>_ where type is sha512.
    verification = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID used to reference this resource in _ignition_config_.
    # "verification" - (Optional) The hash of the config, in the form _\<type\>-\<value\>_ where type is sha512.
}
ignition-datasource-file.description: Describes a file to be written in a particular filesystem.

ignition-datasource-filesystem.body:
data "ignition_filesystem" "$1" {
    # format - (Required) The filesystem format (ext4, btrfs, xfs, vfat, or swap).
    format = ""

    # device - (Required) The absolute path to the device. Devices are typically referenced by the _/dev/disk/by-*_ symlinks.
    device = ""

    # name - (Optional) The identifier for the filesystem, internal to Ignition. This is only required if the filesystem needs to be referenced in the a _ignition\_files_ resource.
    name = ""

    # mount - (Optional) Contains the set of mount and formatting options for the filesystem. A non-null entry indicates that the filesystem should be mounted before it is used by Ignition.
    mount = ""

    # path - (Optional) The mount-point of the filesystem. A non-null entry indicates that the filesystem has already been mounted by the system at the specified path. This is really only useful for _/sysroot_.
    path = ""

    # wipe_filesystem - (Optional)  Whether or not to wipe the device before filesystem creation.
    wipe_filesystem = ""

    # label - (Optional) The label of the filesystem.
    label = ""

    # uuid - (Optional) The uuid of the filesystem.
    uuid = ""

    # options - (Optional) Any additional options to be passed to the format-specific mkfs utility.
    options = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID used to reference this resource in _ignition_config_.
    # "options" - (Optional) Any additional options to be passed to the format-specific mkfs utility.
}
ignition-datasource-filesystem.description: Describes the desired state of a the system’s filesystems to be configured and/or used with the _ignition\_file_ resource.

ignition-datasource-group.body:
data "ignition_group" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The groupname for the account.
    name = ""

    # password_hash - (Optional) The encrypted password for the account.
    password_hash = ""

    # gid - (Optional) The group ID of the new account.
    gid = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID used to reference this resource in _ignition_config_.
    # "gid" - (Optional) The group ID of the new account.
}
ignition-datasource-group.description: Describes the desired group additions to the passwd database.

ignition-datasource-link.body:
data "ignition_link" "$1" {
    # target - (Required) The target path of the link.
    target = ""

    # path - (Required) The absolute path to the link.
    path = ""

    # filesystem - (Required) The internal identifier of the filesystem. This matches the last filesystem with the given identifier. This should be a valid name from a _ignition\_filesystem_ resource.
    filesystem = ""

    # hard - (Optional) A symbolic link is created if this is false, a hard one if this is true.
    hard = ""

    # uid - (Optional) The user ID of the owner.
    uid = ""

    # gid - (Optional) The group ID of the owner.
    gid = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID used to reference this resource in _ignition_config_.
    # "gid" - (Optional) The group ID of the owner.
}
ignition-datasource-link.description: Describes a link to be created in a particular filesystem.

ignition-datasource-networkd-unit.body:
data "ignition_networkd_unit" "$1" {
    # content - (Required) The contents of the networkd file.
    content = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the file. This must be suffixed with a valid unit type (e.g. _00-eth0.network_).
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID used to reference this resource in _ignition_config_.
    # "content" - (Required) The contents of the networkd file.
}
ignition-datasource-networkd-unit.description: Describes the desired state of the networkd units.

ignition-datasource-raid.body:
data "ignition_raid" "$1" {
    # devices - (Required) The list of devices (referenced by their absolute path) in the array.
    devices = ""

    # level - (Required) The redundancy level of the array (e.g. linear, raid1, raid5, etc.).
    level = ""

    # name - (Required) The name to use for the resulting md device.
    name = ""

    # spares - (Optional) The number of spares (if applicable) in the array.
    spares = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID used to reference this resource in _ignition_config_
    # "spares" - (Optional) The number of spares (if applicable) in the array.
}
ignition-datasource-raid.description: Describes the desired state of the system’s RAID.

ignition-datasource-systemd-unit.body:
data "ignition_systemd_unit" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the drop-in. This must be suffixed with _.conf_.
    name = ""

    # name - (Required) Tthe name of the unit. This must be suffixed with a valid unit type (e.g. _thing.service_).
    name = ""

    # enabled - (Optional) Whether or not the service shall be enabled. When true, the service is enabled. In order for this to have any effect, the unit must have an install section. (default true)
    enabled = ""

    # mask - (Optional) Whether or not the service shall be masked. When true, the service is masked by symlinking it to _/dev/null_.
    mask = ""

    # content - (Optional) The contents of the unit.
    content = ""

    # dropin - (Optional) The list of drop-ins for the unit.
    dropin = ""

    # content - (Optional) The contents of the drop-in.
    content = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID used to reference this resource in _ignition_config_.
    # "content" - (Optional) The contents of the drop-in.
}
ignition-datasource-systemd-unit.description: Describes the desired state of the systemd units.

ignition-datasource-user.body:
data "ignition_user" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The username for the account.
    name = ""

    # password_hash - (Optional) The encrypted password for the account.
    password_hash = ""

    # ssh_authorized_keys - (Optional) A list of SSH keys to be added to the user’s authorized_keys.
    ssh_authorized_keys = ""

    # uid - (Optional) The user ID of the new account.
    uid = ""

    # gecos - (Optional) The GECOS field of the new account.
    gecos = ""

    # home_dir - (Optional) The home directory of the new account.
    home_dir = ""

    # no_create_home - (Optional) Whether or not to create the user’s home directory.
    no_create_home = ""

    # primary_group - (Optional) The name or ID of the primary group of the new account.
    primary_group = ""

    # groups - (Optional) The list of supplementary groups of the new account.
    groups = ""

    # no_user_group - (Optional) Whether or not to create a group with the same name as the user.
    no_user_group = ""

    # no_log_init - (Optional) Whether or not to add the user to the lastlog and faillog databases.
    no_log_init = ""

    # shell - (Optional) The login shell of the new account.
    shell = ""

    # system - (Optional) Whether or not to make the account a system account. This only has an effect if the account doesn't exist yet.
    system = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID used to reference this resource in _ignition_config_.
    # "system" - (Optional) Whether or not to make the account a system account. This only has an effect if the account doesn't exist yet.
}
ignition-datasource-user.description: Describes the desired user additions to the passwd database.

influxdb-resource-continuous_query.body:
resource "influxdb_continuous_query" "$1" {
    # query - (Required) The query for the continuous_query. 
    query = ""

    # database - (Required) The database for the continuous_query. This must be an existing influxdb database.
    database = ""

    # name - (Required) The name for the continuous_query. This must be unique on the InfluxDB server.
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
influxdb-resource-continuous_query.description: The continuous_query resource allows a continuous query to be created on an InfluxDB server.

influxdb-resource-database.description: The database resource allows a database to be created on an InfluxDB server.

influxdb-resource-user.body:
resource "influxdb_user" "$1" {
    # privilege - (Required) The privilege to grant (READ|WRITE|ALL)
    privilege = ""

    # database - (Required) The name of the database the privilege is associated with
    database = ""

    # password - (Required) The password for the user. 
    password = ""

    # name - (Required) The name for the user. 
    name = ""

    # admin - (Optional) Mark the user as admin.
    admin = ""

    # grant - (Optional) A list of grants for non-admin users
    grant = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "admin" - (Bool) indication if the user is an admin or not.
}
influxdb-resource-user.description: The user resource allows a user to be created on an InfluxDB server.

librato-resource-alert.body:
resource "librato_alert" "$1" {
    # description - (Required) Description of the alert.
    description = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the alert.
    name = ""

    # active - (Optional) whether the alert is active (can be triggered). Defaults to true.
    active = ""

    # rearm_seconds - (Optional) minimum amount of time between sending alert notifications, in seconds.
    rearm_seconds = ""

    # services - (Optional) list of notification service IDs.
    services = ""

    # condition - (Optional) A trigger condition for the alert. Conditions documented below.
    condition = ""

    # attributes - (Optional) A hash of additional attribtues for the alert. Attributes documented below.
    attributes = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the alert.
    # "name" - The name of the alert.
    # "description" - (Required) Description of the alert.
    # "active" - whether the alert is active (can be triggered). Defaults to true.
    # "rearm_seconds" - minimum amount of time between sending alert notifications, in seconds.
    # "services" - list of notification service IDs.
    # "condition" - A trigger condition for the alert. Conditions documented below.
    # "type" - The type of condition. Must be one of "above", "below" or "absent".
    # "metric_name"- The name of the metric this alert condition applies to.
    # "source"- A source expression which identifies which sources for the given metric to monitor.
    # "detect_reset" - boolean: toggles the method used to calculate the delta from the previous sample when the summary_function is "derivative".
    # "duration" - number of seconds condition must be true to fire the alert (required for type "absent").
    # "threshold" - float: measurements over this number will fire the alert (only for "above" or "below").
    # "summary_function" - Indicates which statistic of an aggregated measurement to alert on. ((only for "above" or "below").
    # "runbook_url" - a URL for the runbook to be followed when this alert is firing. Used in the Librato UI if set.
}
librato-resource-alert.description:
Provides a Librato Alert resource. This can be used to
create and manage alerts on Librato.

librato-resource-metric.body:
resource "librato_metric" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The unique identifier of the metric.
    name = ""

    # type - (Required) The type of metric to create (gauge, counter, or composite).
    type = ""

    # display_name - (Optional) The name which will be used for the metric when viewing the Metrics website.
    display_name = ""

    # description - (Optional) Text that can be used to explain precisely what the metric is measuring.
    description = ""

    # period - (Optional) Number of seconds that is the standard reporting period of the metric.
    period = ""

    # attributes - (Optional) The attributes hash configures specific components of a metric’s visualization.
    attributes = ""

    # composite - (Optional) The definition of the composite metric.
    composite = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "name" - The identifier for the metric.
    # "display_name" - The name which will be used for the metric when viewing the Metrics website.
    # "type" - The type of metric to create (gauge, counter, or composite).
    # "description" - Text that describes precisely what the metric is measuring.
    # "period" - Number of seconds that is the standard reporting period of the metric. Setting the period enables Metrics to detect abnormal interruptions in reporting and aids in analytics. For gauge metrics that have service-side aggregation enabled, this option will define the period that aggregation occurs on.
    # "source_lag" -
    # "composite" - The composite definition. Only used when type is composite.
    # "color" - Sets a default color to prefer when visually rendering the metric. Must be a seven character string that represents the hex code of the color e.g. #52D74C.
    # "display_max" - If a metric has a known theoretical maximum value, set display_max so that visualizations can provide perspective of the current values relative to the maximum value.
    # "display_min" - If a metric has a known theoretical minimum value, set display_min so that visualizations can provide perspective of the current values relative to the minimum value.
    # "display_units_long" - A string that identifies the unit of measurement e.g. Microseconds. Typically the long form of display_units_short and used in visualizations e.g. the Y-axis label on a graph.
    # "display_units_short" -	A terse (usually abbreviated) string that identifies the unit of measurement e.g. uS (Microseconds). Typically the short form of display_units_long and used in visualizations e.g. the tooltip for a point on a graph.
    # "display_stacked" -	A boolean value indicating whether or not multiple metric streams should be aggregated in a visualization (e.g. stacked graphs). By default counters have display_stacked enabled while gauges have it disabled.
    # "summarize_function" -	Determines how to calculate values when rolling up from raw values to higher resolution intervals. Must be one of: ‘average’, 'sum’, 'count’, 'min’, 'max’. If summarize_function is not set the behavior defaults to average.
    # "aggregate"	- Enable service-side aggregation for this metric. When enabled, measurements sent using the same tag set will be aggregated into single measurements on an interval defined by the period of the metric. If there is no period defined for the metric then all measurements will be aggregated on a 60-second interval.
}
librato-resource-metric.description: Provides a Librato Metric resource. This can be used to create and manage metrics on Librato.

    group_function = ""

    summary_function = ""

    name = ""

    color = ""

    units_short = ""

    units_long = ""

    min = ""

librato-resource-space-chart.description:
Provides a Librato Space Chart resource. This can be used to

local-resource-file.body:
resource "local_file" "$1" {
    # filename - (Required) The path of the file to create.
    filename = ""

    # content - (Required) The content of file to create.
    content = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
local-resource-file.description:
Generates a local file with the given content. ~> **Note** When working with local files, Terraform will detect the resource
as having been deleted each time a configuration is applied on a new machine
where the file is not present and will generate a diff to re-create it. This
may cause "noise" in diffs in environments where configurations are routinely
applied by many different users or within automation systems.

logentries-log.body:
resource "logentries_log" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the log. The name should be short and descriptive. For example, Apache Access, Hadoop Namenode.
    name = ""

    # logset_id - (Required) The id of the `logentries_logset` resource.
    logset_id = ""

    # retention_period - (Optional) (Optional, default `ACCOUNT_DEFAULT`) The retention period (`1W`, `2W`, `1M`, `2M`, `6M`, `1Y`, `2Y`, `UNLIMITED`, `ACCOUNT_DEFAULT`)
    retention_period = ""

    # source - (Optional) (Optional, default `token`) The log source (`token`, `syslog`, `agent`, `api`). Review the Logentries [log inputs documentation](https://docs.logentries.com/docs/) for more information.
    source = ""

    # type - (Optional) The log type. See the Logentries [log type documentation](https://logentries.com/doc/log-types/) for more information.
    type = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "token" - If the log "source" is "token", this value holds the generated log token that is used by logging clients. See the Logentries [token-based input documentation](https://logentries.com/doc/input-token/) for more information.
}

logentries-logset.body:
resource "logentries_logset" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The log set name, which should be short and descriptive. For example, www, db1.
    name = ""

    # location - (Optional) (Optional, default "nonlocation") A location is for your convenience only. You can specify a DNS entry such as web.example.com, IP address or arbitrary comment.
    location = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
logentries-logset.description: Provides a Logentries logset resource. A logset is a collection of `logentries_log` resources.

mysql-resource-database.body:
resource "mysql_database" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the database. This must be unique within a given MySQL server and may or may not be case-sensitive depending on the operating system on which the MySQL server is running.
    name = ""

    # default_character_set - (Optional) The default character set to use when a table is created without specifying an explicit character set. Defaults to "utf8".
    default_character_set = ""

    # default_collation - (Optional) The default collation to use when a table is created without specifying an explicit collation. Defaults to ``utf8_general_ci``. Each character set has its own set of collations, so changing the character set requires also changing the collation.
    default_collation = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
mysql-resource-database.description:
The ``mysql_database`` resource creates and manages a database on a MySQL
server. ~> **Caution:** The ``mysql_database`` resource can completely delete your
database just as easily as it can create it. To avoid costly accidents,
consider setting
[``prevent_destroy``](/docs/configuration/resources.html#prevent_destroy)
on your database resources as an extra safety measure.

mysql-resource-grant.body:
resource "mysql_grant" "$1" {
    # privileges - (Required) A list of privileges to grant to the user. Refer to a list of privileges (such as [here](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.5/en/grant.html)) for applicable privileges.
    privileges = ""

    # database - (Required) The database to grant privileges on. At this time, privileges are given to all tables on the database (`mydb.*`).
    database = ""

    # user - (Required) The name of the user.
    user = ""

    # host - (Optional) The source host of the user. Defaults to "localhost".
    host = ""

    # grant - (Optional) Whether to also give the user privileges to grant the same privileges to other users.
    grant = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
mysql-resource-grant.description:
The ``mysql_grant`` resource creates and manages privileges given to
a user on a MySQL server.

mysql-resource-user.body:
resource "mysql_user" "$1" {
    # user - (Required) The name of the user.
    user = ""

    # host - (Optional) The source host of the user. Defaults to "localhost".
    host = ""

    # plaintext_password - (Optional) The password for the user. This must be provided in plain text, so the data source for it must be secured. An _unsalted_ hash of the provided password is stored in state.
    plaintext_password = ""

    # password - (Optional) Deprecated alias of `plaintext_password`, whose value is *stored as plaintext in state*. Prefer to use `plaintext_password` instead, which stores the password as an unsalted hash.
    password = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
mysql-resource-user.description:
The ``mysql_user`` resource creates and manages a user on a MySQL
server. ~> **Note:** The password for the user is provided in plain text, and is
obscured by an unsalted hash in the state
[Read more about sensitive data in state](/docs/state/sensitive-data.html).
Care is required when using this resource, to avoid disclosing the password.

nomad-resource-job.body:
resource "nomad_job" "$1" {
    # jobspec - (Optional) The contents of the jobspec to register.
    jobspec = ""

    # deregister_on_destroy - (Optional) Determines if the job will be deregistered when this resource is destroyed in Terraform.
    deregister_on_destroy = ""

    # deregister_on_id_change - (Optional) Determines if the job will be deregistered if the ID of the job in the jobspec changes.
    deregister_on_id_change = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
nomad-resource-job.description:
Manages a job registered in Nomad. This can be used to initialize your cluster with system jobs, common services,
and more. In day to day Nomad use it is common for developers to submit jobs to
Nomad directly, such as for general app deployment. In addition to these apps, a
Nomad cluster often runs core system services that are ideally setup during
infrastructure creation. This resource is ideal for the latter type of job, but
can be used to manage any job within Nomad.

ns1-resource-monitoringjob.body:
resource "ns1_monitoringjob" "$1" {
    # value - (Required) The value to compare to.
    value = ""

    # comparison - (Required) The comparison to perform on the the output.
    comparison = ""

    # key - (Required) The output key.
    key = ""

    config = ""

    # policy - (Required) The policy for determining the monitor's global status based on the status of the job in all regions.
    policy = ""

    # rapid_recheck - (Required) If true, on any apparent state change, the job is quickly re-run after one second to confirm the state change before notification.
    rapid_recheck = ""

    # frequency - (Required) The frequency, in seconds, at which to run the monitoring job in each region.
    frequency = ""

    # regions - (Required) The list of region codes in which to run the monitoring job.
    regions = ""

    # active - (Required) Indicates if the job is active or temporaril.y disabled.
    active = ""

    # job_type - (Required) The type of monitoring job to be run.
    job_type = ""

    # name - (Required) The free-form display name for the monitoring job.
    name = ""

    # notify_delay - (Optional) The time in seconds after a failure to wait before sending a notification.
    notify_delay = ""

    # notify_repeat - (Optional) The time in seconds between repeat notifications of a failed job.
    notify_repeat = ""

    # notify_failback - (Optional) If true, a notification is sent when a job returns to an "up" state.
    notify_failback = ""

    # notify_regional - (Optional) If true, notifications are sent for any regional failure (and failback if desired), in addition to global state notifications.
    notify_regional = ""

    # notify_list - (Optional) The id of the notification list to send notifications to.
    notify_list = ""

    # notes - (Optional) Freeform notes to be included in any notifications about this job.
    notes = ""

    # rules - (Optional) A list of rules for determining failure conditions. Job Rules are documented below.
    rules = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}

oneandone-resource-firewall-policy.body:
resource "oneandone_firewall_policy" "$1" {
    # protocol - (Required)  The protocol for the rule. Allowed values are `TCP`, `UDP`, `TCP/UDP`, `ICMP` and `IPSEC`.
    protocol = ""

opc-datasource-image-list-entry.body:
data "opc_compute_image_list_entry" "$1" {
    # version - (Required) - The version (integer) of the Image List to use.
    version = ""

    # image_list - (Required) - The name of the image list to lookup.
    image_list = ""

    # entry - (Optional) - Which machine image to use. See [Entry](#entry) below for more details
    entry = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "dns" - Array of DNS servers for the interface.
    # "attributes" - JSON object of all of the image list's attributes
    # "machine_images" - An array of machine images as strings
    # "uri" - The URI of the image list
}
opc-datasource-image-list-entry.description: Use this data source to access the configuration of an Image List Entry.

opc-datasource-network-interface.body:
data "opc_compute_network_interface" "$1" {
    # instance_name - (Optional) `instance_name` is the name of the instance.
    instance_name = ""

    # instance_id - (Optional) `instance_id` is the id of the instance.
    instance_id = ""

    # interface - (Optional) `interface` is the name of the attached interface. `eth0`, `eth1`, ... `eth9`.
    interface = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "dns" - Array of DNS servers for the interface.
    # "ip_address" - IP Address assigned to the interface.
    # "ip_network" - The IP Network assigned to the interface.
    # "mac_address" - The MAC address of the interface.
    # "model" - The model of the NIC card used.
    # "name_servers" - Array of name servers for the interface.
    # "nat" - The IP Reservation (in IP Networks) associated with the interface.
    # "search_domains" - The search domains that are sent through DHCP as option 119.
    # "sec_lists" - The security lists the interface is added to.
    # "shared_network" - Whether or not the interface is inside the Shared Network or an IP Network.
    # "vnic" - The name of the vNIC created for the IP Network.
    # "vnic_sets" - The array of vNIC Sets the interface was added to.
}
opc-datasource-network-interface.description: Use this data source to access the configuration of an instance's network interface

opc-datasource-storage-volume-snapshot.body:
data "opc_compute_storage_volume_snapshot" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) `name` is the name of the storage volume snapshot.
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "account" - Account of the snapshot.
    # "collocated" - Boolean specifying whether the snapshot is collocated or remote.
    # "description" - The description of the storage volume snapshot.
    # "machine_image_name" - The name of the machine image that's used in the boot volume from which this snapshot is taken.
    # "parent_volume_bootable" - Boolean specifying whether or not the snapshot's parent volume was bootable.
    # "property" - Where the snapshot is stored, whether collocated, or in the Oracle Storage Cloud Service instance.
    # "platform" - The OS platform this snapshot is compatible with
    # "size" - The size of the snapshot in GB.
    # "snapshot_timestamp" - Timestamp of the storage snapshot, generated by storage server. The snapshot will contain data written to the original volume before this time.
    # "snapshot_id" - The Oracle ID of the snapshot.
    # "start_timestamp" - Timestamp when the snapshot was started.
    # "status" - Status of the snapshot.
    # "status_detail" - Details about the latest state of the storage volume snapshot.
    # "status_timestamp" - Indicates the time that the current view of the storage volume snapshot was generated.
    # "tags" - Comma-separated strings that tag the storage volume.
    # "uri" - Uniform Resource Identifier
    # "volume_name" - The name of the storage volume that the snapshot was created from
}
opc-datasource-storage-volume-snapshot.description: Use this data source to access the configuration of a storage volume snapshot.

opc-datasource-vnic.body:
data "opc_compute_vnic" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) `name` is the name of the Virtual NIC.
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "description" is a description of the Virtual NIC.
    # "mac_address" is the MAC Address of the Virtual NIC.
    # "tags" is a list of Tags associated with the Virtual NIC.
    # "transit_flag" is "true" if the Virtual NIC is of the type "transit".
    # "uri" is the Unique Resource Locator of the Virtual NIC.
}
opc-datasource-vnic.description: Use this data source to access the configuration of a Virtual NIC.
