    enabled = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the ACL.
    description = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the ACL.
    tags = ""

    # uri - (Optional) The Uniform Resource Identifier for the ACL
    uri = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the ACL.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-acl.description: The ``opc_compute_acl`` resource creates and manages an ACL in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-image-list-entry.body:
resource "opc_compute_image_list_entry" "$1" {
    # version - (Required) The unique version of the image list entry, as an integer.
    version = ""

    # machine_images - (Required) An array of machine images.
    machine_images = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the Image List.
    name = ""

    # attributes - (Optional) JSON String of optional data that will be passed to an instance of this machine image when it is launched.
    attributes = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "uri" - The Unique Resource Identifier for the Image List Entry.
    # "attributes" - (Optional) JSON String of optional data that will be passed to an instance of this machine image when it is launched.
}
opc-resource-image-list-entry.description: The ``opc_compute_image_list_entry`` resource creates and manages an Image List Entry in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-image-list-type.body:
resource "opc_compute_image_list" "$1" {
    # default - (Required) The image list entry to be used, by default, when launching instances using this image list. Defaults to `1`.
    default = ""

    # description - (Required) A description of the Image List.
    description = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the Image List.
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-image-list-type.description: The ``opc_compute_image_list`` resource creates and manages an Image List in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-instance.body:
resource "opc_compute_instance" "$1" {
    # shape - (Required) The shape of the instance, e.g. `oc4`.
    shape = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the instance.
    name = ""

    # instance_attributes - (Optional) A JSON string of custom attributes. See [Attributes](#attributes) below for more information.
    instance_attributes = ""

    # boot_order - (Optional) The index number of the bootable storage volume, presented as a list, that should be used to boot the instance. The only valid value is `[1]`. If you set this attribute, you must also specify a bootable storage volume with index number 1 in the volume sub-parameter of storage_attachments. When you specify boot_order, you don't need to specify the imagelist attribute, because the instance is booted using the image on the specified bootable storage volume. If you specify both boot_order and imagelist, the imagelist attribute is ignored.
    boot_order = ""

    # hostname - (Optional) The host name assigned to the instance. On an Oracle Linux instance, this host name is displayed in response to the hostname command. Only relative DNS is supported. The domain name is suffixed to the host name that you specify. The host name must not end with a period. If you don't specify a host name, then a name is generated automatically.
    hostname = ""

    # image_list - (Optional) The imageList of the instance, e.g. `/oracle/public/oel_6.4_2GB_v1`.
    image_list = ""

    # label - (Optional) The label to apply to the instance.
    label = ""

    # networking_info - (Optional) Information pertaining to an individual network interface to be created and attached to the instance. If left unspecified, the instance will be created within the `shared_network`. See [Networking Info](#networking-info) below for more information.
    networking_info = ""

    # storage - (Optional) Information pertaining to an individual storage attachment to be created during instance creation. Please see [Storage Attachments](#storage-attachments) below for more information.
    storage = ""

    # reverse_dns - (Optional) If set to `true` (default), then reverse DNS records are created. If set to `false`, no reverse DNS records are created.
    reverse_dns = ""

    # ssh_keys - (Optional) A list of the names of the SSH Keys that can be used to log into the instance.
    ssh_keys = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The "id" of the instance.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "attributes" - The full attributes of the instance, as a JSON string.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "availability_domain" - The availability domain the instance is in.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "domain" - The default domain to use for the hostname and for DNS lookups.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "entry" - Imagelist entry number.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "fingerprint" - SSH server fingerprint presented by the instance.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "fqdn" - The fully qualified domain name of the instance.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "image_format" - The format of the image.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "ip_address" - The IP Address of the instance.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "placement_requirements" - The array of placement requirements for the instance.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "platform" - The OS Platform of the instance.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "priority" - The priority at which the instance was ran.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "quota_reservation" - Reference to the QuotaReservation, to be destroyed with the instance.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "relationships" - The array of relationship specifications to be satisfied on instance placement.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "resolvers" - Array of resolvers to be used instead of the default resolvers.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "site" - The site the instance is running on.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "start_time" - The launch time of the instance.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "state" - The instance's state.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "vcable_id" - vCable ID for the instance.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "virtio" - Boolean that determines if the instance is a virtio device.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
    # "vnc_address" - The VNC address and port of the instance.
    # "tags" - (Optional) A list of strings that should be supplied to the instance as tags.
}
opc-resource-instance.description:
The ``opc_compute_instance`` resource creates and manages an instance in an OPC identity domain. ~> **Caution:** The ``opc_compute_instance`` resource can completely delete your
instance just as easily as it can create it. To avoid costly accidents,
consider setting
[``prevent_destroy``](/docs/configuration/resources.html#prevent_destroy)
on your instance resources as an extra safety measure.

opc-resource-ip-address-association.body:
resource "opc_compute_ip_address_association" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the ip address association.
    name = ""

    # ip_address_reservation - (Optional) The name of the NAT IP address reservation.
    ip_address_reservation = ""

    # vnic - (Optional) The name of the virtual NIC associated with this NAT IP reservation.
    vnic = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the ip address association.
    description = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the ip address association.
    tags = ""

    # uri - (Optional) (Computed) The Uniform Resource Identifier of the ip address association.
    uri = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the ip address association.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-ip-address-association.description: The ``opc_compute_ip_address_association`` resource creates and manages an IP address association between an IP address reservation and a virtual NIC in an OPC identity domain, for an IP Network.

opc-resource-ip-address-prefix-set.body:
resource "opc_compute_ip_address_prefix_set" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the ip address prefix set.
    name = ""

    # prefixes - (Optional) List of CIDR IPv4 prefixes assigned in the virtual network.
    prefixes = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the ip address prefix set.
    description = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the ip address prefix set.
    tags = ""

    # uri - (Optional) (Computed) The Uniform Resource Identifier of the ip address prefix set.
    uri = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the ip address prefix set.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-ip-address-prefix-set.description: The ``opc_compute_ip_address_prefix_set`` resource creates and manages an IP address prefix set in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-ip-address-reservation.body:
resource "opc_compute_ip_address_reservation" "$1" {
    # ip_address_pool - (Required) The IP address pool from which you want to reserve an IP address. Must be either `public-ippool` or `cloud-ippool`.
    ip_address_pool = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the ip address reservation.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the ip address reservation.
    description = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the IP address reservation.
    tags = ""

    # ip_address - (Optional) Reserved NAT IPv4 address from the IP address pool.
    ip_address = ""

    # uri - (Optional) The Uniform Resource Identifier of the ip address reservation
    uri = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-ip-address-reservation.description: The ``opc_compute_ip_address_reservation`` resource creates and manages an IP address reservation in an OPC identity domain, for an IP Network.

opc-resource-ip-association.body:
resource "opc_compute_ip_association" "$1" {
    # parentpool - (Required) The pool from which to take an IP address. To associate a specific reserved IP address, use the prefix `ipreservation:` followed by the name of the IP reservation. To allocate an IP address from a pool, use the prefix `ippool:`, e.g. `ippool:/oracle/public/ippool`.
    parentpool = ""

    # vcable - (Required) The vcable of the instance to associate the IP address with.
    vcable = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "name" The name of the IP Association
    # "parentpool" - (Required) The pool from which to take an IP address. To associate a specific reserved IP address, use the prefix "ipreservation:" followed by the name of the IP reservation. To allocate an IP address from a pool, use the prefix "ippool:", e.g. "ippool:/oracle/public/ippool".
}
opc-resource-ip-association.description:
The ``opc_compute_ip_association`` resource creates and manages an association between an IP address and an instance in
an OPC identity domain, for the Shared Network.

opc-resource-ip-network.body:
resource "opc_compute_ip_network" "$1" {
    # ip_address_prefix - (Required) The IPv4 address prefix, in CIDR format.
    ip_address_prefix = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the IP Network. Changing this name forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the IP Network.
    description = ""

    # ip_network_exchange - (Optional) Specify the IP Network exchange to which the IP Network belongs to.
    ip_network_exchange = ""

    # public_napt_enabled - (Optional) If true, enable public internet access using NAPT for VNICs without any public IP Reservation. Defaults to `false`.
    public_napt_enabled = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "name" - The name of the IP Network
    # "ip_address_prefix" - The IPv4 address prefix, in CIDR format.
    # "description" - The description of the IP Network.
    # "ip_network_exchange" - The IP Network Exchange for the IP Network
    # "public_napt_enabled" - Whether public internet access using NAPT for VNICs without any public IP Reservation or not.
    # "uri" - Uniform Resource Identifier for the IP Network
}
opc-resource-ip-network.description: The ``opc_compute_ip_network`` resource creates and manages an IP Network.

opc-resource-ip-network-exchange.body:
resource "opc_compute_ip_network_exchange" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the ip network exchange.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the ip network exchange.
    description = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the IP network exchange.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-ip-network-exchange.description: The ``opc_compute_ip_network_exchange`` resource creates and manages an IP network exchange in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-ip-reservation.body:
resource "opc_compute_ip_reservation" "$1" {
    # permanent - (Required) Whether the IP address remains reserved even when it is no longer associated with an instance (if true), or may be returned to the pool and replaced with a different IP address when an instance is restarted, or deleted and recreated (if false).
    permanent = ""

    # parent_pool - (Optional) The pool from which to allocate the IP address. Defaults to `/oracle/public/ippool`, and is currently the only acceptable input.
    parent_pool = ""

    # name - (Optional) Name of the IP Reservation. Will be generated if unspecified.
    name = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the IP reservation.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-ip-reservation.description: The ``opc_compute_ip_reservation`` resource creates and manages an IP reservation in an OPC identity domain for the Shared Network.

opc-resource-route.body:
resource "opc_compute_route" "$1" {
    # next_hop_vnic_set - (Required) Name of the virtual NIC set to route matching packets to. Routed flows are load-balanced among all the virtual NICs in the virtual NIC set.
    next_hop_vnic_set = ""

    # ip_address_prefix - (Required) The IPv4 address prefix, in CIDR format, of the external network from which to route traffic.
    ip_address_prefix = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the route.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the route.
    description = ""

    # admin_distance - (Optional) The route's administrative distance. Defaults to `0`.
    admin_distance = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "name" The name of the route
    # "description" - The description of the route.
    # "admin_distance" - The route's administrative distance. Defaults to "0".
    # "ip_address_prefix" - The IPv4 address prefix, in CIDR format, of the external network from which to route traffic.
    # "next_hop_vnic_set" - Name of the virtual NIC set to route matching packets to. Routed flows are load-balanced among all the virtual NICs in the virtual NIC set.
}
opc-resource-route.description: The `opc_compute_route` resource creates and manages a route for an IP Network.

opc-resource-sec-rule.body:
resource "opc_compute_sec_rule" "$1" {
    # action - (Required) Whether to `permit`, `refuse` or `deny` packets to which this rule applies. This will ordinarily be `permit`.
    action = ""

    # application - (Required) The name of the application to which the rule applies.
    application = ""

    # source_list - (Required) The source security list (prefixed with `seclist:`), or security IP list (prefixed with `seciplist:`). `destination_list` - (Required) The destination security list (prefixed with `seclist:`), or security IP list (prefixed with `seciplist:`).
    source_list = ""

    # source_list - (Required) The source security list (prefixed with `seclist:`), or security IP list (prefixed with `seciplist:`). `destination_list` - (Required) The destination security list (prefixed with `seclist:`), or security IP list (prefixed with `seciplist:`).
    source_list = ""

    # name - (Required) The unique (within the identity domain) name of the security rule.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description for this security rule.
    description = ""

    # disabled - (Optional) Whether to disable this security rule. This is useful if you want to temporarily disable a rule without removing it outright from your Terraform resource definition. Defaults to `false`.
    disabled = ""

    # uri - (Optional) The Uniform Resource Identifier of the sec rule.
    uri = ""

    # disabled - (Optional) Whether to disable this security rule. This is useful if you want to temporarily disable a rule without removing it outright from your Terraform resource definition. Defaults to `false`.
    disabled = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-sec-rule.description: The ``opc_compute_sec_rule`` resource creates and manages a sec rule in an OPC identity domain, which joinstogether a source security list (or security IP list), a destination security list (or security IP list), and a security application.

opc-resource-security-application.body:
resource "opc_compute_security_application" "$1" {
    # dport - (Required) The port, or range of ports, to enable for this application, e.g `8080`, `6000-7000`. This must be set if the `protocol` is set to `tcp` or `udp`.
    dport = ""

    # protocol - (Required) The protocol to enable for this application. Must be one of `tcp`, `udp`, `ah`, `esp`, `icmp`, `icmpv6`, `igmp`, `ipip`, `gre`, `mplsip`, `ospf`, `pim`, `rdp`, `sctp` or `all`.
    protocol = ""

    # name - (Required) The unique (within the identity domain) name of the application
    name = ""

    # icmptype - (Optional) The ICMP type to enable for this application, if the `protocol` is `icmp`. Must be one of `echo`, `reply`, `ttl`, `traceroute`, `unreachable`.
    icmptype = ""

    # icmpcode - (Optional) The ICMP code to enable for this application, if the `protocol` is `icmp`. Must be one of `admin`, `df`, `host`, `network`, `port` or `protocol`.
    icmpcode = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-security-application.description: The ``opc_compute_security_application`` resource creates and manages a security application in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-security-association.body:
resource "opc_compute_security_association" "$1" {
    # seclist - (Required) The name of the security list to associate the instance to.
    seclist = ""

    # vcable - (Required) The `vcable` of the instance to associate to the security list.
    vcable = ""

    # name - (Optional) The Name for the Security Association. If not specified, one is created automatically. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-security-association.description:
The ``opc_compute_security_association`` resource creates and manages an association between an instance and a security
list in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-security-list.body:
resource "opc_compute_security_list" "$1" {
    # output_cidr_policy - (Required) The policy for outbound traffic from the security list. Must be one of `permit`, `reject` (packets are dropped but a reply is sent) and `deny` (packets are dropped and no reply is sent).
    output_cidr_policy = ""

    # policy - (Required) The policy to apply to instances associated with this list. Must be one of `permit`, `reject` (packets are dropped but a reply is sent) and `deny` (packets are dropped and no reply is sent).
    policy = ""

    # name - (Required) The unique (within the identity domain) name of the security list.
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-security-list.description: The ``opc_compute_security_list`` resource creates and manages a security list in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-security-protocol.body:
resource "opc_compute_security_protocol" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the security protocol.
    name = ""

    # dst_ports - (Optional) Enter a list of port numbers or port range strings. 	Traffic is enabled by a security rule when a packet's destination port matches the ports specified here. 	For TCP, SCTP, and UDP, each port is a destination transport port, between 0 and 65535, 	inclusive. For ICMP, each port is an ICMP type, between 0 and 255, inclusive. 	If no destination ports are specified, all destination ports or ICMP types are allowed.
    dst_ports = ""

    # src_ports - (Optional) Enter a list of port numbers or port range strings. 	Traffic is enabled by a security rule when a packet's source port matches the 	ports specified here. 	For TCP, SCTP, and UDP, each port is a source transport port, 	between 0 and 65535, inclusive. 	For ICMP, each port is an ICMP type, between 0 and 255, inclusive. 	If no source ports are specified, all source ports or ICMP types are allowed.
    src_ports = ""

    # ip_protocol - (Optional) The protocol used in the data portion of the IP datagram. 	 Permitted values are: tcp, udp, icmp, igmp, ipip, rdp, esp, ah, gre, icmpv6, ospf, pim, sctp, 	 mplsip, all. 	 Traffic is enabled by a security rule when the protocol in the packet matches the 	 protocol specified here. If no protocol is specified, all protocols are allowed.
    ip_protocol = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the security protocol.
    description = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the security protocol.
    tags = ""

    # uri - (Optional) The Uniform Resource Identifier for the Security Protocol
    uri = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the security protocol.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-security-protocol.description: The ``opc_compute_security_protocol`` resource creates and manages a security protocol in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-security-rule.body:
resource "opc_compute_security_rule" "$1" {
    # flow_direction - (Required) Specify the direction of flow of traffic, which is relative to the instances, for this security rule. Allowed values are ingress or egress.
    flow_direction = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the security rule.
    name = ""

    # disabled - (Optional) Whether to disable this security rule. This is useful if you want to temporarily disable a rule without removing it outright from your Terraform resource definition. Defaults to `false`.
    disabled = ""

    # acl - (Optional) Name of the ACL that contains this security rule.
    acl = ""

    # dst_ip_address_prefixes - (Optional) List of IP address prefix set names to match the packet's destination IP address.
    dst_ip_address_prefixes = ""

    # src_ip_address_prefixes - (Optional) List of names of IP address prefix set to match the packet's source IP address.
    src_ip_address_prefixes = ""

    # dst_vnic_set - (Optional) Name of virtual NIC set containing the packet's destination virtual NIC.
    dst_vnic_set = ""

    # src_vnic_set - (Optional) Name of virtual NIC set containing the packet's source virtual NIC.
    src_vnic_set = ""

    # security_protocols - (Optional) List of security protocol object names to match the packet's protocol and port.
    security_protocols = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the security rule.
    description = ""

    # tags - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the security rule.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "uri" - The Uniform Resource Identifier of the security rule.
    # "tags" - (Optional) List of tags that may be applied to the security rule.
}
opc-resource-security-rule.description: The ``opc_compute_security_rule`` resource creates and manages a security rule in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-service-instance.body:
resource "opc_database_service_instance" "$1" {
    # password - (Required) Password for the Oracle Storage Cloud Service administrator.
    password = ""

    # username - (Required) Username for the Oracle Storage Cloud Service administrator.
    username = ""

    # container - (Required) Name of the Oracle Storage Cloud Service container used to provide storage for your service instance backups. Use the following format to specify the container name: `<storageservicename>-<storageidentitydomain>/<containername>`
    container = ""

    # database_id - (Required) Database id of the database from which the existing cloud backup was created.
    database_id = ""

    # cloud_storage_password - (Required) Password of the Oracle Cloud user specified in `ibkup_cloud_storage_user`.
    cloud_storage_password = ""

    # cloud_storage_username - (Required) Username of the Oracle Cloud user.
    cloud_storage_username = ""

    # usable_storage - (Required) Storage size for data (in GB). Minimum value is `15`. Maximum value depends on the backup destination: if `BOTH` is specified, the maximum value is `1200`; if `OSS` or `NONE` is specified, the maximum value is `2048`.
    usable_storage = ""

    # char_set - (Required) Character Set for the Database Cloud Service Instance. All possible values are listed under the [parameters section documentation](http://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/database-dbaas-cloud/csdbr/op-paas-service-dbcs-api-v1.1-instances-%7BidentityDomainId%7D-post.html). Default value is `AL32UTF8`.
    char_set = ""

    # backup_destination - (Required) Backup Destination. Possible values are `BOTH`, `OSS`, `NONE`.
    backup_destination = ""

    # admin_password - (Required) Password for Oracle Database administrator users sys and system. The password must meet the following requirements: Starts with a letter. Is between 8 and 30 characters long. Contains letters, at least one number, and optionally, any number of these special characters: dollar sign `$`, pound sign `#`, and underscore `_`.
    admin_password = ""

    # vm_public_key - (Required) Public key for the secure shell (SSH). This key will be used for authentication when connecting to the Database Cloud Service instance using an SSH client.
    vm_public_key = ""

    # version - (Required) Oracle Database software version; one of: `12.2.0.1`, `12.1.0.2`, or `11.2.0.4`.
    version = ""

    # subscription_type - (Required) Billing unit. Possible values are `HOURLY` or `MONTHLY`.
    subscription_type = ""

    # shape - (Required) Desired compute shape. Possible values are `oc3`, `oc4`, `oc5`, `oc6`, `oc1m`, `oc2m`, `oc3m`, or `oc4m`.
    shape = ""

    # level - (Required) Service level for the service instance. Possible values are `BASIC` or `PAAS`.
    level = ""

    # edition - (Required) Database edition for the service instance. Possible values are `SE`, `EE`, `EE_HP`, or `EE_EP`.
    edition = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the Service Instance.
    name = ""

    # parameter - (Optional) Additional configuration for a service instance. This set is required if level is PAAS. Parameter is documented below.
    parameter = ""

    # ibkup - (Optional) Specify if the service instance's database should, after the instance is created, be replaced by a database stored in an existing cloud backup that was created using Oracle Database Backup Cloud Service. IBKUP is documented below.
    ibkup = ""

    # cloud_storage - (Optional) Provides Cloud Storage for service instance backups. Cloud Storage is documented below
    cloud_storage = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the Service Instance.
    description = ""

    # disaster_recovery - (Optional) Specify if an Oracle Data Guard configuration is created using the Disaster Recovery option or the High Availability option. Valid values are `yes` and `no`. Default value is no.
    disaster_recovery = ""

    # failover_database - (Optional) Specify if an Oracle Data Guard configuration comprising a primary database and a standby database is created. Valid values are `yes` and `no`. Default value is `no`.
    failover_database = ""

    # golden_gate - (Optional) Specify if the database should be configured for use as the replication database of an Oracle GoldenGate Cloud Service instance. Valid values are `yes` and `no`. Default value is `no`. You cannot set `goldenGate` to `yes` if either `is_rac` or `failoverDatabase` is set to `yes`.
    golden_gate = ""

    # is_rac - (Optional) Specify if a cluster database using Oracle Real Application Clusters should be configured. Valid values are `yes` and `no`. Default value is `no`.
    is_rac = ""

    # n_char_set - (Optional) National Character Set for the Database Cloud Service instance. Valid values are `AL16UTF16` and `UTF8`. Default value is `AL16UTF16`.
    n_char_set = ""

    # pdb_name - (Optional) This attribute is valid when Database Cloud Service instance is configured with version 12c. Pluggable Database Name for the Database Cloud Service instance. Default value is `pdb1`.
    pdb_name = ""

    # sid - (Optional) Database Name for the Database Cloud Service instance. Default value is `ORCL`.
    sid = ""

    # source_service_name - (Optional) Indicates that the service instance should be created as a "snapshot clone" of another service instance. Provide the name of the existing service instance whose snapshot is to be used.
    source_service_name = ""

    # snapshot_name - (Optional) The name of the snapshot of the service instance specified by sourceServiceName that is to be used to create a "snapshot clone". This parameter is valid only if source_service_name is specified.
    snapshot_name = ""

    # timezone - (Optional) Time Zone for the Database Cloud Service instance. Default value is `UTC`.
    timezone = ""

    # type - (Optional) Component type to which the set of parameters applies. Defaults to `db`
    type = ""

    # db_demo - (Optional) Indicates whether to include the Demos PDB. Valid values are `yes` or `no`.
    db_demo = ""

    # decryption_key - (Optional) Password used to create the existing, password-encrypted cloud backup. This password is used to decrypt the backup. Specify either `ibkup_decryption_key` or `ibkup_wallet_file_content` for decrypting the backup.
    decryption_key = ""

    # wallet_file_content - (Optional) String containing the xsd:base64Binary representation of the cloud backup's wallet file. This wallet is used to decrypt the backup. Specify either `ibkup_decryption_key` or `ibkup_wallet_file_content` for decrypting the backup.
    wallet_file_content = ""

    # create_if_missing - (Optional) Specify if the given cloud_storage_container is to be created if it does not already exist. Default value is `false`.
    create_if_missing = ""

    # apex_url - (Optional) The URL to use to connect to Oracle Application Express on the service instance.
    apex_url = ""

    # backup_supported_version - (Optional) The version of cloud tooling for backup and recovery supported by the service instance.
    backup_supported_version = ""

    # compute_site_name - (Optional) The Oracle Cloud location housing the service instance.
    compute_site_name = ""

    # connect_descriptor_with_public_ip - (Optional) The connection descriptor for Oracle Net Services (SQL*Net) with IP addresses instead of host names.
    connect_descriptor_with_public_ip = ""

    # created_by - (Optional) The user name of the Oracle Cloud user who created the service instance.
    created_by = ""

    # creation_time - (Optional) The date-and-time stamp when the service instance was created.
    creation_time = ""

    # current_version - (Optional) The Oracle Database version on the service instance, including the patch level.
    current_version = ""

    # dbaasmonitor_url - (Optional) `dbaasmonitor_url`- The URL to use to connect to Oracle DBaaS Monitor on the service instance.
    dbaasmonitor_url = ""

    # em_url - (Optional) The URL to use to connect to Enterprise Manager on the service instance.
    em_url = ""

    # glassfish_url - (Optional) The URL to use to connect to the Oracle GlassFish Server Administration Console on the service instance.
    glassfish_url = ""

    # hdg_prem_ip - (Optional) Data Guard Role of the on-premise instance in Oracle Hybrid Disaster Recovery configuration.
    hdg_prem_ip = ""

    # hybrid_dg - (Optional) Indicates whether the service instance hosts an Oracle Hybrid Disaster Recovery configuration.
    hybrid_dg = ""

    # identity_domain - (Optional) The identity domain housing the service instance.
    identity_domain = ""

    # ip_network - (Optional) This attribute is only applicable to accounts where regions are supported. The three-part name of an IP network to which the service instance is added. For example: /Compute-identity_domain/user/object
    ip_network = ""

    # ip_reservations - (Optional) Groups one or more IP reservations in use on this service instance. This attribute is only applicable to accounts where regions are supported.
    ip_reservations = ""

    # jaas_instances_using_service - (Optional) The Oracle Java Cloud Service instances using this Database Cloud Service instance.
    jaas_instances_using_service = ""

    # listener_port - (Optional) The listener port for Oracle Net Services (SQL*Net) connections.
    listener_port = ""

    # num_ip_reservations - (Optional) The number of Oracle Compute Service IP reservations assigned to the service instance.
    num_ip_reservations = ""

    # num_nodes - (Optional) The number of compute nodes in the service instance.
    num_nodes = ""

    # rac_database - (Optional) Indicates whether the service instance hosts an Oracle RAC database.
    rac_database = ""

    # region - (Optional) This attribute is only applicable to accounts where regions are supported. Location where the service instance is provisioned (only for accounts where regions are supported).
    region = ""

    # sm_plugin_version - (Optional) The version of the cloud tooling service manager plugin supported by the service instance.
    sm_plugin_version = ""

    # total_shared_storage - (Optional) For service instances hosting an Oracle RAC database, the size in GB of the storage shared and accessed by the nodes of the RAC database.
    total_shared_storage = ""

    # uri - (Optional) The Uniform Resource Identifier for the Service Instance
    uri = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-service-instance.description: The ``opc_database_service_instance`` resource creates and manages a service instance in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-ssh-key.body:
resource "opc_compute_ssh_key" "$1" {
    # key - (Required) The SSH key itself
    key = ""

    # name - (Required) The unique (within this identity domain) name of the SSH key.
    name = ""

    # enabled - (Optional) Whether or not the key is enabled. This is useful if you want to temporarily disable an SSH key, without removing it entirely from your Terraform resource definition. Defaults to `true`
    enabled = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-ssh-key.description: The ``opc_compute_ssh_key`` resource creates and manages an SSH key in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-storage-container.body:
resource "opc_storage_container" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the Storage Container.
    name = ""

    # read_acls - (Optional) The list of ACLs that grant read access.
    read_acls = ""

    # write_acls - (Optional) The list of ACLs that grant write access.
    write_acls = ""

    # primary_key - (Optional) The primary secret key value for temporary URLs.
    primary_key = ""

    # secondary_key - (Optional) The secondary secret key value for temporary URLs.
    secondary_key = ""

    # allowed_origins - (Optional) List of origins that are allowed to make cross-origin requests.
    allowed_origins = ""

    # max_age - (Optional) Maximum age in seconds for the origin to hold the preflight results.
    max_age = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-storage-container.description:
Creates and manages a Container in the OPC Storage Domain. `storage_endpoint` must be set in the
provider or environment to manage these resources.

opc-resource-storage-object.body:
resource "opc_storage_object" "$1" {
    # container - (Required) The name of the Storage Container in which to place the object.
    container = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the Storage Object.
    name = ""

    # content - (Optional) A raw string value for the Storage Object's contents.
    content = ""

    # file - (Optional) The path to the file to use as the Storage Object's contents.
    file = ""

    # copy_from - (Optional) The source Storage Object to copy from. (`container_name/object_name`).
    copy_from = ""

    # content_disposition - (Optional) Overrides the behavior of the browser.
    content_disposition = ""

    # content_encoding - (Optional) Set the content-encoding metadata for the Storage Object.
    content_encoding = ""

    # content_type - (Optional) Sets the MIME type for the object. Will be computed via the API if not specified.
    content_type = ""

    # delete_at - (Optional) Specify the number of seconds after which the system deletes the storage object.
    delete_at = ""

    # etag - (Optional) MD5 checksum value of the request body. Unquoted, strongly recommended, but not required.
    etag = ""

    # transfer_encoding - (Optional) Sets the transfer encoding. Can only be `chunked` if set. Requires `content_length` to be `0` if set.
    transfer_encoding = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "accept_ranges" - Type of ranges that the object accepts.
    # "content_length" - Length of the Storage Object in bytes.
    # "last_modified" - Date and time that the object was created/modified in ISO 8601.
    # "object_manifest" - The dynamic large-object manifest object.
    # "timestamp" - Date and Time in UNIX EPOCH when the account, container, or object was initially created at the current version.
    # "transaction_id" - Transaction ID of the request. Used for bug reports.
}
opc-resource-storage-object.description:
Creates and manages a Container in the OPC Storage Domain. `storage_endpoint` must be set in the
provider or environment to manage these resources.

opc-resource-storage-volume-snapshot.body:
resource "opc_compute_storage_volume_snapshot" "$1" {
    # volume_name - (Required) The name of the storage volume to create the snapshot from.
    volume_name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the storage volume snapshot.
    description = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the storage volume snapshot. Will be generated if unspecified.
    name = ""

    # parent_volume_bootable - (Optional) A string value of whether or not the parent volume is 'bootable' or not. Defaults to `"false"`.
    parent_volume_bootable = ""

    # collocated - (Optional) Boolean specifying whether the snapshot is collocated or remote. Defaults to `false`.
    collocated = ""

    # tags - (Optional) Comma-separated strings that tag the storage volume.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "account" - Account to use for snapshots.
    # "machine_image_name" - The name of the machine image that's used in the boot volume from which this snapshot is taken.
    # "size" - The size of the snapshot in GB.
    # "property" - Where the snapshot is stored, whether collocated, or in the Oracle Storage Cloud Service instance.
    # "platform" - The OS platform this snapshot is compatible with
    # "snapshot_timestamp" - Timestamp of the storage snapshot, generated by storage server. The snapshot will contain data written to the original volume before this time.
    # "snapshot_id" - The Oracle ID of the snapshot.
    # "start_timestamp" - Timestamp when the snapshot was started.
    # "status" - Status of the snapshot.
    # "status_detail" - Details about the latest state of the storage volume snapshot.
    # "status_timestamp" - Indicates the time that the current view of the storage volume snapshot was generated.
    # "uri" - Uniform Resource Identifier
}
opc-resource-storage-volume-snapshot.description: The ``opc_compute_storage_volume_snapshot`` resource creates and manages a storage volume snapshot in an OPC identity domain.

opc-resource-storage-volume-type.body:
resource "opc_compute_storage_volume" "$1" {
    # size - (Required) The size of this storage volume in GB. The allowed range is from 1 GB to 2 TB (2048 GB).
    size = ""

    # name - (Required) The name for the Storage Account.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the storage volume.
    description = ""

    # storage_type - (Optional) - The Type of Storage to provision. Defaults to `/oracle/public/storage/default`.
    storage_type = ""

    # bootable - (Optional) Is the Volume Bootable? Defaults to `false`.
    bootable = ""

    # image_list - (Optional) Defines an image list.
    image_list = ""

    # image_list_entry - (Optional) Defines an image list entry.
    image_list_entry = ""

    # snapshot - (Optional) The name of the parent snapshot from which the storage volume is restored or cloned. See [Snapshots](#snapshots), below for more information.
    snapshot = ""

    # snapshot_id - (Optional) The Id of the parent snapshot from which the storage volume is restored or cloned. See [Snapshots](#snapshots), below for more information.
    snapshot_id = ""

    # snapshot_account - (Optional) The Account of the parent snapshot from which the storage volume is restored. See [Snapshots](#snapshots), below for more information.
    snapshot_account = ""

    # tags - (Optional) Comma-separated strings that tag the storage volume.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "hypervisor" - The hypervisor that this volume is compatible with.
    # "machine_image" - Name of the Machine Image - available if the volume is a bootable storage volume.
    # "managed" - Is this a Managed Volume?
    # "platform" - The OS platform this volume is compatible with.
    # "readonly" - Can this Volume be attached as readonly?
    # "status" - The current state of the storage volume.
    # "storage_pool" - The storage pool from which this volume is allocated.
    # "uri" - Unique Resource Identifier of the Storage Volume.
}
opc-resource-storage-volume-type.description: The ``opc_compute_storage_volume`` resource creates and manages a storage volume in an OPC identity domain. ~> **Caution:** The ``opc_compute_storage_volume`` resource can completely delete your storage volume just as easily as it can create it. To avoid costly accidents, consider setting [``prevent_destroy``](/docs/configuration/resources.html#prevent_destroy) on your storage volume resources as an extra safety measure.

opc-resource-vnic-set.body:
resource "opc_compute_vnic_set" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The unique (within this identity domain) name of the virtual nic set.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the virtual nic set.
    description = ""

    # applied_acls - (Optional) A list of the ACLs to apply to the virtual nics in the set.
    applied_acls = ""

    # virtual_nics - (Optional) List of virtual NICs associated with this virtual NIC set.
    virtual_nics = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A list of tags to apply to the storage volume.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
opc-resource-vnic-set.description: The ``opc_compute_vnic_set`` resource creates and manages a virtual NIC set in an OPC identity domain.

openstack-datasource-dns-zone-v2.body:
data "openstack_dns_zone_v2" "$1" {
    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 DNS client. A DNS client is needed to retrieve zone ids. If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider is used.
    region = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the zone.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the zone.
    description = ""

    # email - (Optional) The email contact for the zone record.
    email = ""

    # status - (Optional) The zone's status.
    status = ""

    # ttl - (Optional) The time to live (TTL) of the zone.
    ttl = ""

    # type - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be `PRIMARY` or `SECONDARY`.
    type = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" is set to the ID of the found zone. In addition, the following attributes
are exported:
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "email" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "type" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "ttl" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "description" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "status" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "attributes" - Attributes of the DNS Service scheduler.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "masters" - An array of master DNS servers. When "type" is  "SECONDARY".
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "created_at" - The time the zone was created.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "updated_at" - The time the zone was last updated.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "transferred_at" - The time the zone was transferred.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "version" - The version of the zone.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "serial" - The serial number of the zone.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "pool_id" - The ID of the pool hosting the zone.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "project_id" - The project ID that owns the zone.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
}
openstack-datasource-dns-zone-v2.description: Use this data source to get the ID of an available OpenStack DNS zone.

data "openstack_images_image_v2" "$1" {
    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Glance client.   A Glance client is needed to create an Image that can be used with   a compute instance. If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider   is used.
    region = ""

    # most_recent - (Optional) If more than one result is returned, use the most recent image.
    most_recent = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the image.
    name = ""

    # owner - (Optional) The owner (UUID) of the image.
    owner = ""

    # properties - (Optional) a map of key/value pairs to match an image with.   All specified properties must be matched.
    properties = ""

    # size_min - (Optional) The minimum size (in bytes) of the image to return.
    size_min = ""

    # size_max - (Optional) The maximum size (in bytes) of the image to return.
    size_max = ""

    # sort_direction - (Optional) Order the results in either `asc` or `desc`.

are exported:

    # "disk_format": The format of the image's disk.

    # "file" - the trailing path after the glance endpoint that represent the
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". Defaults to "private".
    # "metadata" - The metadata associated with the image.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". Defaults to "private".
    # "min_disk_gb" - The minimum amount of disk space required to use the image.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". Defaults to "private".
    # "min_ram_mb" - The minimum amount of ram required to use the image.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". Defaults to "private".
    # "properties" - Freeform information about the image.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". Defaults to "private".
    # "protected" - Whether or not the image is protected.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". Defaults to "private".
    # "schema" - The path to the JSON-schema that represent
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". Defaults to "private".
    # "size_bytes" - The size of the image (in bytes).
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". Defaults to "private".
    # "tags" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". Defaults to "private".
    # "update_at" - The date the image was last updated.

openstack-resource-blockstorage-volume-a.body:
resource "openstack_blockstorage_volume_attach_v2" "$1" {
    # volume_id - (Required) The ID of the Volume to attach to an Instance.
    volume_id = ""

    # host_name - (Required) The host to attach the volume to.
    host_name = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Block Storage   client. A Block Storage client is needed to create a volume attachment.   If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this   creates a new volume attachment.
    region = ""

    # attach_mode - (Optional) Specify whether to attach the volume as Read-Only (`ro`) or Read-Write (`rw`). Only values of `ro` and `rw` are accepted. If left unspecified, the Block Storage API will apply a default of `rw`.
    attach_mode = ""

    # device - (Optional) The device to tell the Block Storage service this volume will be attached as. This is purely for informational purposes. You can specify `auto` or a device such as `/dev/vdc`.
    device = ""

    # initiator - (Optional) The iSCSI initiator string to make the connection.
    initiator = ""

    # ip_address - (Optional) The IP address of the `host_name` above.
    ip_address = ""

    # multipath - (Optional) Whether to connect to this volume via multipath.
    multipath = ""

    # os_type - (Optional) The iSCSI initiator OS type.
    os_type = ""

    # platform - (Optional) The iSCSI initiator platform.
    platform = ""

    # wwpn - (Optional) An array of wwpn strings. Used for Fibre Channel connections.
    wwpn = ""

    # wwnn - (Optional) A wwnn name. Used for Fibre Channel connections.
    wwnn = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "data" - This is a map of key/value pairs that contain the connection information. You will want to pass this information to a provisioner script to finalize the connection. See below for more information.
    # "driver_volume_type" - The storage driver that the volume is based on.
    # "mount_point_base" - A mount point base name for shared storage.
}
openstack-resource-blockstorage-volume-a.description:
This resource is experimental and may be removed in the future! Feedback
is requested if you find this resource useful or if you find any problems
with it. Creates a general purpose attachment connection to a Block
Storage volume using the OpenStack Block Storage (Cinder) v2 API.
Depending on your Block Storage service configuration, this
resource can assist in attaching a volume to a non-OpenStack resource
such as a bare-metal server or a remote virtual machine in a
different cloud provider. This does not actually attach a volume to an instance. Please use
the `openstack_compute_volume_attach_v2` resource for that.

openstack-resource-compute-floatingip-as.description:
Associate a floating IP to an instance. This can be used instead of the
`floating_ip` options in `openstack_compute_instance_v2`.

openstack-resource-compute-floatingip-v2.body:
resource "openstack_compute_floatingip_v2" "$1" {
    # pool - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
    pool = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Compute client.   A Compute client is needed to create a floating IP that can be used with   a compute instance. If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider   is used. Changing this creates a new floating IP (which may or may not   have a different address).
    region = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "pool" - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
    # "pool" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "pool" - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
    # "address" - The actual floating IP address itself.
    # "pool" - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
    # "fixed_ip" - The fixed IP address corresponding to the floating IP.
    # "pool" - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
    # "instance_id" - UUID of the compute instance associated with the floating IP.
    # "pool" - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
}
openstack-resource-compute-floatingip-v2.description:
Manages a V2 floating IP resource within OpenStack Nova (compute)
that can be used for compute instances.
These are similar to Neutron (networking) floating IP resources,
but only networking floating IPs can be used with load balancers.

openstack-resource-compute-instance-v2.body:
resource "openstack_compute_instance_v2" "$1" {
    # contents - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    contents = ""

    # file - (Required) The absolute path of the destination file.
    file = ""

    # source_type - (Required) The source type of the device. Must be one of   "blank", "image", "volume", or "snapshot". Changing this creates a new   server.
    source_type = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource.
    name = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to create the server instance. If   omitted, the `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this   creates a new server.
    region = ""

    # image_id - (Optional) (Optional; Required if `image_name` is empty and not booting   from a volume. Do not specify if booting from a volume.) The image ID of   the desired image for the server. Changing this creates a new server.
    image_id = ""

    # image_name - (Optional) (Optional; Required if `image_id` is empty and not booting   from a volume. Do not specify if booting from a volume.) The name of the   desired image for the server. Changing this creates a new server.
    image_name = ""

    # flavor_id - (Optional) (Optional; Required if `flavor_name` is empty) The flavor ID of   the desired flavor for the server. Changing this resizes the existing server.
    flavor_id = ""

    # flavor_name - (Optional) (Optional; Required if `flavor_id` is empty) The name of the   desired flavor for the server. Changing this resizes the existing server.
    flavor_name = ""

    # user_data - (Optional) The user data to provide when launching the instance.   Changing this creates a new server.
    user_data = ""

    # security_groups - (Optional) An array of one or more security group names   to associate with the server. Changing this results in adding/removing   security groups from the existing server. *Note*: When attaching the   instance to networks using Ports, place the security groups on the Port   and not the instance.
    security_groups = ""

    # availability_zone - (Optional) The availability zone in which to create   the server. Changing this creates a new server.
    availability_zone = ""

    # network - (Optional) An array of one or more networks to attach to the   instance. The network object structure is documented below. Changing this   creates a new server.
    network = ""

    # metadata - (Optional) Metadata key/value pairs to make available from   within the instance. Changing this updates the existing server metadata.
    metadata = ""

    # config_drive - (Optional) Whether to use the config_drive feature to   configure the instance. Changing this creates a new server.
    config_drive = ""

    # admin_pass - (Optional) The administrative password to assign to the server.   Changing this changes the root password on the existing server.
    admin_pass = ""

    # key_pair - (Optional) The name of a key pair to put on the server. The key   pair must already be created and associated with the tenant's account.   Changing this creates a new server.
    key_pair = ""

    # block_device - (Optional) Configuration of block devices. The block_device   structure is documented below. Changing this creates a new server.   You can specify multiple block devices which will create an instance with   multiple disks. This configuration is very flexible, so please see the   following [reference](http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/block_device_mapping.html)   for more information.
    block_device = ""

    # scheduler_hints - (Optional) Provide the Nova scheduler with hints on how   the instance should be launched. The available hints are described below.
    scheduler_hints = ""

    # personality - (Optional) Customize the personality of an instance by   defining one or more files and their contents. The personality structure   is described below.
    personality = ""

    # stop_before_destroy - (Optional) Whether to try stop instance gracefully   before destroying it, thus giving chance for guest OS daemons to stop correctly.   If instance doesn't stop within timeout, it will be destroyed anyway.
    stop_before_destroy = ""

    # force_delete - (Optional) Whether to force the OpenStack instance to be   forcefully deleted. This is useful for environments that have reclaim / soft   deletion enabled.
    force_delete = ""

    # uuid - (Optional) (Required unless `port`  or `name` is provided) The network UUID to   attach to the server. Changing this creates a new server.
    uuid = ""

    # name - (Optional) (Required unless `uuid` or `port` is provided) The human-readable   name of the network. Changing this creates a new server.
    name = ""

    # port - (Optional) (Required unless `uuid` or `name` is provided) The port UUID of a   network to attach to the server. Changing this creates a new server.
    port = ""

    # access_network - (Optional) Specifies if this network should be used for   provisioning access. Accepts true or false. Defaults to false.
    access_network = ""

    # uuid - (Optional) (Required unless `source_type` is set to `"blank"` ) The UUID of   the image, volume, or snapshot. Changing this creates a new server.
    uuid = ""

    # volume_size - (Optional) The size of the volume to create (in gigabytes). Required   in the following combinations: source=image and destination=volume,   source=blank and destination=local, and source=blank and destination=volume.   Changing this creates a new server.
    volume_size = ""

    # boot_index - (Optional) The boot index of the volume. It defaults to 0.   Changing this creates a new server.
    boot_index = ""

    # destination_type - (Optional) The type that gets created. Possible values   are "volume" and "local". Changing this creates a new server.
    destination_type = ""

    # delete_on_termination - (Optional) Delete the volume / block device upon   termination of the instance. Defaults to false. Changing this creates a   new server.
    delete_on_termination = ""

    # group - (Optional) A UUID of a Server Group. The instance will be placed   into that group.
    group = ""

    # different_host - (Optional) A list of instance UUIDs. The instance will   be scheduled on a different host than all other instances.
    different_host = ""

    # same_host - (Optional) A list of instance UUIDs. The instance will be   scheduled on the same host of those specified.
    same_host = ""

    # query - (Optional) A conditional query that a compute node must pass in   order to host an instance.
    query = ""

    # target_cell - (Optional) The name of a cell to host the instance.
    target_cell = ""

    # build_near_host_ip - (Optional) An IP Address in CIDR form. The instance   will be placed on a compute node that is in the same subnet.
    build_near_host_ip = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "access_ip_v4" - The first detected Fixed IPv4 address _or_ the
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "access_ip_v6" - The first detected Fixed IPv6 address.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "metadata" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "security_groups" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "flavor_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "flavor_name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "network/uuid" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "network/name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "network/port" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "network/fixed_ip_v4" - The Fixed IPv4 address of the Instance on that
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "network/fixed_ip_v6" - The Fixed IPv6 address of the Instance on that
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "network/mac" - The MAC address of the NIC on that network.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "all_metadata" - Contains all instance metadata, even metadata not set
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
}
openstack-resource-compute-instance-v2.description: Manages a V2 VM instance resource within OpenStack.

openstack-resource-compute-secgroup-v2.body:
resource "openstack_compute_secgroup_v2" "$1" {
    # ip_protocol - (Required) The protocol type that will be allowed. Changing this creates a new security group rule.
    ip_protocol = ""

    # to_port - (Required) An integer representing the upper bound of the port range to open. Changing this creates a new security group rule.
    to_port = ""

    # from_port - (Required) An integer representing the lower bound of the port range to open. Changing this creates a new security group rule.
    from_port = ""

    # description - (Required) A description for the security group. Changing this   updates the `description` of an existing security group.
    description = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the security group. Changing this   updates the `name` of an existing security group.
    name = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Compute client.   A Compute client is needed to create a security group. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   security group.
    region = ""

    # rule - (Optional) A rule describing how the security group operates. The   rule object structure is documented below. Changing this updates the   security group rules. As shown in the example above, multiple rule blocks   may be used.
    rule = ""

    # cidr - (Optional) Required if `from_group_id` or `self` is empty. The IP range that will be the source of network traffic to the security group. Use 0.0.0.0/0 to allow all IP addresses. Changing this creates a new security group rule. Cannot be combined with `from_group_id` or `self`.
    cidr = ""

    # from_group_id - (Optional) Required if `cidr` or `self` is empty. The ID of a group from which to forward traffic to the parent group. Changing this creates a new security group rule. Cannot be combined with `cidr` or `self`.
    from_group_id = ""

    # self - (Optional) Required if `cidr` and `from_group_id` is empty. If true, the security group itself will be added as a source to this ingress rule. Cannot be combined with `cidr` or `from_group_id`.
    self = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "self" - (Optional) Required if "cidr" and "from_group_id" is empty. If true, the security group itself will be added as a source to this ingress rule. Cannot be combined with "cidr" or "from_group_id".
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "self" - (Optional) Required if "cidr" and "from_group_id" is empty. If true, the security group itself will be added as a source to this ingress rule. Cannot be combined with "cidr" or "from_group_id".
    # "description" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "self" - (Optional) Required if "cidr" and "from_group_id" is empty. If true, the security group itself will be added as a source to this ingress rule. Cannot be combined with "cidr" or "from_group_id".
    # "rule" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "self" - (Optional) Required if "cidr" and "from_group_id" is empty. If true, the security group itself will be added as a source to this ingress rule. Cannot be combined with "cidr" or "from_group_id".
}
openstack-resource-compute-secgroup-v2.description: Manages a V2 security group resource within OpenStack.

openstack-resource-compute-servergroup-v.body:
resource "openstack_compute_servergroup_v2" "$1" {
    # policies - (Required) The set of policies for the server group. Only two   two policies are available right now, and both are mutually exclusive. See   the Policies section for more information. Changing this creates a new   server group.
    policies = ""

    name = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Compute client.   If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing   this creates a new server group.
    region = ""

    # value_specs - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    value_specs = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "anti-affinity" - All instances/servers launched in this group will be   hosted on different compute nodes.
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "anti-affinity" - All instances/servers launched in this group will be   hosted on different compute nodes.
    # "policies" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "anti-affinity" - All instances/servers launched in this group will be   hosted on different compute nodes.
    # "members" - The instances that are part of this server group.
    # "anti-affinity" - All instances/servers launched in this group will be   hosted on different compute nodes.
}

openstack-resource-compute-volume-attach.body:
resource "openstack_compute_volume_attach_v2" "$1" {

There is a chance that the device specified in Terraform will not be the same device the hypervisor chose. If this happens, Terraform will wish to update the device upon subsequent applying which will cause the volume to be detached and reattached indefinitely. Please use with caution.

There is a chance that the device specified in Terraform will not be the same device the hypervisor chose. If this happens, Terraform will wish to update the device upon subsequent applying which will cause the volume to be detached and reattached indefinitely. Please use with caution.
    # "instance_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "device" - (Optional) The device of the volume attachment (ex: "/dev/vdc"). _NOTE_: Being able to specify a device is dependent upon the hypervisor in use. There is a chance that the device specified in Terraform will not be the same device the hypervisor chose. If this happens, Terraform will wish to update the device upon subsequent applying which will cause the volume to be detached and reattached indefinitely. Please use with caution.
    # "volume_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "device" - (Optional) The device of the volume attachment (ex: "/dev/vdc"). _NOTE_: Being able to specify a device is dependent upon the hypervisor in use. There is a chance that the device specified in Terraform will not be the same device the hypervisor chose. If this happens, Terraform will wish to update the device upon subsequent applying which will cause the volume to be detached and reattached indefinitely. Please use with caution.
    # "device" - See Argument Reference above. _NOTE_: The correctness of this
    # "device" - (Optional) The device of the volume attachment (ex: "/dev/vdc"). _NOTE_: Being able to specify a device is dependent upon the hypervisor in use. There is a chance that the device specified in Terraform will not be the same device the hypervisor chose. If this happens, Terraform will wish to update the device upon subsequent applying which will cause the volume to be detached and reattached indefinitely. Please use with caution.
}
openstack-resource-compute-volume-attach.description:
Attaches a Block Storage Volume to an Instance using the OpenStack
Compute (Nova) v2 API.

openstack-resource-fw-firewall-v1.body:
resource "openstack_fw_firewall_v1" "$1" {
    # description - (Required) A description for the firewall. Changing this   updates the `description` of an existing firewall.
    description = ""

    # policy_id - (Required) The policy resource id for the firewall. Changing   this updates the `policy_id` of an existing firewall.
    policy_id = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the v1 networking client.   A networking client is needed to create a firewall. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   firewall.
    region = ""

    # name - (Optional) A name for the firewall. Changing this   updates the `name` of an existing firewall.
    name = ""

    # admin_state_up - (Optional) Administrative up/down status for the firewall   (must be "true" or "false" if provided - defaults to "true").   Changing this updates the `admin_state_up` of an existing firewall.
    admin_state_up = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The owner of the floating IP. Required if admin wants   to create a firewall for another tenant. Changing this creates a new   firewall.
    tenant_id = ""

    # associated_routers - (Optional) Router(s) to associate this firewall instance   with. Must be a list of strings. Changing this updates the associated routers   of an existing firewall. Conflicts with `no_routers`.
    associated_routers = ""

    # no_routers - (Optional) Should this firewall not be associated with any routers   (must be "true" or "false" if provide - defaults to "false").   Conflicts with `associated_routers`.
    no_routers = ""

    # value_specs - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    value_specs = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "policy_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "description" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "admin_state_up" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "tenant_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "associated_routers" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "no_routers" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
}
openstack-resource-fw-firewall-v1.description: Manages a v1 firewall resource within OpenStack.

openstack-resource-fw-policy-v1.body:
resource "openstack_fw_policy_v1" "$1" {
    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the v1 networking client.   A networking client is needed to create a firewall policy. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   firewall policy.
    region = ""

    # name - (Optional) A name for the firewall policy. Changing this   updates the `name` of an existing firewall policy.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description for the firewall policy. Changing   this updates the `description` of an existing firewall policy.
    description = ""

    # rules - (Optional) An array of one or more firewall rules that comprise   the policy. Changing this results in adding/removing rules from the   existing firewall policy.
    rules = ""

    # audited - (Optional) Audit status of the firewall policy   (must be "true" or "false" if provided - defaults to "false").   This status is set to "false" whenever the firewall policy or any of its   rules are changed. Changing this updates the `audited` status of an existing   firewall policy.
    audited = ""

    # shared - (Optional) Sharing status of the firewall policy (must be "true"   or "false" if provided). If this is "true" the policy is visible to, and   can be used in, firewalls in other tenants. Changing this updates the   `shared` status of an existing firewall policy. Only administrative users   can specify if the policy should be shared.
    shared = ""

    # value_specs - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    value_specs = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "description" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "audited" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "shared" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
}
openstack-resource-fw-policy-v1.description: Manages a v1 firewall policy resource within OpenStack.

openstack-resource-fw-rule-v1.body:
resource "openstack_fw_rule_v1" "$1" {

    action = ""

    protocol = ""

    region = ""

    # name - (Optional) A unique name for the firewall rule. Changing this   updates the `name` of an existing firewall rule.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description for the firewall rule. Changing this   updates the `description` of an existing firewall rule.
    description = ""

    # ip_version - (Optional) IP version, either 4 (default) or 6. Changing this   updates the `ip_version` of an existing firewall rule.
    ip_version = ""

    destination_ip_address = ""

    source_port = ""

    # destination_port - (Optional) The destination port on which the firewall   rule operates. Changing this updates the `destination_port` of an existing   firewall rule.
    destination_port = ""

    # enabled - (Optional) Enabled status for the firewall rule (must be "true"   or "false" if provided - defaults to "true"). Changing this updates the   `enabled` status of an existing firewall rule.
    enabled = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The owner of the firewall rule. Required if admin   wants to create a firewall rule for another tenant. Changing this creates a   new firewall rule.
    tenant_id = ""

    # value_specs - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    value_specs = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "description" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "protocol" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "action" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "ip_version" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "source_ip_address" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "destination_ip_address" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "source_port" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "destination_port" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "enabled" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "tenant_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
