openstack-resource-images-image-v2.body:
resource "openstack_images_image_v2" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the image.
    name = ""

    # disk_format - (Required) The disk format. Must be one of  "ami", "ari", "aki", "vhd", "vmdk", "raw", "qcow2", "vdi", "iso".
    disk_format = ""

    # container_format - (Required) The container format. Must be one of  "ami", "ari", "aki", "bare", "ovf".
    container_format = ""

    # local_file_path - (Optional) This is the filepath of the raw image file  that will be uploaded to Glance. Conflicts with `image_source_url`.
    local_file_path = ""

    # image_cache_path - (Optional) This is the directory where the images will  be downloaded. Images will be stored with a filename corresponding to  the url's md5 hash. Defaults to "$HOME/.terraform/image_cache"
    image_cache_path = ""

    # image_source_url - (Optional) This is the url of the raw image that will  be downloaded in the `image_cache_path` before being uploaded to Glance.  Glance is able to download image from internet but the `gophercloud` library  does not yet provide a way to do so.  Conflicts with `local_file_path`.
    image_source_url = ""

    # min_disk_gb - (Optional) Amount of disk space (in GB) required to boot image.  Defaults to 0.
    min_disk_gb = ""

    # min_ram_mb - (Optional) Amount of ram (in MB) required to boot image.  Defauts to 0.
    min_ram_mb = ""

    # properties - (Optional) A map of key/value pairs to set freeform   information about an image.
    properties = ""

    # protected - (Optional) If true, image will not be deletable.  Defaults to false.
    protected = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Glance client.   A Glance client is needed to create an Image that can be used with   a compute instance. If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider   is used. Changing this creates a new Image.
    region = ""

    # tags - (Optional) The tags of the image. It must be a list of strings.   At this time, it is not possible to delete all tags of an image.
    tags = ""

    # visibility - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    visibility = ""

    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.

    # "file" - the trailing path after the glance

    # "id" - A unique ID assigned by Glance.

    # "metadata" - The metadata associated with the image.

    # "min_disk_gb" - See Argument Reference above.

    # "properties" - See Argument Reference above.

openstack-resource-lb-monitor-v1.body:
resource "openstack_lb_monitor_v1" "$1" {
    # max_retries - (Required) Number of permissible ping failures before changing   the member's status to INACTIVE. Must be a number between 1 and 10. Changing   this updates the max_retries of the existing monitor.
    max_retries = ""

    # timeout - (Required) Maximum number of seconds for a monitor to wait for a   ping reply before it times out. The value must be less than the delay value.   Changing this updates the timeout of the existing monitor.
    timeout = ""

    # delay - (Required) The time, in seconds, between sending probes to members.   Changing this creates a new monitor.
    delay = ""

    # type - (Required) The type of probe, which is PING, TCP, HTTP, or HTTPS,   that is sent by the monitor to verify the member state. Changing this   creates a new monitor.
    type = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create an LB monitor. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   LB monitor.
    region = ""

    # url_path - (Optional) Required for HTTP(S) types. URI path that will be   accessed if monitor type is HTTP or HTTPS. Changing this updates the   url_path of the existing monitor.
    url_path = ""

    # http_method - (Optional) Required for HTTP(S) types. The HTTP method used   for requests by the monitor. If this attribute is not specified, it defaults   to "GET". Changing this updates the http_method of the existing monitor.
    http_method = ""

    # expected_codes - (Optional) equired for HTTP(S) types. Expected HTTP codes   for a passing HTTP(S) monitor. You can either specify a single status like   "200", or a range like "200-202". Changing this updates the expected_codes   of the existing monitor.
    expected_codes = ""

    # admin_state_up - (Optional) The administrative state of the monitor.   Acceptable values are "true" and "false". Changing this value updates the   state of the existing monitor.
    admin_state_up = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The owner of the monitor. Required if admin wants to   create a monitor for another tenant. Changing this creates a new monitor.
    tenant_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.

    # max_retries - (Required) Number of permissible ping failures before   changing the member's status to INACTIVE. Must be a number between 1   and 10..
    max_retries = ""

    timeout = ""

    # delay - (Required) The time, in seconds, between sending probes to members.
    delay = ""

    # type - (Required) The type of probe, which is PING, TCP, HTTP, or HTTPS,   that is sent by the load balancer to verify the member state. Changing this   creates a new monitor.
    type = ""

    # pool_id - (Required) The id of the pool that this monitor will be assigned to.
    pool_id = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create an . If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   monitor.
    region = ""

    name = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) Required for admins. The UUID of the tenant who owns   the monitor.  Only administrative users can specify a tenant UUID   other than their own. Changing this creates a new monitor.
    tenant_id = ""

    # url_path - (Optional) Required for HTTP(S) types. URI path that will be   accessed if monitor type is HTTP or HTTPS.
    url_path = ""

    # http_method - (Optional) Required for HTTP(S) types. The HTTP method used  for requests by the monitor. If this attribute is not specified, it  defaults to "GET".
    http_method = ""

    # expected_codes - (Optional) Required for HTTP(S) types. Expected HTTP codes   for a passing HTTP(S) monitor. You can either specify a single status like   "200", or a range like "200-202".

resource "openstack_lb_pool_v1" "$1" {

    admin_state_up = ""

    port = ""

    # address - (Required) The IP address of the member. Changing this creates a new member.
    address = ""

    # lb_method - (Required) The algorithm used to distribute load between the   members of the pool. The current specification supports 'ROUND_ROBIN' and   'LEAST_CONNECTIONS' as valid values for this attribute.
    lb_method = ""

    # subnet_id - (Required) The network on which the members of the pool will be   located. Only members that are on this network can be added to the pool.   Changing this creates a new pool.
    subnet_id = ""

    # protocol - (Required)  The protocol used by the pool members, you can use either 'TCP, 'HTTP', or 'HTTPS'. Changing this creates a new pool.
    protocol = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the pool. Changing this updates the name of   the existing pool.
    name = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create an LB pool. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   LB pool.
    region = ""

    # lb_provider - (Optional) The backend load balancing provider. For example:   `haproxy`, `F5`, etc.
    lb_provider = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The owner of the pool. Required if admin wants to   create a pool member for another tenant. Changing this creates a new pool.

    # monitor_ids - (Optional) A list of IDs of monitors to associate with the   pool.
    monitor_ids = ""

    member = ""

openstack-resource-lb-pool-v2.body:
resource "openstack_lb_pool_v2" "$1" {
    # type - (Required) The type of persistence mode. The current specification   supports SOURCE_IP, HTTP_COOKIE, and APP_COOKIE.
    type = ""

    # lb_method - (Required) The load balancing algorithm to   distribute traffic to the pool's members. Must be one of   ROUND_ROBIN, LEAST_CONNECTIONS, or SOURCE_IP.
    lb_method = ""

    # protocol - (Required) The protocol - can either be TCP, HTTP or HTTPS.   Changing this creates a new pool.
    protocol = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create an . If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   pool.
    region = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) Required for admins. The UUID of the tenant who owns   the pool.  Only administrative users can specify a tenant UUID   other than their own. Changing this creates a new pool.
    tenant_id = ""

    # name - (Optional) Human-readable name for the pool.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) Human-readable description for the pool.
    description = ""

    # loadbalancer_id - (Optional) The load balancer on which to provision this   pool. Changing this creates a new pool.   Note:  One of LoadbalancerID or ListenerID must be provided.
    loadbalancer_id = ""

    # listener_id - (Optional) The Listener on which the members of the pool   will be associated with. Changing this creates a new pool. 	Note:  One of LoadbalancerID or ListenerID must be provided.
    listener_id = ""

    # persistence - (Optional) Omit this field to prevent session persistence.  Indicates   whether connections in the same session will be processed by the same Pool   member or not. Changing this creates a new pool.
    persistence = ""

    # admin_state_up - (Optional) The administrative state of the pool.   A valid value is true (UP) or false (DOWN).
    admin_state_up = ""

    # cookie_name - (Optional) The name of the cookie if persistence mode is set   appropriately. Required if `type = APP_COOKIE`.
    cookie_name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The unique ID for the pool.
    # "cookie_name" - (Optional) The name of the cookie if persistence mode is set   appropriately. Required if "type = APP_COOKIE".

    # "persistence" - See Argument Reference above.

    # "admin_state_up" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "cookie_name" - (Optional) The name of the cookie if persistence mode is set   appropriately. Required if "type = APP_COOKIE".
}

resource "openstack_lb_vip_v1" "$1" {

    type = ""

    pool_id = ""

    # port - (Required) The port on which to listen for client traffic. Changing   this creates a new vip.
    port = ""

    # protocol - (Required)  The protocol - can be either 'TCP, 'HTTP', or   HTTPS'. Changing this creates a new vip.
    protocol = ""

    # subnet_id - (Required) The network on which to allocate the vip's address. A   tenant can only create vips on networks authorized by policy (e.g. networks   that belong to them or networks that are shared). Changing this creates a   new vip.
    subnet_id = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the vip. Changing this updates the name of   the existing vip.
    name = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create a VIP. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   VIP.
    region = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The owner of the vip. Required if admin wants to   create a vip member for another tenant. Changing this creates a new vip.
    tenant_id = ""

    # address - (Optional)  The IP address of the vip. Changing this creates a new   vip.
    address = ""

    description = ""

    # persistence - (Optional) Omit this field to prevent session persistence.   The persistence object structure is documented below. Changing this updates   the persistence of the existing vip.
    persistence = ""

    # conn_limit - (Optional) The maximum number of connections allowed for the   vip. Default is -1, meaning no limit. Changing this updates the conn_limit   of the existing vip.
    conn_limit = ""

    # floating_ip - (Optional) A *Networking* Floating IP that will be associated   with the vip. The Floating IP must be provisioned already.
    floating_ip = ""

    # admin_state_up - (Optional) The administrative state of the vip.   Acceptable values are "true" and "false". Changing this value updates the   state of the existing vip.

openstack-resource-networking-floatingip.body:
resource "openstack_networking_floatingip_v2" "$1" {
    # pool - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
    pool = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create a floating IP that can be used with   another networking resource, such as a load balancer. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   floating IP (which may or may not have a different address).
    region = ""

    # port_id - (Optional) ID of an existing port with at least one IP address to   associate with this floating IP.
    port_id = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The target tenant ID in which to allocate the floating   IP, if you specify this together with a port_id, make sure the target port   belongs to the same tenant. Changing this creates a new floating IP (which   may or may not have a different address)
    tenant_id = ""

    # fixed_ip - (Optional) Fixed IP of the port to associate with this floating IP. Required if the port has multiple fixed IPs.
    fixed_ip = ""

    # value_specs - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    value_specs = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "pool" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "address" - The actual floating IP address itself.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "port_id" - ID of associated port.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "tenant_id" - the ID of the tenant in which to create the floating IP.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "fixed_ip" - The fixed IP which the floating IP maps to.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
}
openstack-resource-networking-floatingip.description:
Manages a V2 floating IP resource within OpenStack Neutron (networking)
that can be used for load balancers.
These are similar to Nova (compute) floating IP resources,
but only compute floating IPs can be used with compute instances.

openstack-resource-networking-port-v2.body:

    network_id = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 networking client.   A networking client is needed to create a port. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   port.
    region = ""

    # name - (Optional) A unique name for the port. Changing this   updates the `name` of an existing port.
    name = ""

    # admin_state_up - (Optional) Administrative up/down status for the port   (must be "true" or "false" if provided). Changing this updates the   `admin_state_up` of an existing port.
    admin_state_up = ""

    # mac_address - (Optional) Specify a specific MAC address for the port. Changing   this creates a new port.
    mac_address = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The owner of the Port. Required if admin wants   to create a port for another tenant. Changing this creates a new port.
    tenant_id = ""

    # device_owner - (Optional) The device owner of the Port. Changing this creates   a new port.
    device_owner = ""

    # security_group_ids - (Optional) Conflicts with `no_security_groups`) A list   of security group IDs to apply to the port. The security groups must be   specified by ID and not name (as opposed to how they are configured with   the Compute Instance).
    security_group_ids = ""

    # no_security_groups - (Optional) Conflicts with `security_group_ids`) If set to   `true`, then no security groups are applied to the port. If set to `false` and   no `security_group_ids` are specified, then the Port will yield to the default   behavior of the Networking service, which is to usually apply the "default"   security group.
    no_security_groups = ""

    # device_id - (Optional) The ID of the device attached to the port. Changing this   creates a new port.
    device_id = ""

    # fixed_ip - (Optional) An array of desired IPs for this port. The structure is   described below.
    fixed_ip = ""

    # allowed_address_pairs - (Optional) An IP/MAC Address pair of additional IP   addresses that can be active on this port. The structure is described   below.
    allowed_address_pairs = ""

    # value_specs - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    value_specs = ""

    # ip_address - (Optional) IP address desired in the subnet for this port. If you don't specify `ip_address`, an available IP address from the specified subnet will be allocated to this port. This field will not be populated if it is left blank. To retrieve the assigned IP address, use the `all_fixed_ips` attribute.
    ip_address = ""

    # mac_address - (Optional) The additional MAC address.
    mac_address = ""

    # Exported Attributes

    # "admin_state_up" - See Argument Reference above.

    # "mac_address" - (Optional) The additional MAC address.
    # "device_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "mac_address" - (Optional) The additional MAC address.

openstack-resource-networking-router-v2.body:
resource "openstack_networking_router_v2" "$1" {
    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 networking client.   A networking client is needed to create a router. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   router.
    region = ""

    # name - (Optional) A unique name for the router. Changing this   updates the `name` of an existing router.
    name = ""

    # admin_state_up - (Optional) Administrative up/down status for the router   (must be "true" or "false" if provided). Changing this updates the   `admin_state_up` of an existing router.
    admin_state_up = ""

    # distributed - (Optional) Indicates whether or not to create a   distributed router. The default policy setting in Neutron restricts   usage of this property to administrative users only.
    distributed = ""

    # external_gateway - (Optional) The network UUID of an external gateway for   the router. A router with an external gateway is required if any compute   instances or load balancers will be using floating IPs. Changing this   updates the `external_gateway` of an existing router.
    external_gateway = ""

    # enable_snat - (Optional) Enable Source NAT for the router.   (must be "true" or "false" if provided). An `external_gateway` has to be    set in order to set the `enable_snat` property. Changing this   updates the `enable_snat` of an existing router.
    enable_snat = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The owner of the floating IP. Required if admin wants   to create a router for another tenant. Changing this creates a new router.
    tenant_id = ""

    # value_specs - (Optional) Map of additional driver-specific options.
    value_specs = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID of the router.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional driver-specific options.
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional driver-specific options.
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional driver-specific options.
    # "admin_state_up" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional driver-specific options.
    # "external_gateway" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional driver-specific options.
    # "enable_snat" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional driver-specific options.
    # "tenant_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional driver-specific options.
    # "value_specs" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional driver-specific options.
}

openstack-resource-networking-secgroup-r.description:
Manages a V2 neutron security group rule resource within OpenStack.
Unlike Nova security groups, neutron separates the group from the rules
and also allows an admin to target a specific tenant_id.

openstack-resource-networking-subnet-v2.body:
resource "openstack_networking_subnet_v2" "$1" {
    # next_hop - (Required) The next hop in the route.
    next_hop = ""

    # destination_cidr - (Required) The destination CIDR.
    destination_cidr = ""

    # end - (Required) The ending address.
    end = ""

    # start - (Required) The starting address.
    start = ""

    # cidr - (Required) CIDR representing IP range for this subnet, based on IP   version. Changing this creates a new subnet.
    cidr = ""

    # network_id - (Required) The UUID of the parent network. Changing this   creates a new subnet.
    network_id = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create a Neutron subnet. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   subnet.
    region = ""

    # ip_version - (Optional) IP version, either 4 (default) or 6. Changing this creates a   new subnet.
    ip_version = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the subnet. Changing this updates the name of   the existing subnet.
    name = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The owner of the subnet. Required if admin wants to   create a subnet for another tenant. Changing this creates a new subnet.
    tenant_id = ""

    # allocation_pools - (Optional) An array of sub-ranges of CIDR available for   dynamic allocation to ports. The allocation_pool object structure is   documented below. Changing this creates a new subnet.
    allocation_pools = ""

    # gateway_ip - (Optional)  Default gateway used by devices in this subnet.   Leaving this blank and not setting `no_gateway` will cause a default   gateway of `.1` to be used. Changing this updates the gateway IP of the   existing subnet.
    gateway_ip = ""

    # no_gateway - (Optional) Do not set a gateway IP on this subnet. Changing   this removes or adds a default gateway IP of the existing subnet.
    no_gateway = ""

    # enable_dhcp - (Optional) The administrative state of the network.   Acceptable values are "true" and "false". Changing this value enables or   disables the DHCP capabilities of the existing subnet. Defaults to true.
    enable_dhcp = ""

    # dns_nameservers - (Optional) An array of DNS name server names used by hosts   in this subnet. Changing this updates the DNS name servers for the existing   subnet.
    dns_nameservers = ""

    # host_routes - (Optional) An array of routes that should be used by devices   with IPs from this subnet (not including local subnet route). The host_route   object structure is documented below. Changing this updates the host routes   for the existing subnet.
    host_routes = ""

    # value_specs - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    value_specs = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "next_hop" - (Required) The next hop in the route.
    # "network_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "next_hop" - (Required) The next hop in the route.
    # "cidr" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "next_hop" - (Required) The next hop in the route.
    # "ip_version" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "next_hop" - (Required) The next hop in the route.
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "next_hop" - (Required) The next hop in the route.
    # "tenant_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "next_hop" - (Required) The next hop in the route.
    # "allocation_pools" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "next_hop" - (Required) The next hop in the route.
    # "gateway_ip" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "next_hop" - (Required) The next hop in the route.
    # "enable_dhcp" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "next_hop" - (Required) The next hop in the route.
    # "dns_nameservers" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "next_hop" - (Required) The next hop in the route.
    # "host_routes" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "next_hop" - (Required) The next hop in the route.
}

    # container_write - (Optional) Sets an ACL that grants write access.   Changing this updates the access control list write access.
    container_write = ""

    # metadata - (Optional) Custom key/value pairs to associate with the container.   Changing this updates the existing container metadata.
    metadata = ""

    # content_type - (Optional) The MIME type for the container. Changing this   updates the MIME type.
    content_type = ""

    # Exported Attributes

    # "content_type" - (Optional) The MIME type for the container. Changing this   updates the MIME type.
    # "content_type" - See Argument Reference above.

opsgenie-resource-user.body:
resource "opsgenie_user" "$1" {
    # role - (Required) The Role assigned to the User. Either a built-in such as 'Owner', 'Admin' or 'User' - or the name of a custom role.
    role = ""

    # full_name - (Required) The Full Name of the User.
    full_name = ""

    # username - (Required) The email address associated with this user. OpsGenie defines that this must not be longer than 100 characters.
    username = ""

    # locale - (Optional) Location information for the user. Please look at [Supported Locale Ids](https://www.opsgenie.com/docs/miscellaneous/supported-locales) for available locales - Defaults to "en_US".
    locale = ""

    # timezone - (Optional) Timezone information of the user. Please look at [Supported Timezone Ids](https://www.opsgenie.com/docs/miscellaneous/supported-timezone-ids) for available timezones - Defaults to "America/New_York".
    timezone = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the OpsGenie User.
    # "timezone" - (Optional) Timezone information of the user. Please look at [Supported Timezone Ids](https://www.opsgenie.com/docs/miscellaneous/supported-timezone-ids) for available timezones - Defaults to "America/New_York".
}

ovh-datasource-publiccloud-region.body:
data "publiccloud_region" "$1" {
    # region - (Required) The name of the region associated with the public cloud project.
    region = ""

    # project_id - (Required) The id of the public cloud project. If omitted,   the `OVH_PROJECT_ID` environment variable is used.

In addition, the following attributes are exported:

    # "region" - (Required) The name of the region associated with the public cloud project.
    # "services" - The list of public cloud services running within the region
    # "name" - the name of the public cloud service
    # "region" - (Required) The name of the region associated with the public cloud project.
    # "status" - the status of the service
    # "region" - (Required) The name of the region associated with the public cloud project.
    # "region" - (Required) The name of the region associated with the public cloud project.
}

Use this data source to retrieve information about a region associated with a
public cloud project. The region must be associated with the project.

are exported:

ovh-resource-publiccloud-private-network.body:
resource "publiccloud_private_network" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the network.
    name = ""

    # project_id - (Required) The id of the public cloud project. If omitted,   the `OVH_PROJECT_ID` environment variable is used.
    project_id = ""

    vlan_id = ""

    # regions - (Optional) an array of valid OVH public cloud region ID in which the network  will be available. Ex.: "GRA1". Defaults to all public cloud regions.
    regions = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "project_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "regions" - an array of valid OVH public cloud region ID in which the network  will be available. Ex.: "GRA1". Defaults to all public cloud regions.
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "regions" - an array of valid OVH public cloud region ID in which the network  will be available. Ex.: "GRA1". Defaults to all public cloud regions.
    # "vlan_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "regions" - an array of valid OVH public cloud region ID in which the network  will be available. Ex.: "GRA1". Defaults to all public cloud regions.
    # "regions" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "regions" - an array of valid OVH public cloud region ID in which the network  will be available. Ex.: "GRA1". Defaults to all public cloud regions.
    # "regions_status" - A map representing the status of the network per region.
    # "regions" - an array of valid OVH public cloud region ID in which the network  will be available. Ex.: "GRA1". Defaults to all public cloud regions.
    # "regions_status/region" - The id of the region.
    # "regions" - an array of valid OVH public cloud region ID in which the network  will be available. Ex.: "GRA1". Defaults to all public cloud regions.
    # "regions_status/status" - The status of the network in the region.
    # "regions" - an array of valid OVH public cloud region ID in which the network  will be available. Ex.: "GRA1". Defaults to all public cloud regions.
    # "status" - the status of the network. should be normally set to 'ACTIVE'.
    # "regions" - an array of valid OVH public cloud region ID in which the network  will be available. Ex.: "GRA1". Defaults to all public cloud regions.
    # "type" - the type of the network. Either 'private' or 'public'. 
    # "regions" - an array of valid OVH public cloud region ID in which the network  will be available. Ex.: "GRA1". Defaults to all public cloud regions.
}
ovh-resource-publiccloud-private-network.description: Creates a private network in a public cloud project.

ovh-resource-publiccloud-private-network.body:
resource "publiccloud_private_network_subnet" "$1" {
    # network - (Required) Global network in CIDR format.  Changing this value recreates the subnet
    network = ""

    # end - (Required) Last ip for this region.  Changing this value recreates the subnet.
    end = ""

    # start - (Required) First ip for this region.  Changing this value recreates the subnet.
    start = ""

    # network_id - (Required) The id of the network.  Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    network_id = ""

    # project_id - (Required) The id of the public cloud project. If omitted,   the `OVH_PROJECT_ID` environment variable is used. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    project_id = ""

    # dhcp - (Optional) Enable DHCP.  Changing this forces a new resource to be created. Defaults to false. _
    dhcp = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which the network subnet will be created.  Ex.: "GRA1". Changing this value recreates the resource.
    region = ""

    # no_gateway - (Optional) Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    no_gateway = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "project_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "network_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "dhcp_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "start" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "end" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "network" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "no_gateway" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "cidr" - Ip Block representing the subnet cidr.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "ip_pools" - List of ip pools allocated in the subnet.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "ip_pools/network" - Global network with cidr.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "ip_pools/region" - Region where this subnet is created.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "ip_pools/dhcp" - DHCP enabled.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "ip_pools/end" - Last ip for this region.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
    # "ip_pools/start" - First ip for this region.
    # "no_gateway" - Set to true if you don't want to set a default gateway IP.  Changing this value recreates the resource. Defaults to false.
}
ovh-resource-publiccloud-private-network.description: Creates a subnet in a private network of a public cloud project.

ovh-resource-publiccloud-user.body:
resource "publiccloud_user" "$1" {
    # project_id - (Required) The id of the public cloud project. If omitted,   the `OVH_PROJECT_ID` environment variable is used.

    # "description" - A description associated with the user.

pagerduty-datasource-escalation-policy.description: Use this data source to get information about a specific [escalation policy][1] that you can use for other PagerDuty resources.

pagerduty-datasource-schedule.description: Use this data source to get information about a specific [schedule][1] that you can use for other PagerDuty resources.

pagerduty-datasource-user.description: Use this data source to get information about a specific [user][1] that you can use for other Pager Duty resources.

pagerduty-datasource-vendor.body:
data "pagerduty_vendor" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The vendor name to use to find a vendor in the PagerDuty API.
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "name" - The short name of the found vendor.
    # "type" - The generic service type for this vendor.
}
pagerduty-datasource-vendor.description: Use this data source to get information about a specific [vendor][1] that you can use for a service integration (e.g Amazon Cloudwatch, Splunk, Datadog).

pagerduty-resource-addon.body:
resource "pagerduty_addon" "$1" {
    # src - (Required) The source URL to display in a frame in the PagerDuty UI. `HTTPS` is required.
    src = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the add-on.
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the add-on.
}
pagerduty-resource-addon.description: With [add-ons](https://v2.developer.pagerduty.com/v2/page/api-reference#!/Add-ons/get_addons), third-party developers can write their own add-ons to PagerDuty's UI. Given a configuration containing a src parameter, that URL will be embedded in an iframe on a page that's available to users from a drop-down menu.

pagerduty-resource-escalation_policy.body:
resource "pagerduty_escalation_policy" "$1" {
    # id - (Required) A target ID
    id = ""

    # targets - (Required) A target block. Target blocks documented below.
    targets = ""

    # escalation_delay_in_minutes - (Required) The number of minutes before an unacknowledged incident escalates away from this rule.
    escalation_delay_in_minutes = ""

    # rule - (Required) An Escalation rule block. Escalation rules documented below.
    rule = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the escalation policy.
    name = ""

    # teams - (Optional) Teams associated with the policy. Account must have the `teams` ability to use this parameter.
    teams = ""

    # description - (Optional) A human-friendly description of the escalation policy.
    description = ""

    # num_loops - (Optional) The number of times the escalation policy will repeat after reaching the end of its escalation.
    num_loops = ""

    # type - (Optional) Can be `user`, `schedule`, `user_reference` or `schedule_reference`. Defaults to `user_reference`
    type = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the escalation policy.
}
pagerduty-resource-escalation_policy.description: An [escalation policy](https://v2.developer.pagerduty.com/v2/page/api-reference#!/Escalation_Policies/get_escalation_policies) determines what user or schedule will be notified first, second, and so on when an incident is triggered. Escalation policies are used by one or more services.

pagerduty-resource-maintenance-window.body:
resource "pagerduty_maintenance_window" "$1" {
    # services - (Required) A list of service IDs to include in the maintenance window.
    services = ""

    # end_time - (Required) The maintenance window's end time. This is when the services will start creating incidents again. This date must be in the future and after the `start_time`.
    end_time = ""

    # start_time - (Required) The maintenance window's start time. This is when the services will stop creating incidents. If this date is in the past, it will be updated to be the current time.
    start_time = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description for the maintenance window.
    description = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the maintenance window.
}
pagerduty-resource-maintenance-window.description: A [maintenance window](https://v2.developer.pagerduty.com/v2/page/api-reference#!/Maintenance_Windows/get_maintenance_windows) is used to temporarily disable one or more services for a set period of time. No incidents will be triggered and no notifications will be received while a service is disabled by a maintenance window. Maintenance windows are specified to start at a certain time and end after they have begun. Once started, a maintenance window cannot be deleted; it can only be ended immediately to re-enable the service.

pagerduty-resource-schedule.body:
resource "pagerduty_schedule" "$1" {
    # duration_seconds - (Required) The duration of the restriction in `seconds`.
    duration_seconds = ""

    # start_time_of_day - (Required) The start time in `HH:mm:ss` format.
    start_time_of_day = ""

    # type - (Required) Can be `daily_restriction` or `weekly_restriction`
    type = ""

    # users - (Required) The ordered list of users on this layer. The position of the user on the list determines their order in the layer.
    users = ""

    # rotation_turn_length_seconds - (Required) The duration of each on-call shift in `seconds`.
    rotation_turn_length_seconds = ""

    # rotation_virtual_start - (Required) The effective start time of the schedule layer. This can be before the start time of the schedule.
    rotation_virtual_start = ""

    # start - (Required) The start time of the schedule layer.
    start = ""

    # layer - (Required) A schedule layer block. Schedule layers documented below.
    layer = ""

    # time_zone - (Required) The time zone of the schedule (e.g Europe/Berlin).
    time_zone = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the escalation policy.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of the schedule
    description = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the schedule layer.
    name = ""

    # end - (Optional) The end time of the schedule layer. If not specified, the layer does not end.
    end = ""

    # restriction - (Optional) A schedule layer restriction block. Restriction blocks documented below.
    restriction = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the schedule
}
pagerduty-resource-schedule.description: A [schedule](https://v2.developer.pagerduty.com/v2/page/api-reference#!/Schedules/get_schedules) determines the time periods that users are on call. Only on-call users are eligible to receive notifications from incidents.

pagerduty-resource-service.body:
resource "pagerduty_service" "$1" {
    # escalation_policy - (Required) The escalation policy used by this service.
    escalation_policy = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the service.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A human-friendly description of the escalation policy.
    description = ""

    # auto_resolve_timeout - (Optional) Time in seconds that an incident is automatically resolved if left open for that long. Disabled if not set.
    auto_resolve_timeout = ""

    # acknowledgement_timeout - (Optional) Time in seconds that an incident changes to the Triggered State after being Acknowledged. Disabled if not set.
    acknowledgement_timeout = ""

    # type - (Optional) The type of incident urgency: `constant` or `use_support_hours` (when depending on specific suppor hours; see `support_hours`).
    type = ""

    # during_support_hours - (Optional) Incidents' urgency during support hours.
    during_support_hours = ""

    # outside_support_hours - (Optional) Incidents' urgency outside of support hours.
    outside_support_hours = ""

    # type - (Optional) The type of support hours. Can be `fixed_time_per_day`.
    type = ""

    # time_zone - (Optional) The time zone for the support hours.
    time_zone = ""

    # days_of_week - (Optional) Array of days of week as integers.
    days_of_week = ""

    # start_time - (Optional) The support hours' starting time of day.
    start_time = ""

    # end_time - (Optional) The support hours' ending time of day.
    end_time = ""

    # type - (Optional) The type of scheduled action. Currently, this must be set to `urgency_change`.
    type = ""

    # at - (Optional) Represents when scheduled action will occur.
    at = ""

    # name - (Optional) Designates either the start or the end of the scheduled action. Can be `support_hours_start` or `support_hours_end`.
    name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the service.
    # "last_incident_timestamp"- Last incident timestamp of the service
    # "created_at"- Creation timestmap of the service
    # "status"- The status of the service
}
pagerduty-resource-service.description: A [service](https://v2.developer.pagerduty.com/v2/page/api-reference#!/Services/get_services) represents something you monitor (like a web service, email service, or database service). It is a container for related incidents that associates them with escalation policies.

pagerduty-resource-service-integration.body:
resource "pagerduty_service_integration" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) The name of the service integration.
    name = ""

    # type - (Optional) The service type. Can be: `aws_cloudwatch_inbound_integration`, `cloudkick_inbound_integration`, `event_transformer_api_inbound_integration`, `generic_email_inbound_integration`, `generic_events_api_inbound_integration`, `keynote_inbound_integration`, `nagios_inbound_integration`, `pingdom_inbound_integration`or `sql_monitor_inbound_integration`. **Note:** This is meant for **generic** service integrations. To integrate with a **vendor** (e.g Datadog or Amazon Cloudwatch) use the `vendor` field instead.
    type = ""

    # service - (Optional) The ID of the service the integration should belong to.
    service = ""

    # vendor - (Optional) The ID of the vendor the integration should integrate with (e.g Datadog or Amazon Cloudwatch). **Note:** You can use the `pagerduty_vendor` data source to locate the appropriate vendor ID. ## Attributes Reference
    vendor = ""

    # id - (Optional) The ID of the service integration.
    id = ""

    # vendor - (Optional) The ID of the vendor the integration should integrate with (e.g Datadog or Amazon Cloudwatch). **Note:** You can use the `pagerduty_vendor` data source to locate the appropriate vendor ID. ## Attributes Reference
    vendor = ""

    # integration_key - (Optional) This is the unique key used to route events to this integration when received via the PagerDuty Events API.
    integration_key = ""

    # vendor - (Optional) The ID of the vendor the integration should integrate with (e.g Datadog or Amazon Cloudwatch). **Note:** You can use the `pagerduty_vendor` data source to locate the appropriate vendor ID. ## Attributes Reference
    vendor = ""

    # integration_email - (Optional) This is the unique fully-qualified email address used for routing emails to this integration for processing.
    integration_email = ""

    # vendor - (Optional) The ID of the vendor the integration should integrate with (e.g Datadog or Amazon Cloudwatch). **Note:** You can use the `pagerduty_vendor` data source to locate the appropriate vendor ID. ## Attributes Reference
    vendor = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
pagerduty-resource-service-integration.description: A [service integration](https://v2.developer.pagerduty.com/v2/page/api-reference#!/Services/post_services_id_integrations) is an integration that belongs to a service.

pagerduty-resource-team.body:
resource "pagerduty_team" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the group.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A human-friendly description of the team.
    description = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the team.
}
pagerduty-resource-team.description: A [team](https://v2.developer.pagerduty.com/v2/page/api-reference#!/Teams/get_teams) is a collection of users and escalation policies that represent a group of people within an organization. The account must have the `teams` ability to use the following resource.

pagerduty-resource-team-membership.body:
resource "pagerduty_team_membership" "$1" {
    # team_id - (Required) The ID of the team in which the user will belong.
    team_id = ""

    # user_id - (Required) The ID of the user to add to the team.
    user_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "user_id" - The ID of the user belonging to the team.
    # "team_id" - The team ID the user belongs to.
}
pagerduty-resource-team-membership.description: A [team membership](https://v2.developer.pagerduty.com/v2/page/api-reference#!/Teams/put_teams_id_users_user_id) manages memberships within a team.

pagerduty-resource-user.body:
resource "pagerduty_user" "$1" {
    # email - (Required) The user's email address.
    email = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the user.
    name = ""

    # color - (Optional) The schedule color for the user.
    color = ""

    # role - (Optional) The user role. Account must have the `read_only_users` ability to set a user as a `read_only_user`. Can be `admin`, `limited_user`, `owner`, `read_only_user`, `team_responder` or `user`
    role = ""

    # job_title - (Optional) The user's title.
    job_title = ""

    # teams - (Optional) A list of teams the user should belong to.
    teams = ""

    # description - (Optional) A human-friendly description of the user.
    description = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the user.
    # "avatar_url" - The URL of the user's avatar.
    # "time_zone" - The timezone of the user
    # "html_url" - URL at which the entity is uniquely displayed in the Web app
    # "invitation_sent" - If true, the user has an outstanding invitation.
}
pagerduty-resource-user.description: A [user](https://v2.developer.pagerduty.com/v2/page/api-reference#!/Users/get_users) is a member of a PagerDuty account that have the ability to interact with incidents and other data on the account.

postgresql-resource-postgresql_database.body:
resource "postgresql_database" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the database. Must be unique on the PostgreSQL server instance where it is configured.
    name = ""

    # owner - (Optional) The role name of the user who will own the database, or `DEFAULT` to use the default (namely, the user executing the command). To create a database owned by another role or to change the owner of an existing database, you must be a direct or indirect member of the specified role, or the username in the provider is a superuser.
    owner = ""

    # tablespace_name - (Optional) The name of the tablespace that will be associated with the database, or `DEFAULT` to use the template database's tablespace.  This tablespace will be the default tablespace used for objects created in this database.
    tablespace_name = ""

    # connection_limit - (Optional) How many concurrent connections can be established to this database. `-1` (the default) means no limit.
    connection_limit = ""

    # allow_connections - (Optional) If `false` then no one can connect to this database. The default is `true`, allowing connections (except as restricted by other mechanisms, such as `GRANT` or `REVOKE CONNECT`).
    allow_connections = ""

    # is_template - (Optional) If `true`, then this database can be cloned by any user with `CREATEDB` privileges; if `false` (the default), then only superusers or the owner of the database can clone it.
    is_template = ""

    # template - (Optional) The name of the template database from which to create the database, or `DEFAULT` to use the default template (`template0`).  NOTE: the default in Terraform is `template0`, not `template1`.  Changing this value will force the creation of a new resource as this value can only be changed when a database is created.
    template = ""

    # encoding - (Optional) Character set encoding to use in the database. Specify a string constant (e.g. `UTF8` or `SQL_ASCII`), or an integer encoding number.  If unset or set to an empty string the default encoding is set to `UTF8`.  If set to `DEFAULT` Terraform will use the same encoding as the template database.  Changing this value will force the creation of a new resource as this value can only be changed when a database is created.
    encoding = ""

    # lc_collate - (Optional) Collation order (`LC_COLLATE`) to use in the database.  This affects the sort order applied to strings, e.g. in queries with `ORDER BY`, as well as the order used in indexes on text columns. If unset or set to an empty string the default collation is set to `C`.  If set to `DEFAULT` Terraform will use the same collation order as the specified `template` database.  Changing this value will force the creation of a new resource as this value can only be changed when a database is created.
    lc_collate = ""

    # lc_ctype - (Optional) Character classification (`LC_CTYPE`) to use in the database. This affects the categorization of characters, e.g. lower, upper and digit. If unset or set to an empty string the default character classification is set to `C`.  If set to `DEFAULT` Terraform will use the character classification of the specified `template` database.  Changing this value will force the creation of a new resource as this value can only be changed when a database is created.
    lc_ctype = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
postgresql-resource-postgresql_database.description:
The ``postgresql_database`` resource creates and manages [database
objects](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/managing-databases.html)
within a PostgreSQL server instance.

postgresql-resource-postgresql_extension.description:
The ``postgresql_extension`` resource creates and manages an extension on a PostgreSQL
server.

postgresql-resource-postgresql_role.body:
resource "postgresql_role" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the role. Must be unique on the PostgreSQL server instance where it is configured.
    name = ""

    # superuser - (Optional) Defines whether the role is a "superuser", and therefore can override all access restrictions within the database.  Default value is `false`.
    superuser = ""

    # create_database - (Optional) Defines a role's ability to execute `CREATE DATABASE`.  Default value is `false`.
    create_database = ""

    # create_role - (Optional) Defines a role's ability to execute `CREATE ROLE`. A role with this privilege can also alter and drop other roles.  Default value is `false`.
    create_role = ""

    # inherit - (Optional) Defines whether a role "inherits" the privileges of roles it is a member of.  Default value is `true`.
    inherit = ""

    # login - (Optional) Defines whether role is allowed to log in.  Roles without this attribute are useful for managing database privileges, but are not users in the usual sense of the word.  Default value is `false`.
    login = ""

    # replication - (Optional) Defines whether a role is allowed to initiate streaming replication or put the system in and out of backup mode.  Default value is `false`
    replication = ""

    # bypass_row_level_security - (Optional) Defines whether a role bypasses every row-level security (RLS) policy.  Default value is `false`.
    bypass_row_level_security = ""

    # connection_limit - (Optional) If this role can log in, this specifies how many concurrent connections the role can establish. `-1` (the default) means no limit.
    connection_limit = ""

    # encrypted_password - (Optional) Defines whether the password is stored encrypted in the system catalogs.  Default value is `true`.  NOTE: this value is always set (to the conservative and safe value), but may interfere with the behavior of [PostgreSQL's `password_encryption` setting](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/runtime-config-connection.html#GUC-PASSWORD-ENCRYPTION).
    encrypted_password = ""

    # password - (Optional) Sets the role's password. (A password is only of use for roles having the `login` attribute set to true, but you can nonetheless define one for roles without it.) Roles without a password explicitly set are left alone.  If the password is set to the magic value `NULL`, the password will be always be cleared.
    password = ""

    # valid_until - (Optional) Defines the date and time after which the role's password is no longer valid.  Established connections past this `valid_time` will have to be manually terminated.  This value corresponds to a PostgreSQL datetime. If omitted or the magic value `NULL` is used, `valid_until` will be set to `infinity`.  Default is `NULL`, therefore `infinity`.
    valid_until = ""

    # skip_drop_role - (Optional) When a PostgreSQL ROLE exists in multiple databases and the ROLE is dropped, the [cleanup of ownership of objects](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/role-removal.html) in each of the respective databases must occur before the ROLE can be dropped from the catalog.  Set this option to true when there are multiple databases in a PostgreSQL cluster using the same PostgreSQL ROLE for object ownership. This is the third and final step taken when removing a ROLE from a database.
    skip_drop_role = ""

    # skip_reassign_owned - (Optional) When a PostgreSQL ROLE exists in multiple databases and the ROLE is dropped, a [`REASSIGN OWNED`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-reassign-owned.html) in must be executed on each of the respective databases before the `DROP ROLE` can be executed to dropped the ROLE from the catalog.  This is the first and second steps taken when removing a ROLE from a database (the second step being an implicit [`DROP OWNED`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-drop-owned.html)).
    skip_reassign_owned = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
postgresql-resource-postgresql_role.description:
The ``postgresql_role`` resource creates and manages a role on a PostgreSQL
server. When a ``postgresql_role`` resource is removed, the PostgreSQL ROLE will
automatically run a [`REASSIGN
OWNED`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-reassign-owned.html)
and [`DROP
OWNED`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-drop-owned.html) to
the `CURRENT_USER` (normally the connected user for the provider).  If the
specified PostgreSQL ROLE owns objects in multiple PostgreSQL databases in the
same PostgreSQL Cluster, one PostgreSQL provider per database must be created
and all but the final ``postgresql_role`` must specify a `skip_drop_role`. ~> **Note:** All arguments including role name and password will be stored in the raw state as plain-text.
[Read more about sensitive data in state](/docs/state/sensitive-data.html).

postgresql-resource-postgresql_schema.body:
resource "postgresql_schema" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the schema. Must be unique in the PostgreSQL
    name = ""

    # owner - (Optional) The ROLE who owns the schema.
    owner = ""

    # policy - (Optional) Can be specified multiple times for each policy.  Each
    policy = ""

    # create - (Optional) Should the specified ROLE have CREATE privileges to the specified SCHEMA.
    create = ""

    # create_with_grant - (Optional) Should the specified ROLE have CREATE privileges to the specified SCHEMA and the ability to GRANT the CREATE privilege to other ROLEs.
    create_with_grant = ""

    # role - (Optional) The ROLE who is receiving the policy.  If this value is empty or not specified it implies the policy is referring to the [`PUBLIC` role](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-grant.html).
    role = ""

    # usage - (Optional) Should the specified ROLE have USAGE privileges to the specified SCHEMA.
    usage = ""

    # usage_with_grant - (Optional) Should the specified ROLE have USAGE privileges to the specified SCHEMA and the ability to GRANT the USAGE privilege to other ROLEs.
    usage_with_grant = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
postgresql-resource-postgresql_schema.description:
The ``postgresql_schema`` resource creates and manages [schema
objects](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/ddl-schemas.html) within
a PostgreSQL database.

You can provide a string for the resource type (datacenter,image,snapshot,ipblock) and/or resource id parameters which will be queries against available resources. If a single match is found, it will be returned. If your search results in multiple matches, an error will be generated. When this happens, please refine your search string so that it is specific enough to return only one result.

rundeck-resource-job.body:
resource "rundeck_job" "$1" {
    # type - (Required) The name of the plugin to execute.
    type = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the job to execute. The target job must be in the same project as the current job.
    name = ""

    # name - (Required) Unique name that will be shown in the UI when entering values and used as a variable name for template substitutions.
    name = ""

    # command - (Required) Nested block defining one step in the job workflow. A job must have one or more commands. The structure of this nested block is described below.
    command = ""

    # project_name - (Required) The name of the project that this job should belong to.
    project_name = ""

    # description - (Required) A longer description of the job, describing the job in the Rundeck UI.
    description = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the job, used to describe the job in the Rundeck UI.
    name = ""

    # group_name - (Optional) The name of a group within the project in which to place the job. Setting this creates collapsable subcategories within the Rundeck UI's project job index.
    group_name = ""

    # log_level - (Optional) The log level that Rundeck should use for this job. Defaults to "INFO".
    log_level = ""

    # allow_concurrent_executions - (Optional) Boolean defining whether two or more executions of this job can run concurrently. The default is `false`, meaning that jobs will only run sequentially.
    allow_concurrent_executions = ""

    # max_thread_count - (Optional) The maximum number of threads to use to execute this job, which controls on how many nodes the commands can be run simulateneously. Defaults to 1, meaning that the nodes will be visited sequentially.
    max_thread_count = ""

    # continue_on_error - (Optional) Boolean defining whether Rundeck will continue to run subsequent steps if any intermediate step fails. Defaults to `false`, meaning that execution will stop and the execution will be considered to have failed.
    continue_on_error = ""

    # rank_attribute - (Optional) The name of the attribute that will be used to decide in which order the nodes will be visited while executing the job across multiple nodes.
    rank_attribute = ""

    # rank_order - (Optional) Keyword deciding which direction the nodes are sorted in terms of the chosen `rank_attribute`. May be either "ascending" (the default) or "descending".
    rank_order = ""

    # preserve_options_order - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the configured options will be presented in their configuration order when shown in the Rundeck UI. The default is `false`, which means that the options will be displayed in alphabetical order by name.
    preserve_options_order = ""

    # command_ordering_strategy - (Optional) The name of the strategy used to describe how to traverse the matrix of nodes and commands. The default is "node-first", meaning that all commands will be executed on a single node before moving on to the next. May also be set to "step-first", meaning that a single step will be executed across all nodes before moving on to the next step.
    command_ordering_strategy = ""

    # node_filter_query - (Optional) A query string using [Rundeck's node filter language](http://rundeck.org/docs/manual/node-filters.html#node-filter-syntax) that defines which subset of the project's nodes will be used to execute this job.
    node_filter_query = ""

    # node_filter_exclude_precedence - (Optional) Boolean controlling a deprecated Rundeck feature that controls whether node exclusions take priority over inclusions.
    node_filter_exclude_precedence = ""

    # option - (Optional) Nested block defining an option a user may set when executing this job. A job may have any number of options. The structure of this nested block is described below.
    option = ""

    # option - (Optional) `option` blocks have the following structure:
    option = ""

    # default_value - (Optional) A default value for the option.
    default_value = ""

    # value_choices - (Optional) A list of strings giving a set of predefined values that the user may choose from when entering a value for the option.
    value_choices = ""

    # value_choices_url - (Optional) Can be used instead of `value_choices` to cause Rundeck to obtain a list of choices dynamically by fetching this URL.
    value_choices_url = ""

    # require_predefined_choice - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the user is allowed to enter values not included in the predefined set of choices (`false`, the default) or whether a predefined choice is required (`true`).
    require_predefined_choice = ""

    # validation_regex - (Optional) A regular expression that a provided value must match in order to be accepted.
    validation_regex = ""

    # description - (Optional) A longer description of the option to be shown in the UI.
    description = ""

    # required - (Optional) Boolean defining whether the user must provide a value for the option. Defaults to `false`.
    required = ""

    # allow_multiple_values - (Optional) Boolean defining whether the user may select multiple values from the set of predefined values. Defaults to `false`, meaning that the user may choose only one value.
    allow_multiple_values = ""

    # multi_value_delimiter - (Optional) Delimiter used to join together multiple values into a single string when `allow_multiple_values` is set and the user chooses multiple values.
    multi_value_delimiter = ""

    # obscure_input - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the value of this option should be obscured during entry and in execution logs. Defaults to `false`, but should be set to `true` when the requested value is a password, private key or any other secret value.
    obscure_input = ""

    # exposed_to_scripts - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the value of this option is available to scripts executed by job commands. Defaults to `false`.
    exposed_to_scripts = ""

    # command - (Optional) `command` blocks must have any one of the following combinations of arguments as contents:
    command = ""

    # description - (Optional) gives a description to the command block.
    description = ""

    # shell_command - (Optional) `shell_command` gives a single shell command to execute on the nodes.
    shell_command = ""

    # inline_script - (Optional) `inline_script` gives a whole shell script, inline in the configuration, to execute on the nodes.
    inline_script = ""

    # script_file - (Optional) `script_file` and `script_file_args` together describe a script that is already pre-installed on the nodes which is to be executed.
    script_file = ""

    # group_name - (Optional) The name of the group that the target job belongs to, if any.
    group_name = ""

    # run_for_each_node - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the job is run only once (`false`, the default) or whether it is run once for each node (`true`).
    run_for_each_node = ""

    # args - (Optional) A string giving the arguments to pass to the target job, using [Rundeck's job arguments syntax](http://rundeck.org/docs/manual/jobs.html#job-reference-step).
    args = ""

    # config - (Optional) Map of arbitrary configuration parameters for the selected plugin.
    config = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - A unique identifier for the job.
    # "config": (Optional) Map of arbitrary configuration parameters for the selected plugin.
}
rundeck-resource-job.description:
The job resource allows Rundeck jobs to be managed by Terraform. In Rundeck a job is a particular
named set of steps that can be executed against one or more of the nodes configured for its
associated project. Each job belongs to a project. A project can be created with the `rundeck_project` resource.

rundeck-resource-private-key.body:
resource "rundeck_private_key" "$1" {
    # key_material - (Required) The private key material to store, serialized in any way that is accepted by OpenSSH.
    key_material = ""

    # path - (Required) The path within the key store where the key will be stored.
    path = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
rundeck-resource-private-key.description:
The private key resource allows SSH private keys to be stored into Rundeck's key store.
The key store is where Rundeck keeps credentials that are needed to access the nodes on which
it runs commands.

rundeck-resource-project.body:
resource "rundeck_project" "$1" {
    # config - (Required) Map of arbitrary configuration properties for the selected resource model plugin.
    config = ""

    # type - (Required) The name of the resource model plugin to use.
    type = ""

    # resource_model_source - (Required) Nested block instructing Rundeck on how to determine the set of resources (nodes) for this project. The nested block structure is described below.
    resource_model_source = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the project, used both in the UI and to uniquely identify the project. Must therefore be unique across a single Rundeck installation.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the project, to be displayed in the Rundeck UI. Defaults to "Managed by Terraform".
    description = ""

    # default_node_file_copier_plugin - (Optional) The name of a plugin to use to copy files onto nodes within this project. Defaults to `jsch-scp`, which uses the "Secure Copy" protocol to send files over SSH.
    default_node_file_copier_plugin = ""

    # default_node_executor_plugin - (Optional) The name of a plugin to use to run commands on nodes within this project. Defaults to `jsch-ssh`, which uses the SSH protocol to access the nodes.
    default_node_executor_plugin = ""

    # ssh_authentication_type - (Optional) When the SSH-based file copier and executor plugins are used, the type of SSH authentication to use. Defaults to `privateKey`.
    ssh_authentication_type = ""

    # ssh_key_storage_path - (Optional) When the SSH-based file copier and executor plugins are used, the location within Rundeck's key store where the SSH private key can be found. Private keys can be uploaded to rundeck using the `rundeck_private_key` resource.
    ssh_key_storage_path = ""

    # ssh_key_file_path - (Optional) Like `ssh_key_storage_path` except that the key is read from the Rundeck server's local filesystem, rather than from the key store.
    ssh_key_file_path = ""

    # extra_config - (Optional) Behind the scenes a Rundeck project is really an arbitrary set of key/value pairs. This map argument allows setting any configuration properties that aren't explicitly supported by the other arguments described above, but due to limitations of Terraform the key names must be written with slashes in place of dots. Do not use this argument to set properties that the above arguments set, or undefined behavior will result.
    extra_config = ""

    # resource_model_source - (Optional) `resource_model_source` blocks have the following nested arguments:
    resource_model_source = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "name" - The unique name that identifies the project, as set in the arguments.
    # "config" - (Required) Map of arbitrary configuration properties for the selected resource model plugin.
    # "ui_url" - The URL of the index page for this project in the Rundeck UI.
    # "config" - (Required) Map of arbitrary configuration properties for the selected resource model plugin.
}
rundeck-resource-project.description:
The project resource allows Rundeck projects to be managed by Terraform. In Rundeck a project
is the container object for a set of jobs and the configuration for which servers those jobs
can be run on.

rundeck-resource-public-key.body:
resource "rundeck_public_key" "$1" {
    # path - (Required) The path within the key store where the key will be stored. By convention this path name normally ends with ".pub" and otherwise has the same name as the associated private key.
    path = ""

    # key_material - (Optional) The public key string to store, serialized in any way that is accepted by OpenSSH. If this is not included, ``key_material`` becomes an attribute that can be used to read the already-existing key material in the Rundeck store.
    key_material = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "url" - The URL at which the key material can be retrieved from the key store by other clients.
    # "key_material" - If "key_material" is omitted in the configuration, it becomes an attribute that exposes the key material already stored at the given "path".
}
rundeck-resource-public-key.description:
The public key resource allows SSH public keys to be stored into Rundeck's key store.
The key store is where Rundeck keeps credentials that are needed to access the nodes on which
it runs commands. This resource also allows the retrieval of an existing public key from the store, so that it
may be used in the configuration of other resources such as ``aws_key_pair``.

softlayer-resource-ssh-key.body:
resource "ssh_key" "$1" {

    public_key = ""

    # name - (Required) A descriptive name used to identify an SSH key.
    name = ""

    # notes - (Optional) A small note about an SSH key to use at your discretion.
    notes = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the new SSH key
    # "fingerprint" - sequence of bytes to authenticate or lookup a longer SSH key.
}
softlayer-resource-ssh-key.description:
Provides SSK keys. This allows SSH keys to be created, updated and deleted.
For additional details please refer to [API documentation](http://sldn.softlayer.com/reference/datatypes/SoftLayer_Security_Ssh_Key).

    image = ""

    # block_device_template_group_gid - (Optional) `block_device_template_group_gid` | *string*
    block_device_template_group_gid = ""

    # public_network_speed - (Optional) `public_network_speed` | *int*
    public_network_speed = ""
