softlayer-resource-virtual-guest.description:
Provides virtual guest resource. This allows virtual guests to be created, updated
and deleted. For additional details please refer to [API documentation](http://sldn.softlayer.com/reference/services/SoftLayer_Virtual_Guest).

statuscake-test.body:
resource "statuscake_test" "$1" {
    # test_type - (Required) The type of Test. Either HTTP or TCP
    test_type = ""

    # website_url - (Required) The URL of the website to be monitored
    website_url = ""

    # website_name - (Required) This is the name of the test and the website to be monitored.
    website_name = ""

    # check_rate - (Optional) Test check rate in seconds. Defaults to 300
    check_rate = ""

    # contact_id - (Optional) The id of the contact group to be add to the test.  Each test can have only one.
    contact_id = ""

    # paused - (Optional) Whether or not the test is paused. Defaults to false.
    paused = ""

    # timeout - (Optional) The timeout of the test in seconds.
    timeout = ""

    # confirmations - (Optional) The number of confirmation servers to use in order to detect downtime. Defaults to 0.
    confirmations = ""

    # port - (Optional) The port to use when specifying a TCP test.
    port = ""

    # trigger_rate - (Optional) The number of minutes to wait before sending an alert. Default is `5`.
    trigger_rate = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "test_id" - A unique identifier for the test.
}
statuscake-test.description: The test resource allows StatusCake tests to be managed by Terraform.

template-datasource-cloudinit-config.body:
data "cloudinit_multipart" "$1" {
    # content - (Required) Body for the part.
    content = ""

    # part - (Required) One may specify this many times, this creates a fragment of the rendered cloud-init config file. The order of the parts is maintained in the configuration is maintained in the rendered template.
    part = ""

    # gzip - (Optional) Specify whether or not to gzip the rendered output. Default to `true`
    gzip = ""

    # filename - (Optional) Filename to save part as.
    filename = ""

    # content_type - (Optional) Content type to send file as.
    content_type = ""

    # merge_type - (Optional) Gives the ability to merge multiple blocks of cloud-config together.
    merge_type = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "rendered" - The final rendered multi-part cloudinit config.
    # "merge_type" - (Optional) Gives the ability to merge multiple blocks of cloud-config together.
}
template-datasource-cloudinit-config.description: Renders a multi-part cloud-init config from source files.

template-datasource-file.body:
data "template_file" "$1" {
    # template - (Required) The contents of the template. These can be loaded from a file on disk using the [`file()` interpolation function](/docs/configuration/interpolation.html#file_path_).
    template = ""

    # vars - (Optional) Variables for interpolation within the template. Note that variables must all be primitives. Direct references to lists or maps will cause a validation error.
    vars = ""

    # filename - (Optional) _Deprecated, please use `template` instead_. The filename for
    filename = ""

    # vars - (Optional) Variables for interpolation within the template. Note that variables must all be primitives. Direct references to lists or maps will cause a validation error.
    vars = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "template" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "vars" - (Optional) Variables for interpolation within the template. Note that variables must all be primitives. Direct references to lists or maps will cause a validation error.
    # "vars" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "vars" - (Optional) Variables for interpolation within the template. Note that variables must all be primitives. Direct references to lists or maps will cause a validation error.
    # "rendered" - The final rendered template.
    # "vars" - (Optional) Variables for interpolation within the template. Note that variables must all be primitives. Direct references to lists or maps will cause a validation error.
}
template-datasource-file.description: Renders a template from a file.

template-resource-dir.body:
resource "template_dir" "$1" {
    # destination_dir - (Required) Path to the directory where the templated files will be written.
    destination_dir = ""

    # source_dir - (Required) Path to the directory where the files to template reside.
    source_dir = ""

    # vars - (Optional) Variables for interpolation within the template. Note that variables must all be primitives. Direct references to lists or maps will cause a validation error.
    vars = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
template-resource-dir.description:
Renders a directory containing templates into a separate directory of
corresponding rendered files. `template_dir` is similar to [`template_file`](../d/file.html) but it walks
a given source directory and treats every file it encounters as a template,
rendering it to a corresponding file in the destination directory. ~> **Note** When working with local files, Terraform will detect the resource
as having been deleted each time a configuration is applied on a new machine
where the destination dir is not present and will generate a diff to create
it. This may cause "noise" in diffs in environments where configurations are
routinely applied by many different users or within automation systems.

terraform-datasource-remote-state.body:
data "terraform_remote_state" "$1" {
    # backend - (Required) The remote backend to use.
    backend = ""

    # environment - (Optional) The Terraform environment to use.
    environment = ""

    # config - (Optional) The configuration of the remote backend.
    config = ""

    # defaults - (Optional) default value for outputs in case state file is empty or it does not have the output.
    defaults = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "backend" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "config" - See Argument Reference above.
}
terraform-datasource-remote-state.description: Retrieves state meta data from a remote backend

tls-data-source-cert-request.body:
resource "tls_cert_request" "$1" {
    # subject - (Required) The subject for which a certificate is being requested. This is a nested configuration block whose structure is described below.
    subject = ""

    # private_key_pem - (Required) PEM-encoded private key data. This can be read from a separate file using the ``file`` interpolation function. Only an irreversable secure hash of the private key will be stored in the Terraform state.
    private_key_pem = ""

    # key_algorithm - (Required) The name of the algorithm for the key provided in `private_key_pem`.
    key_algorithm = ""

    # dns_names - (Optional) List of DNS names for which a certificate is being requested.
    dns_names = ""

    # ip_addresses - (Optional) List of IP addresses for which a certificate is being requested.
    ip_addresses = ""

    # common_name - (Optional) `common_name` (string)
    common_name = ""

    # organization - (Optional) `organization` (string)
    organization = ""

    # organizational_unit - (Optional) `organizational_unit` (string)
    organizational_unit = ""

    # street_address - (Optional) `street_address` (list of strings)
    street_address = ""

    # locality - (Optional) `locality` (string)
    locality = ""

    # province - (Optional) `province` (string)
    province = ""

    # country - (Optional) `country` (string)
    country = ""

    # postal_code - (Optional) `postal_code` (string)
    postal_code = ""

    # serial_number - (Optional) `serial_number` (string)
    serial_number = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "cert_request_pem" - The certificate request data in PEM format.
    # "serial_number" (string)
}
tls-data-source-cert-request.description:
Generates a *Certificate Signing Request* (CSR) in PEM format, which is the
typical format used to request a certificate from a certificate authority. This resource is intended to be used in conjunction with a Terraform provider
for a particular certificate authority in order to provision a new certificate.
This is a *logical resource*, so it contributes only to the current Terraform
state and does not create any external managed resources. ~> **Compatibility Note** From Terraform 0.7.0 to 0.7.4 this resource was
converted to a data source, and the resource form of it was deprecated. This
turned out to be a design error since a cert request includes a random number
in the form of the signature nonce, and so the data source form of this
resource caused non-convergent configuration. The data source form is no longer
supported as of Terraform 0.7.5 and any users should return to using the
resource form.

tls-resource-locally-signed-cert.body:
resource "tls_locally_signed_cert" "$1" {
    # allowed_uses - (Required) List of keywords each describing a use that is permitted for the issued certificate. The valid keywords are listed below.
    allowed_uses = ""

    # validity_period_hours - (Required) The number of hours after initial issuing that the certificate will become invalid.
    validity_period_hours = ""

    # ca_cert_pem - (Required) PEM-encoded certificate data for the CA.
    ca_cert_pem = ""

    # ca_private_key_pem - (Required) PEM-encoded private key data for the CA. This can be read from a separate file using the ``file`` interpolation function.
    ca_private_key_pem = ""

    # ca_key_algorithm - (Required) The name of the algorithm for the key provided in `ca_private_key_pem`.
    ca_key_algorithm = ""

    # cert_request_pem - (Required) PEM-encoded request certificate data.
    cert_request_pem = ""

    # early_renewal_hours - (Optional) If set, the resource will consider the certificate to have expired the given number of hours before its actual expiry time. This can be useful to deploy an updated certificate in advance of the expiration of the current certificate. Note however that the old certificate remains valid until its true expiration time, since this resource does not (and cannot) support certificate revocation. Note also that this advance update can only be performed should the Terraform configuration be applied during the early renewal period.

    # is_ca_certificate - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the CA flag will be set in the generated certificate. Defaults to `false`, meaning that the certificate does not represent a certificate authority.
    is_ca_certificate = ""

    # digital_signature - (Optional) `digital_signature`
    digital_signature = ""

    # is_ca_certificate - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the CA flag will be set in the generated certificate. Defaults to `false`, meaning that the certificate does not represent a certificate authority.

    content_commitment = ""

    decipher_only = ""

    server_auth = ""

    is_ca_certificate = ""

    # client_auth - (Optional) `client_auth`
    client_auth = ""

    # code_signing - (Optional) `code_signing`

    # "is_ca_certificate" - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the CA flag will be set in the generated certificate. Defaults to "false", meaning that the certificate does not represent a certificate authority.

    # "is_ca_certificate" - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the CA flag will be set in the generated certificate. Defaults to "false", meaning that the certificate does not represent a certificate authority.
}
tls-resource-locally-signed-cert.description:
Generates a TLS certificate using a *Certificate Signing Request* (CSR) and
signs it with a provided certificate authority (CA) private key. Locally-signed certificates are generally only trusted by client software when
setup to use the provided CA. They are normally used in development environments
or when deployed internally to an organization.

tls-resource-private-key.body:
resource "tls_private_key" "$1" {
    # algorithm - (Required) The name of the algorithm to use for the key. Currently-supported values are "RSA" and "ECDSA".
    algorithm = ""

    # rsa_bits - (Optional) When `algorithm` is "RSA", the size of the generated RSA key in bits. Defaults to 2048.
    rsa_bits = ""

    # ecdsa_curve - (Optional) When `algorithm` is "ECDSA", the name of the elliptic curve to use. May be any one of "P224", "P256", "P384" or "P521", with "P224" as the default.
    ecdsa_curve = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "algorithm" - The algorithm that was selected for the key.
    # "ecdsa_curve" - (Optional) When "algorithm" is "ECDSA", the name of the elliptic curve to use. May be any one of "P224", "P256", "P384" or "P521", with "P224" as the default.
    # "private_key_pem" - The private key data in PEM format.
    # "ecdsa_curve" - (Optional) When "algorithm" is "ECDSA", the name of the elliptic curve to use. May be any one of "P224", "P256", "P384" or "P521", with "P224" as the default.
    # "public_key_pem" - The public key data in PEM format.
    # "ecdsa_curve" - (Optional) When "algorithm" is "ECDSA", the name of the elliptic curve to use. May be any one of "P224", "P256", "P384" or "P521", with "P224" as the default.
    # "public_key_openssh" - The public key data in OpenSSH "authorized_keys"
    # "ecdsa_curve" - (Optional) When "algorithm" is "ECDSA", the name of the elliptic curve to use. May be any one of "P224", "P256", "P384" or "P521", with "P224" as the default.
}
tls-resource-private-key.description:
Generates a secure private key and encodes it as PEM. This resource is
primarily intended for easily bootstrapping throwaway development
environments. ~> **Important Security Notice** The private key generated by this resource will
be stored *unencrypted* in your Terraform state file. **Use of this resource
for production deployments is *not* recommended**. Instead, generate
a private key file outside of Terraform and distribute it securely
to the system where Terraform will be run. This is a *logical resource*, so it contributes only to the current Terraform
state and does not create any external managed resources.

tls-resource-self-signed-cert.description:
Generates a *self-signed* TLS certificate in PEM format, which is the typical
format used to configure TLS server software. Self-signed certificates are generally not trusted by client software such
as web browsers. Therefore clients are likely to generate trust warnings when
connecting to a server that has a self-signed certificate. Self-signed certificates
are usually used only in development environments or apps deployed internally
to an organization. This resource is intended to be used in conjunction with a Terraform provider
that has a resource that requires a TLS certificate, such as: ``aws_iam_server_certificate`` to register certificates for use with AWS *Elastic Load Balancer*, *Elastic Beanstalk*, *CloudFront* or *OpsWorks*. ``heroku_cert`` to register certificates for applications deployed on Heroku.

triton-datasource-image.body:
data "triton_image" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (string)   The name of the image
    name = ""

    # os - (Optional) (string)   The underlying operating system for the image
    os = ""

    # version - (Optional) (string)   The version for the image
    version = ""

    # public - (Optional) (boolean)   Whether to return public as well as private images
    public = ""

    # state - (Optional) (string)   The state of the image. By default, only `active` images are shown. Must be one of:   `active`, `unactivated`, `disabled`, `creating`, `failed` or `all`, though the   default is sufficient in almost every case.
    state = ""

    # owner - (Optional) (string)   The UUID of the account which owns the image
    owner = ""

    # type - (Optional) (string)   The image type. Must be one of: `zone-dataset`, `lx-dataset`, `zvol`, `docker` or   `other`.
    type = ""

    # most_recent - (Optional) (bool) If more than one result is returned, use the most recent Image.
    most_recent = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-datasource-image.description:
The `triton_image` data source queries the Triton Image API for an image ID based
on a variety of different parameters.

triton-datasource-network.description:
The `triton_network` data source queries the Triton Network API for a network ID
based on the name of the network.

triton-resource-fabric.body:
resource "triton_fabric" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String, Required, Change forces new resource)   Network name.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) (String, Optional, Change forces new resource)   Optional description of network.
    description = ""

    # subnet - (Optional) (String, Required, Change forces new resource)   CIDR formatted string describing network.
    subnet = ""

    # provision_start_ip - (Optional) (String, Required, Change forces new resource)   First IP on the network that can be assigned.
    provision_start_ip = ""

    # provision_end_ip - (Optional) (String, Required, Change forces new resource)   Last assignable IP on the network.
    provision_end_ip = ""

    # gateway - (Optional) (String, Optional, Change forces new resource)   Optional gateway IP.
    gateway = ""

    # resolvers - (Optional) (List, Optional)   Array of IP addresses for resolvers.
    resolvers = ""

    # routes - (Optional) (Map, Optional, Change forces new resource)   Map of CIDR block to Gateway IP address.
    routes = ""

    # internet_nat - (Optional) (Bool, Optional, Change forces new resource)   If a NAT zone is provisioned at Gateway IP address. Default is `false`. This differs from [CloudAPI](https://apidocs.joyent.com/cloudapi/#CreateFabricNetwork) which implicitly creates a NAT instance by default.   NOTE: There is a known issue in Triton that prevents deletion of fabric networks when `internet_nat` is enabled.
    internet_nat = ""

    # vlan_id - (Optional) (Int, Required, Change forces new resource)   VLAN id the network is on. Number between 0-4095 indicating VLAN ID.
    vlan_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-resource-fabric.description: The `triton_fabric` resource represents an fabric for a Triton account. The fabric is a logical set of interconnected switches.

triton-resource-firewall-rule.body:
resource "triton_firewall_rule" "$1" {
    # rule - (Optional) (string, Required)   The firewall rule described using the Cloud API rule syntax defined at https://docs.joyent.com/public-cloud/network/firewall/cloud-firewall-rules-reference.
    rule = ""

    # enabled - (Optional) (boolean)  Default: `false`   Whether the rule should be effective.
    enabled = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-resource-firewall-rule.description: The `triton_firewall_rule` resource represents a rule for the Triton cloud firewall.

triton-resource-key.body:
resource "triton_key" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (string, Change forces new resource)   The name of the key. If this is left empty, the name is inferred from the comment in the SSH key material.
    name = ""

    # key - (Optional) (string, Required, Change forces new resource)   The SSH key material. In order to read this from a file, use the `file` interpolation.
    key = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-resource-key.description: The `triton_key` resource represents an SSH key for a Triton account.

triton-resource-machine.body:
resource "triton_machine" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (string)   The friendly name for the machine. Triton will generate a name if one is not specified.
    name = ""

    # tags - (Optional) (map)   A mapping of tags to apply to the machine.
    tags = ""

    # cns - (Optional) (map of CNS attributes, Optional)   A mapping of [CNS](https://docs.joyent.com/public-cloud/network/cns) attributes to apply to the machine.
    cns = ""

    # metadata - (Optional) (map, optional)   A mapping of metadata to apply to the machine.
    metadata = ""

    # package - (Optional) (string, Required)   The name of the package to use for provisioning.
    package = ""

    # image - (Optional) (string, Required)   The UUID of the image to provision.
    image = ""

    # networks - (Optional) (list, optional)   The list of networks to associate with the machine. The network ID will be in hex form, e.g `xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx`.
    networks = ""

    # affinity - (Optional) (list of Affinity rules, Optional)   A list of valid [Affinity Rules](https://apidocs.joyent.com/cloudapi/#affinity-rules) to apply to the machine which assist in data center placement. Using this attribute will force resource creation to be serial. NOTE: Affinity rules are best guess and assist in placing instances across a data center. They're used at creation and not referenced after.
    affinity = ""

    # locality - (Optional) (map of Locality hints, Optional)   A mapping of [Locality](https://apidocs.joyent.com/cloudapi/#CreateMachine) attributes to apply to the machine that assist in data center placement. NOTE: Locality hints are only used at the time of machine creation and not referenced after.
    locality = ""

    # firewall_enabled - (Optional) (boolean)  Default: `false`   Whether the cloud firewall should be enabled for this machine.
    firewall_enabled = ""

    # root_authorized_keys - (Optional) (string)   The public keys authorized for root access via SSH to the machine.
    root_authorized_keys = ""

    # user_data - (Optional) (string)   Data to be copied to the machine on boot.
    user_data = ""

    # user_script - (Optional) (string)   The user script to run on boot (every boot on SmartMachines).
    user_script = ""

    # administrator_pw - (Optional) (string)   The initial password for the Administrator user. Only used for Windows virtual machines.
    administrator_pw = ""

    # cloud_config - (Optional) (string)   Cloud-init configuration for Linux brand machines, used instead of `user_data`.
    cloud_config = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-resource-machine.description:
The `triton_machine` resource represents a virtual machine or infrastructure container running in Triton. ~> **Note:** Starting with Triton 0.2.0, Please note that when you want to specify the networks that you want the machine to be attached to, use the `networks` parameter
and not the `nic` parameter.

triton-resource-vlan.body:
resource "triton_vlan" "$1" {
    # vlan_id - (Optional) (int, Required, Change forces new resource)   Number between 0-4095 indicating VLAN ID
    vlan_id = ""

    # name - (Optional) (string, Required)   Unique name to identify VLAN
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) (string, Optional)   Description of the VLAN
    description = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-resource-vlan.description: The `triton_vlan` resource represents an Triton VLAN. A VLAN provides a low level way to segregate and subdivide the network. Traffic on one VLAN cannot, _on its own_, reach another VLAN.

ultradns-resource-dirpool.body:
resource "ultradns_dirpool" "$1" {
    # rdata - (Required) a list of Record Data blocks, one for each member in the pool. Record Data documented below.
    rdata = ""

    # description - (Required) Description of the Traffic Controller pool. Valid values are strings less than 256 characters.
    description = ""

    # type - (Required) The Record Type of the record
    type = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the record
    name = ""

    # zone - (Required) The domain to add the record to
    zone = ""

    # ttl - (Optional) The TTL of the record. Default: `3600`.
    ttl = ""

    # conflict_resolve - (Optional) String. Valid: `"GEO"` or `"IP"`. Default: `"GEO"`.
    conflict_resolve = ""

    # no_response - (Optional) a single Record Data block, without any `host` attribute. Record Data documented below.
    no_response = ""

    # host - (Optional) (Required in `rdata`, absent in `no_response`) IPv4 address or CNAME for the pool member.
    host = ""

    # all_non_configured - (Optional) Boolean. Default: `false`.
    all_non_configured = ""

    # geo_info - (Optional) a single Geo Info block. Geo Info documented below.
    geo_info = ""

    # ip_info - (Optional) a single IP Info block. IP Info documented below.
    ip_info = ""

    # name - (Optional) String.
    name = ""

    # is_account_level - (Optional) Boolean. Default: `false`.
    is_account_level = ""

    # codes - (Optional) Set of geo code strings. Shorthand codes are expanded.
    codes = ""

    # name - (Optional) String.
    name = ""

    # is_account_level - (Optional) Boolean. Default: `false`.
    is_account_level = ""

    # ips - (Optional) Set of IP blocks. IP Info documented below.
    ips = ""

    # start - (Optional) String. IP Address. Must be paired with `end`. Conflicts with `cidr` or `address`.
    start = ""

    # end - (Optional) String. IP Address. Must be paired with `start`.
    end = ""

    # cidr - (Optional) String.
    cidr = ""

    # address - (Optional) String. IP Address.
    address = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The record ID
    # "hostname" - The FQDN of the record
}
ultradns-resource-dirpool.description: Provides an UltraDNS Directional Controller pool resource.

ultradns-resource-probe-http.body:
resource "ultradns_probe_http" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) Kind of limit. Valid values are `"lossPercent"`, `"total"`, `"average"`, `"run"` & `"avgRun"`.
    name = ""

    # limit - (Required) One or more Limit blocks. Only one limit block may exist for each name.
    limit = ""

    # url - (Required) URL to probe.
    url = ""

    # method - (Required) HTTP method. Valid values are`"GET"`, `"POST"`.
    method = ""

    # http_probe - (Required) an HTTP Probe block.
    http_probe = ""

    # threshold - (Required) Number of agents that must agree for a probe state to be changed.
    threshold = ""

    # agents - (Required) List of locations that will be used for probing. One or more values must be specified. Valid values are `"NEW_YORK"`, `"PALO_ALTO"`, `"DALLAS"` & `"AMSTERDAM"`.
    agents = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the pool to probe.
    name = ""

    # zone - (Required) The domain of the pool to probe.
    zone = ""

    # pool_record - (Optional) (optional) IP address or domain. If provided, a record-level probe is created, otherwise a pool-level probe is created.
    pool_record = ""

    # interval - (Optional) Length of time between probes in minutes. Valid values are `"HALF_MINUTE"`, `"ONE_MINUTE"`, `"TWO_MINUTES"`, `"FIVE_MINUTES"`, `"TEN_MINUTES"` & `"FIFTEEN_MINUTE"`. Default: `"FIVE_MINUTES"`.
    interval = ""

    # transaction - (Optional) One or more Transaction blocks.
    transaction = ""

    # total_limits - (Optional) A Limit block, but with no `name` attribute.
    total_limits = ""

    # transmitted_data - (Optional) Data to send to URL.
    transmitted_data = ""

    # follow_redirects - (Optional) Whether to follow redirects.
    follow_redirects = ""

    # warning - (Optional) Amount to trigger a warning.
    warning = ""

    # critical - (Optional) Amount to trigger a critical.
    critical = ""

    # fail - (Optional) Amount to trigger a failure.
    fail = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}

ultradns-resource-probe-ping.body:
resource "ultradns_probe_ping" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) Kind of limit. Valid values are `"lossPercent"`, `"total"`, `"average"`, `"run"` & `"avgRun"`.
    name = ""

    # limit - (Required) One or more Limit blocks. Only one limit block may exist for each name.
    limit = ""

    # ping_probe - (Required) a Ping Probe block.
    ping_probe = ""

    # threshold - (Required) Number of agents that must agree for a probe state to be changed.
    threshold = ""

    # agents - (Required) List of locations that will be used for probing. One or more values must be specified. Valid values are `"NEW_YORK"`, `"PALO_ALTO"`, `"DALLAS"` & `"AMSTERDAM"`.
    agents = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the pool to probe.
    name = ""

    # zone - (Required) The domain of the pool to probe.
    zone = ""

    # pool_record - (Optional) (optional) IP address or domain. If provided, a record-level probe is created, otherwise a pool-level probe is created.
    pool_record = ""

    # interval - (Optional) Length of time between probes in minutes. Valid values are `"HALF_MINUTE"`, `"ONE_MINUTE"`, `"TWO_MINUTES"`, `"FIVE_MINUTES"`, `"TEN_MINUTES"` & `"FIFTEEN_MINUTE"`. Default: `"FIVE_MINUTES"`.
    interval = ""

    # packets - (Optional) Number of ICMP packets to send. Default `3`.
    packets = ""

    # packet_size - (Optional) Size of packets in bytes. Default `56`.
    packet_size = ""

    # warning - (Optional) Amount to trigger a warning.
    warning = ""

    # critical - (Optional) Amount to trigger a critical.
    critical = ""

    # fail - (Optional) Amount to trigger a failure.
    fail = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}

ultradns-resource-rdpool.body:
resource "ultradns_rdpool" "$1" {
    # rdata - (Required) list ip addresses.
    rdata = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the record
    name = ""

    # zone - (Required) The domain to add the record to
    zone = ""

    # order - (Optional) Ordering rule, one of FIXED, RANDOM or ROUND_ROBIN. Default: 'ROUND_ROBIN'.
    order = ""

    # description - (Optional) Description of the Resource Distribution pool. Valid values are strings less than 256 characters.
    description = ""

    # ttl - (Optional) The TTL of the pool in seconds. Default: `3600`.
    ttl = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The record ID
    # "hostname" - The FQDN of the record
}
ultradns-resource-rdpool.description:
Provides an UltraDNS Resource Distribution (RD) pool resource, which are
used to define rules for returning multiple A or AAAA records for a given owner name. Ordering can be FIXED, RANDOM or ROUND_ROBIN.

ultradns-resource-record.body:
resource "ultradns_record" "$1" {
    # type - (Required) The type of the record
    type = ""

    # rdata - (Required) An array containing the values of the record
    rdata = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the record
    name = ""

    # zone - (Required) The domain to add the record to
    zone = ""

    # ttl - (Optional) The TTL of the record
    ttl = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The record ID
    # "name" - The name of the record
    # "rdata" - An array containing the values of the record
    # "type" - The type of the record
    # "ttl" - The TTL of the record
    # "zone" - The domain of the record
    # "hostname" - The FQDN of the record
}

ultradns-resource-tcpool.body:
resource "ultradns_tcpool" "$1" {
    # host - (Required) IPv4 address or CNAME for the pool member.
    host = ""

    # description - (Required) Description of the Traffic Controller pool. Valid values are strings less than 256 characters.
    description = ""

    # rdata - (Required) a list of rdata blocks, one for each member in the pool. Record Data documented below.
    rdata = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the record
    name = ""

    # zone - (Required) The domain to add the record to
    zone = ""

    # ttl - (Optional) The TTL of the record. Default: `3600`.
    ttl = ""

    # run_probes - (Optional) Boolean to run probes for this pool. Default: `true`.
    run_probes = ""

    # act_on_probes - (Optional) Boolean to enable and disable pool records when probes are run. Default: `true`.
    act_on_probes = ""

    # max_to_lb - (Optional) Determines the number of records to balance between. Valid values are integers  `0` - `len(rdata)`. Default: `0`.
    max_to_lb = ""

    # backup_record_rdata - (Optional) IPv4 address or CNAME for the backup record. Default: `nil`.
    backup_record_rdata = ""

    # backup_record_failover_delay - (Optional) Time in minutes that Traffic Controller waits after detecting that the pool record has failed before activating primary records. Valid values are integers `0` - `30`. Default: `0`.
    backup_record_failover_delay = ""

    # failover_delay - (Optional) Time in minutes that Traffic Controller waits after detecting that the pool record has failed before activating secondary records. `0` will activate the secondary records immediately. Integer. Range: `0` - `30`. Default: `0`.
    failover_delay = ""

    # priority - (Optional) Indicates the serving preference for this pool record. Valid values are integers `1` or greater. Default: `1`.
    priority = ""

    # run_probes - (Optional) Whether probes are run for this pool record. Boolean. Default: `true`.
    run_probes = ""

    # state - (Optional) Current state of the pool record. String. Must be one of `"NORMAL"`, `"ACTIVE"`, or `"INACTIVE"`. Default: `"NORMAL"`.
    state = ""

    # threshold - (Optional) How many probes must agree before the record state is changed. Valid values are integers `1` - `len(probes)`. Default: `1`.
    threshold = ""

    # weight - (Optional) Traffic load to send to each server in the Traffic Controller pool. Valid values are integers `2` - `100`. Default: `2`
    weight = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The record ID
    # "hostname" - The FQDN of the record
}
ultradns-resource-tcpool.description: Provides an UltraDNS Traffic Controller pool resource.

vcd-resource-dnat.body:
resource "vcd_dnat" "$1" {
    # internal_ip - (Required) The IP of the VM to map to

vcd-resource-dnat.description:
Provides a vCloud Director DNAT resource. This can be used to create, modify,
and delete destination NATs to map an external IP/port to an internal IP/port.

    local_ip_address = ""

vcd-resource-edgegateway-vpn.description:
Provides a vCloud Director IPsec VPN. This can be used to create,
modify, and delete VPN settings and rules.

vcd-resource-firewall-rules.body:
resource "vcd_firewall_rules" "$1" {
    # default_action - (Required) Either "allow" or "deny". Specifies what to do should none of the rules match

vcd-resource-firewall-rules.description:
Provides a vCloud Director Firewall resource. This can be used to create,
modify, and delete firewall settings and rules.

vcd-resource-network.body:
resource "vcd_network" "$1" {
    # gateway - (Required) The gateway for this network
    gateway = ""

    # edge_gateway - (Required) The name of the edge gateway
    edge_gateway = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the network
    name = ""

    netmask = ""

    # dns_suffix - (Optional) A FQDN for the virtual machines on this network
    dns_suffix = ""

    # dhcp_pool - (Optional) A range of IPs to issue to virtual machines that don't
    dhcp_pool = ""

    # static_ip_pool - (Optional) A range of IPs permitted to be used as static IPs for
    static_ip_pool = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vcd-resource-network.description:
Provides a vCloud Director VDC Network. This can be used to create,
modify, and delete internal networks for vApps to connect.

vcd-resource-snat.body:
resource "vcd_snat" "$1" {
    # internal_ip - (Required) The IP or IP Range of the VM(s) to map from
    internal_ip = ""

    # external_ip - (Required) One of the external IPs available on your Edge Gateway
    external_ip = ""

    # edge_gateway - (Required) The name of the edge gateway on which to apply the SNAT
    edge_gateway = ""

vcd-resource-snat.description:
Provides a vCloud Director SNAT resource. This can be used to create, modify,

vcd-resource-vapp.body:
resource "vcd_vapp" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) A unique name for the vApp
    name = ""

vcd-resource-vapp.description:
Provides a vCloud Director vApp resource. This can be used to create,

    # power_on - (Optional) A boolean value stating if this vApp should be powered on. Default to `true`

    # Exported Attributes

vcd-resource-vapp-vm.description:
Provides a vCloud Director VM resource. This can be used to create,
modify, and delete VMs within a vApp. ~> **Note:** There is known bug with this implementation, that to use the vcd_vapp_vm resource, you must set the paralellism parameter to 1. [We are working on this.](https://github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-vcd/issues/27)

vsphere-data-source-datacenter.description:
The `vsphere_datacenter` data source can be used to discover the ID of a
vSphere datacenter. This can then be used with resources or data sources that
require a datacenter, such as the [`vsphere_host`][data-source-vsphere-host]
data source.

vsphere-data-source-distributed-virtual-.body:
data "vsphere_distributed_virtual_switch" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the distributed virtual switch. This can be a
    name = ""

    # datacenter_id - (Optional) The managed object reference ID of the
    datacenter_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-data-source-distributed-virtual-.description:
The `vsphere_distributed_virtual_switch` data source can be used to discover
the ID and uplink data of a of a vSphere distributed virtual switch (DVS). This
can then be used with resources or data sources that require a DVS, such as the
[`vsphere_distributed_port_group`][distributed-port-group] resource, for which
an example is shown below. ~> **NOTE:** This data source requires vCenter and is not available on direct
ESXi connections.

vsphere-data-source-host.body:
data "vsphere_host" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String) The name of the host. This can be a name or path.	Can be
    name = ""

    # datacenter_id - (Optional) (String, required) The managed object reference ID of a
    datacenter_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-data-source-host.description:
The `vsphere_host` data source can be used to discover the ID of a vSphere
host. This can then be used with resources or data sources that require a host
managed object reference ID.

vsphere-data-source-network.body:
data "vsphere_network" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the network. This can be a name or path.
    name = ""

    # datacenter_id - (Optional) The managed object reference ID of the
    datacenter_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-data-source-network.description:
The `vsphere_network` data source can be used to discover the ID of a network
in vSphere. This can be any network that can be used as the backing for a
network interface for `vsphere_virtual_machine` or any other vSphere resource
that requires a network. This includes standard (host-based) port groups, DVS
port groups, or opaque networks such as those managed by NSX. ~> **NOTE:** This data source requires vCenter and is not available on direct
ESXi connections.

vsphere-data-source-tag-category.description:
The `vsphere_tag_category` data source can be used to reference tag categories
that are not managed by Terraform. Its attributes are exactly the same as the
[`vsphere_tag_category` resource][resource-tag-category], and, like importing,
the data source takes a name to search on. The `id` and other attributes are
then populated with the data found by the search. ~> **NOTE:** Tagging support is unsupported on direct ESXi connections and
requires vCenter 6.0 or higher.

vsphere-data-source-tag-data-source.body:
data "vsphere_tag" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String, required) The name of the tag.
    name = ""

    # category_id - (Optional) (String, required) The ID of the tag category the tag is
    category_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-data-source-tag-data-source.description:
The `vsphere_tag` data source can be used to reference tags that are not
managed by Terraform. Its attributes are exactly the same as the [`vsphere_tag`
resource][resource-tag], and, like importing, the data source takes a name and
category to search on. The `id` and other attributes are then populated with
the data found by the search. ~> **NOTE:** Tagging support is unsupported on direct ESXi connections and
requires vCenter 6.0 or higher.

vsphere-data-source-vmfs-disks.body:
data "vsphere_vmfs_disks" "$1" {
    # host_system_id - (Optional) (String, required) The managed object ID of the host to
    host_system_id = ""

    # rescan - (Optional) (Boolean, optional) Whether or not to rescan storage adapters
    rescan = ""

    # filter - (Optional) (String, optional) A regular expression to filter the disks
    filter = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-data-source-vmfs-disks.description:
The `vsphere_vmfs_disks` data source can be used to discover the storage
devices available on an ESXi host. This data source can be combined with the
[`vsphere_vmfs_datastore`][data-source-vmfs-datastore] resource to create VMFS
datastores based off a set of discovered disks.

vsphere-resource-admin-license.body:
resource "vsphere_license" "$1" {
    # license_key - (Required) The license key to add.
    license_key = ""

    # labels - (Optional) A map of key/value pairs to be attached as labels (tags) to the license key.
    labels = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "edition_key" - The product edition of the license key.
    # "total" - Total number of units (example: CPUs) contained in the license.
    # "used" - The number of units (example: CPUs) assigned to this license.
    # "name" - The display name for the license.
}
vsphere-resource-admin-license.description: Provides a VMware vSphere license resource. This can be used to add and remove license keys.

vsphere-resource-inventory-datacenter.description:
Provides a VMware vSphere datacenter resource. This can be used as the primary
container of inventory objects such as hosts and virtual machines.

vsphere-resource-inventory-folder.body:
resource "vsphere_folder" "$1" {
    # type - (Required) The type of folder to create. Allowed options are
    type = ""

    # path - (Required) The path of the folder to be created. This is relative to
    path = ""

    # vm - (Optional) `vm` (denoting a virtual machine folder), and a supplied folder of
    vm = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) `datacenter` for datacenter folders, `host` for host and cluster folders,
    datacenter = ""

    # vm - (Optional) `vm` for virtual machine folders, `datastore` for datastore folders, and
    vm = ""

vsphere-resource-inventory-folder.description:
The `vsphere_folder` resource can be used to manage vSphere inventory folders.
The resource supports creating folders of the 5 major types - datacenter
folders, host and cluster folders, virtual machine folders, datastore folders,
and network folders. Paths are always relative to the specific type of folder you are creating.
Subfolders are discovered by parsing the relative path specified in `name`, so
`foo/bar` will create a folder named `bar` in the parent folder `foo`, as long
as that folder exists.

vsphere-resource-inventory-tag-category.body:
resource "vsphere_tag_category" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String, required) The name of the category.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) (String, optional) A description for the category.
    description = ""

    # cardinality - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The number of tags
    cardinality = ""

    # associable_types - (Optional) (List of strings, required) A list object types that
    associable_types = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-inventory-tag-category.description:
The `vsphere_tag_category` resource can be used to create and manage tag
categories, which determine how tags are grouped together and applied to
specific objects. For more information about tags, click [here][ext-tags-general]. For more
information about tag categories specifically, click
[here][ext-tag-categories]. ~> **NOTE:** Tagging support is unsupported on direct ESXi connections and
requires vCenter 6.0 or higher.

vsphere-resource-inventory-tag-resource.body:

    # Exported Attributes

vsphere-resource-inventory-tag-resource.description:
The `vsphere_tag` resource can be used to create and manage tags, which allow
you to attach metadata to objects in the vSphere inventory to make these
objects more sortable and searchable. For more information about tags, click [here][ext-tags-general]. ~> **NOTE:** Tagging support is unsupported on direct ESXi connections and
requires vCenter 6.0 or higher.

vsphere-resource-network-distributed-por.body:
resource "vsphere_distributed_port_group" "$1" {
    # distributed_virtual_switch_uuid - (Required) The ID of the DVS to add the
    distributed_virtual_switch_uuid = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the port group.
    name = ""

    # type - (Optional) The port group type. Can be one of `earlyBinding` (static
    type = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional description for the port group.
    description = ""

    number_of_ports = ""

    auto_expand = ""

    # port_name_format - (Optional) An optional formatting policy for naming of
    port_name_format = ""

vsphere-resource-network-distributed-por.description:
The `vsphere_distributed_port_group` resource can be used to manage vSphere
distributed virtual port groups. These port groups are connected to distributed
virtual switches, which can be managed by the
[`vsphere_distributed_virtual_switch`][distributed-virtual-switch] resource. Distributed port groups can be used as networks for virtual machines, allowing
VMs to use the networking supplied by a distributed virtual switch (DVS), with
a set of policies that apply to that individual newtork, if desired. For an overview on vSphere networking concepts, see [this
page][ref-vsphere-net-concepts]. For more information on vSphere DVS
portgroups, see [this page][ref-vsphere-dvportgroup]. ~> **NOTE:** This resource requires vCenter and is not available on direct ESXi
connections.

vsphere-resource-network-distributed-vir.body:
resource "vsphere_distributed_virtual_switch" "$1" {
    # datacenter_id - (Required) The ID of the datacenter where the distributed
    datacenter_id = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the distributed virtual switch.
    name = ""

    # folder - (Optional) The folder to create the DVS in. Forces a new resource
    folder = ""

    # description - (Optional) A detailed description for the DVS.
    description = ""

    # contact_name - (Optional) The name of the person who is responsible for the
    contact_name = ""

    # contact_detail - (Optional) The detailed contact information for the person
    contact_detail = ""

    # lacp_api_version - (Optional) The Link Aggregation Control Protocol group
    lacp_api_version = ""

    # link_discovery_operation - (Optional) Whether to `advertise` or `listen`
    link_discovery_operation = ""

    # link_discovery_protocol - (Optional) The discovery protocol type. Valid
    link_discovery_protocol = ""

    # max_mtu - (Optional) The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the virtual
    max_mtu = ""

    # multicast_filtering_mode - (Optional) The multicast filtering mode to use
    multicast_filtering_mode = ""

    # version - (Optional) - The version of the DVS to create. The default is to
    version = ""

    # tags - (Optional) The IDs of any tags to attach to this resource. See
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-network-distributed-vir.description:
The `vsphere_distributed_virtual_switch` resource can be used to manage VMware
Distributed Virtual Switches. An essential component of a distributed, scalable VMware datacenter, the
vSphere Distributed Virtual Switch (DVS) provides centralized management and
monitoring of the networking configuration of all the hosts that are associated
with the switch. In addition to adding port groups (see the
[`vsphere_distributed_port_group`][distributed-port-group] resource) that can
be used as networks for virtual machines, a DVS can be configured to perform
advanced high availability, traffic shaping, network monitoring, and more. For an overview on vSphere networking concepts, see [this
page][ref-vsphere-net-concepts]. For more information on vSphere DVS, see [this
page][ref-vsphere-dvs]. ~> **NOTE:** This resource requires vCenter and is not available on direct ESXi
connections.

vsphere-resource-networking-host-port-gr.body:
resource "vsphere_host_port_group" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The name of the port group.
    name = ""

    # host_system_id - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The managed object
    host_system_id = ""

    # virtual_switch_name - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The name of
    virtual_switch_name = ""

    # vlan_id - (Optional) (Integer, optional) The VLAN ID/trunk mode for this port group.
    vlan_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-networking-host-port-gr.description:
The `vsphere_host_port_group` resource can be used to manage vSphere standard
port groups on an ESXi host. These port groups are connected to standard
virtual switches, which can be managed by the
[`vsphere_host_virtual_switch`][host-virtual-switch] resource. For an overview on vSphere networking concepts, see [this page][ref-vsphere-net-concepts].

vsphere-resource-networking-host-virtual.body:

    # name - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The name of the virtual switch.
    name = ""

    # host_system_id - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The managed object
    host_system_id = ""

    # mtu - (Optional) (Integer, optional) The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the virtual
    mtu = ""

    # number_of_ports - (Optional) (Integer, optional) The number of ports to create with
    number_of_ports = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-networking-host-virtual.description:
The `vsphere_host_virtual_switch` resource can be used to manage vSphere
standard switches on an ESXi host. These switches can be used as a backing for
standard port groups, which can be managed by the
[`vsphere_host_port_group`][host-port-group] resource. For an overview on vSphere networking concepts, see [this
page][ref-vsphere-net-concepts].

vsphere-resource-storage-file.body:

    # datastore - (Required) The name of the Datastore in which to upload the file to.
    datastore = ""

    # destination_file - (Required) The path to where the file should be uploaded or copied to on vSphere.

    source_datacenter = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The name of a Datacenter in which the file will be uploaded to.
    datacenter = ""

    # source_datastore - (Optional) The name of the Datastore in which file will be copied from.
    source_datastore = ""

    # create_directories - (Optional) Create directories in `destination_file` path parameter if any missing for copy operation.  *Note: Directories are not deleted on destroy operation.
    create_directories = ""

    # Exported Attributes

vsphere-resource-storage-file.description: Provides a VMware vSphere virtual machine file resource. This can be used to upload files (e.g. vmdk disks) from the Terraform host machine to a remote vSphere.  The file resource can also be used to copy files within vSphere.  Files can be copied between Datacenters and/or Datastores. Updates to file resources will handle moving a file to a new destination (datacenter and/or datastore and/or destination_file).  If any source parameter (e.g. `source_datastore`, `source_datacenter` or `source_file`) are changed, this results in a new resource (new file uploaded or copied and old one being deleted).

vsphere-resource-storage-nas-datastore.description:
The `vsphere_nas_datastore` resource can be used to create and manage NAS
datastores on an ESXi host or a set of hosts. The resource supports mounting
NFS v3 and v4.1 shares to be used as datastores. ~> **NOTE:** Unlike [`vsphere_vmfs_datastore`][resource-vmfs-datastore], a NAS
datastore is only mounted on the hosts you choose to mount it on. To mount on
multiple hosts, you must specify each host that you want to add in the
`host_system_ids` argument.

vsphere-resource-storage-vmfs-datastore.body:
resource "vsphere_vmfs_datastore" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The name of the datastore.
    name = ""

    # host_system_id - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The managed object
    host_system_id = ""

    # folder - (Optional) (String, optional) The relative path to a folder to put this
    folder = ""

    # disks - (Optional) (List of strings, required) The disks to use with the datastore.

    # tags - (Optional) (List of strings, optional) The IDs of any tags to attach to this

vsphere-resource-storage-vmfs-datastore.description:
The `vsphere_vmfs_datastore` resource can be used to create and manage VMFS
datastores on an ESXi host or a set of hosts. The resource supports using any
SCSI device that can generally be used in a datastore, such as local disks, or
disks presented to a host or multiple hosts over Fibre Channel or iSCSI.
Devices can be specified manually, or discovered using the
[`vsphere_vmfs_disks`][data-source-vmfs-disks] data source.

    adapter_type = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The name of a Datacenter in which to create the disk.
    datacenter = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-vm-virtual-disk.description: Provides a VMware virtual disk resource.  This can be used to create and delete virtual disks.

    cdrom = ""

    linked_clone = ""

    network_interface = ""

    # tags - (Optional) The IDs of any tags to attach to this resource. See

    # adapter_type - (Optional) The adapter type on the network interface. Can be

    ip_address = ""

    # subnet_mask - (Optional) __Deprecated, please use `ipv4_prefix_length` instead__.
    subnet_mask = ""

    # admin_password - (Optional) The password for the new `administrator`

    domain = ""

    # domain - (Optional) `domain`, `domain_user`, and `domain_user_password` are not all set, all
    domain = ""

    # domain_user_password - (Optional) Password for domain user, in plain text.

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The instance ID.

vsphere-resource-vm-virtual-machine.description:
Provides a VMware vSphere virtual machine resource. This can be used to create,
modify, and delete virtual machines.

vsphere-resource-vm-virtual-machine-snap.body:
resource "vsphere_virtual_machine_snapshot" "$1" {
    # quiesce - (Required) If set to `true`, and the virtual machine is powered
    quiesce = ""

    # memory - (Required) If set to `true`, a dump of the internal state of the
    memory = ""

    # description - (Required) A description for the snapshot.
    description = ""

    # snapshot_name - (Required) The name of the snapshot.
    snapshot_name = ""

    # virtual_machine_uuid - (Required) The virtual machine UUID.
    virtual_machine_uuid = ""

    # remove_children - (Optional) If set to `true`, the entire snapshot subtree
    remove_children = ""

    # consolidate - (Optional) If set to `true`, the delta disks involved in this
    consolidate = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-vm-virtual-machine-snap.description:
The `vsphere_virtual_machine_snapshot` resource can be used to manage snapshots
for a virtual machine. For more information on managing snapshots and how they work in VMware, see
[here][ext-vm-snapshot-management]. ~> **NOTE:** A snapshot in VMware differs from traditional disk snapshots in
that the actual running state of the virtual machine can be taken with the
snapshot as well, all non-independent disks are included in the snapshot
(including any disks that have been attached externally but are not
independent), and VM and disk activity post-snapshot is not included in the
original state. Use this resource with care! VMware nor HashiCorp recommends
retaining snapshots for a extended period of time and does NOT recommend using
them as as backup feature. For more information on the limitation of virtual
machine snapshots, see [here][ext-vm-snap-limitations].
